story:
This is our final push to raise the funds to get to Almagro! We are due to land in less than two months, so every last penny helps us along the way. Read on to discover how you can help... 

About the Production

Music and hearts are beating, and as the love stories are played out, a seemingly harmless prank goes horribly wrong resulting in a tragic fall from grace. 

 Our Twelfth Night is a direct response to our last show, Hamlet. As a company we have been immersed in expressing grief and trauma for the last two years and have now turned our creative forces toward love, music and romance. We finished Hamlet with the ghost of the drowned Ophelia speaking her own narrative to her brother, ‘I am drowned Laertes’. We begin Twelfth Night with the near drowned Viola as if picking up directly from where we left off. With the same actors - Francesca Zoutewelle and Finlay Cormack  - again playing brother and sister we are exploring, as Shakespeare did, where a narrative of courage and hope can lead us as the twins are reunited at the end of the play.

“The play seems as we read it to tremble perpetually on the brink of music” Virginia Woolf 

The show is performed by six young actors, who play all the music; they never leave the stage. Our tale explores love’s madness and our deep human need for music, whilst catching transgender inclinations, emotional transgressions and impossibly romantic reunions.

"Prove true, imagination oh prove true" Viola Act 3 sc 4

With nothing but benches to sit on, instruments to play and costumes and props that may have been washed up on a beach, the actors create an authentic, funny and moving experience for a 21st Century audience.

Director  Kelly Hunter

Composer Tom Chapman

How to Get Involved

We have been selected to perform at the Festival de Teatro Clásico de Almagro on Tuesday 25th July 2017 as part of the Almagro OFF. 150 companies applied, only 10 are chosen and only 4 are international- of which we are 1. This is an immensely exciting opportunity for Flute and this is where you come in. 

In order to create Twelfth Night, and share our music, love, and joy with the world at large, we need your help. By becoming a Flute Angel, and donating today, you can become a part the extraordinary journey that Twelfth Night makes. 

100% of each donation will go towards the creation and delivery of the production, and most importantly, enable us to reach and affect as wide an audience as possible. In return, we offer a broad wealth of thank yous including (but not limited to) original songs, sonnets, and exclusive entry into our rehearsal process. 

More details about our work can be found at www.flutetheatre.co.uk  and more information about Almagro Festival can be found at www.festivaldealmagro.com Further queries can be answered by emma@flutetheatre.co.uk  

Follow us on Twitter @FluteTheatre and Facebook to keep up to date on our work.

story:
"The Very Important Child"

In 2012 we launched our company, The Mostly Everything People, aiming to make relatable theatre work that fascinates and entertains. Last year we produced our first full-length touring show, "The Very Important Child", which went down great with audiences and press (we think). 

Succeeding at the Edinburgh Fringe could take TMEP to the next level - it enables us to be seen by national press, large audiences, and movers/shakers in the world of UK theatre. But in total it will cost us around £6,500. Can you help us raise a quarter of that?

Here's some of what the reviewers said:

“Visually there’s so much to take in and enjoy…I was enthralled throughout.” –Views From the Gods

“It was the most engaging educational theory lesson as well as a good, honest look in the mirror…It was an evening that left me with my mind full of bubbling thoughts and an honest smile on my face.” – Buzz Magazine

What We Need & What You Get

Any amount, small or large is appreciated. But certain contributions will be rewarded!

- £20 or more. You will receive an unplanned improvisation via video from Chris and Jen

- £50 or more. Chris will write you a song about you, perform it and send it to you. 

- £100 or more. Chris and Jen will perform a dance in your honour, filmed and send to you. 

- £250 or more. The Deluxe Dance Package. You will receive a dance from the company with costumes and music.

Our Work

Jennifer and Christopher have gained lots of experience making work for other companies (New Art Club, Royal Exchange, Unicorn Theatre, Mid Wales Opera, Bath International Music Festival, Graeae Theatre, Storyhouse) but have a strong desire to make really arty, impactful work that ordinary people strongly relate to and feel involved in. We love contemporary theatre (because it’s fun, funny, discursive, essential, entertaining, nourishing) but we also recognise there are lots of reasons to stay at home as well! We love making audiences laugh with recognition, disorienting them inside theories, and using lots of clever theatrics. We are preoccupied with human behaviour, development of the mind, and hope the audience recognises themselves.

Other Ways You Can Help

Don't worry if you can't donate. Can you share the campaign on Facebook? Can you tweet a picture of yourself donating? Perhaps you could Instagram yourself screaming to passers by in the street about us? Perhaps you could somehow FIND and CONVINCE some sort of oligarch to support us? and Snapchat it?

story:
Daughters of the Revolution

is Back and Ready to Tour!

Join our heroine Evelyn Murphy on her epic journey down the rabbit-hole of maternity. Can the very people who are there to help you, take your power away? 

 

Hello everyone, this is Kate Harris creator, director, and facilitator of the Daughters of the Revolution play and community experience. We had a very successful sold-out run at the Harbour Playhouse in March of 2016 with an excellent public reception and response to the performance and art installation.

In 2017 we sold out both performances in the Coombe Maternity Hospital and had an incredible engagement with hospital staff, women, and families.

Couldn't make the performance? We have performance clips for you HERE!

The post-show discussions featuring professionals from the maternity services in conversation with the audience were so successful and in demand, that we put them up HERE on the 4elements website for everyone to listen to!

And what participants are these? I'm glad you asked!

Participants included Prof Chris Fitzpatrick, former master of the Coombe Women and Infants University Hospital, Marie O'Connor from Survivors of Symphysiotomy, and Philomena Canning midwife and co-founder of Midwives4Choice. We are so grateful that such prominent members of the Irish maternity system showed up to participate adding much to the vitality and integrity of the experience.

We had some lovely write ups in the Irish Times and by The Waterford Healing Arts Trust.

Thanks to our stunning actors, panel members, and audience participants there is now a demand for our production to tour around Ireland! THE REVOLUTION IS HAPPENING!

However, in order for it to happen, we need some financial help to make the play/experience/provocation work as a touring production.

4elements intends to bring this project to cities around Ireland that are home to major maternity units and in proximity to teaching hospitals. Our next stop is Galway!

Mick Lally Theatre, Galway-Feb 23/24 8pm (2018)

The play, Daughters of the Revolution, is a witty and fast-paced theatrical provocation, exploring a woman’s journey through maternity care in Ireland. The performance is immediately followed by a post-show discussion between the audience and a panel of experts representing a range of perspectives on maternity in Ireland, including obstetric consultants, midwives, doulas, academics, and service users.  The panel and audience will be unique and specific to each area in which Daughters of the Revolution is performed. 

Evelyn’s story creates a picture of contemporary Ireland in a time of rising birth-rates, uncertain economic prospects, and a health service in crisis.  In a year of renewed debate around the treatment of women in the Irish Constitution, Daughters of the Revolution asks: How free are women in Ireland when it comes their maternity experience?

As before, the panels will bring together experts in the field of maternity and social policy to engage in open and honest dialogue with the audience in a safe, creative space. The conversations will be recorded, edited, and uploaded as podcasts to a dedicated SoundCloud account under the title Daughters of Revolution.

What We Need 

Your contribution will go directly to:

  • Sound and Lighting Technicians
  • Payment for Actors
  • Royalties for Original Music by Doc O'Connor
  • Accommodations for the traveling actors and staff
  • Venue Hire
  • Insurance

What You Get 

  • Participant €10: Special thank you on the 4elements website and in the programme
  • Instigator €25: Set of 5 postcards featuring scenes from Daughters of the Revolution!
  • Activator €25: Original Daughters of the Revolution poster signed by the cast and crew plus a thank you in the programme and on the 4elements website
  • Collector €50: You get both the postcards and the touring cast and crew signed poster!
  • Facilitator €100: Exclusive invitation for the Opening Night in the Mick Lally Theatre-Galway, with two tickets to Daughters of the Revolution, as well as the signed poster and special thank you
  • Dramaturge €150: Limited edition soft-bound copy of the Daughters of the Revolution script and poster signed by the cast and crew, as well as the exclusive invitation to the opening night in the Mick Lally Theatre, two tickets to the play, the postcards, and special thank you on the  4elements website
  • Patron €250: Dinner for you and a guest in a restaurant with the cast and crew of Daughters of the Revolution, as well as the limited edition signed script, exclusive invitation to opening night in the Mick Lally, with two tickets to the play, signed poster, postcard set, and special thank you in the programme and a permanent listing on the 4elements website as a patron of the arts.

Other Ways You Can Help

Austerity hitting your wallet?

You can still join the revolution by spreading the word!

Please share this campaign on Facebook and Twitter, tell your friends, colleagues, and family!  

And of course we could always use volunteers, don't be shy, get in touch.

Help make Daughters of the Revolution happen!

Risks & Challenges

There are a variety of risks and challenges associated with a touring production. Here are the top five addressed.

Performance

We will do our best to put on the highest quality production in a variety of different theatre types as well as facilitating the intense and important after show discussions.

Discussions

What we can say to you for the discussions is that we always try to have back up speakers ready to attend in case of accident, sickness, or family emergency. We work closely with each local medical community to ensure that not only are we discussing these issues for Ireland but that we are getting area specific professionals to address the concerns of the city we are performing in. 

Cities

We can only tour as much as the funding we receive allows. We may have to postpone certain performances if our funding goal is not met until such times as we can secure complimentary or additional finances.

The more we get the more we can tour! Want us to come to your city? Contact Kate Harris and see if that can happen! Share us and make it happen! 

Recording and Podcasts

There is always a chance of a poor quality or lost recording. We will not put out an inferior product though. We have not had this happen yet, and here's hoping we don't, but there it is.

Printing and Mailing

We haven't ever had an issue with getting the posters or scripts made, but if they come out poorly we send them back and make sure they are beautiful before you receive them. 

The Impact We Hope To Have:

Daughters of the Revolution is an experiment in using art and performance to shape a public response to the crisis in the Irish maternity services. We are women exploring the underlying conflict between women’s bodily autonomy and the law, with humour and our unique insight on the experience of maternity in Ireland. 

This response is both timely and necessary. Since the death of Savita Halappanavar in University Hospital Galway in October 2012, the maternity services in Ireland have been in a state of continued crisis. The 8th amendment of the Irish constitution has also come under renewed scrutiny in the aftermath of Savita’s death, and the Protection of Life During Pregnancy Act, especially in light of the ‘Y’ case, has done nothing to halt public disquiet in that area.

In the contested narrative of maternity in Ireland, it is time for women to have their say.

With your help we have started the journey. Help us continue to fight for a better Ireland. Join the Revolution today.

We Are:

4elements Theatre Company: Using theatre to create dialogue within society.

Founded in 2009, 4elements tackles political and social issues by transforming them into a broader cultural discussions. 4elements focuses on participatory, interactive, and activist theatre productions. Our goal is to create exceptional artistic experiences based on social engagement.

Kate Harris

Kate Harris is a theatre maker, drama facilitator, and activist. She specializes in interstitial theatre provocations that challenge the line between audience and community. Participatory theatre techniques such as those used in Theatre of the Oppressed provide an accessible framework to engage marginalized communities as well as seasoned theatre goers in combating social exclusion. Kate Harris works and creates theatre in partnership with artists, a wide range of youth and community groups, government and medical groups, and educational institutions; The creation of productive dialogues where many would prefer the issues ignored or unspoken.

Her previous theatre work includes: 

Home (2012) Devised and directed in collaboration with actress Sarah Tapes and performed as a work in progress at the Project Arts Centre; Dodgy Dealings (2011) Devised and written in collaboration with Henrietta Street Adult Community Education Centre, performed at the Dublin Five Lamps Arts Festival in April 2012; Wasted (2011) Devised with ARTSI and the Community Response Drama Group; and Hidden Voices Trilogy (2009) Three short films produced by Community Response Drama Group.

story:
Who We Are

We are a group of young, passionate and dedicated artists all hailing from the William Esper Studio in New York City.  Our love for Stephen Belber's TAPE came to fruition during our two years of training at the studio, after performing several scenes from the play in our classes.  From that point on, a fire was lit underneath us, and we were determined to stage a full production of TAPE after we graduated.

With your help, we are more than determined to make our dream a reality, and bring to life a story we are all very moved to share with the New York theater scene.
 

Why We Need Your Help!

As bright, new, emerging independent artists in New York City, we need your help in order to fully produce and uphold the integrity and the sincerity of the material to the best of our vision and capabilities.  Our goal is $4,000, which will be used to facilitate our production.  Below you can find a specific breakdown of how everything will be budgeted. 

Other Ways You Can Help Us!

We would appreciate any and all support!  If you cannot make a financial donation, we ask that you share our IndieGoGo campaign on social media and by word of mouth to help spread awareness about our production!  We thank you all from the bottom of our hearts for taking time to read and support us!

story:
The Wit is putting on... wait a second, who is The Wit?


The Wit is a Denver based company that was started 3 years ago with the vision of creating vital, genuine and dynamic theatre. To us, theatre has always been nothing less than a way of life—meaning it penetrates (totally a good enough reason to use the word penetrate) and influences nearly every single aspect of daily life. In our three years of existence we’ve come to learn that we are not alone in this. We have spent our formative years cultivating the dream of turning our reality into the thing that we call Lifestyle Theater.


So The Wit is putting on Sarah Ruhl’s Eurydice?


You may be familiar with the myth of Orpheus and his journey into the Underworld to save his true love, the nymph-ish Eurydice, from the clutches of Hades. Eurydice is based on the same Greek fable, but approaches from a different angle—hers. Her curiosity causes her fall from earth and brings her to a world where she must remember who she is. She experiences her fate as a child, lost in the carnival of the strange wonderland into which she plummets. Love and letters are exchanged between worlds and we are challenged to see if fate can be remade. As most myths come from history, here we are shown the unique and enchanting tale from hers.


Why are we asking for money?


Simply, producing quality theatre is costly. One must account for license fees, space rental, costumes, sets and other costs that inevitably crop up along the way. In addition to basic production costs, this show also boasts some amazing technical aspects—like an elevator, that rains.

Your funding will not only fuel this production, but also future projects and helps pay our actors and crew who make all of this possible.

Now you know why we need the money. The question now is, why should you give it?

First of all, we have worked up a whole slew of excellent perks that will not only bring you ‘round the theatre, but will also engage you in the production itself—we’ll even throw in a walk-on role if you’ve the right fare! Additionally, you will be helping to cultivate the growth of a company that is not only focused on enriching the artistic lives of the audience, but also trying to build an independent lifestyle based in art and creative experience.


Risks & Challenges

Producing theatre is no easy feat. It demands time, money, enthusiasm, and creative effort. These resources aren’t abundant in most theater communities. The Wit is unique. Having spent our time growing a dedicated, enthusiastic,and independent creative community, we have developed each of those resources from within. Except for the money. This early on, most other theatre organizations quickly pursue funding in the form of grants or various subsidies. The Wit does not. We believe the surest way to do make good theatre is if the audience keeps paying for it. One dollar, one ticket, one vote. This notion keeps us constantly adapting and trying new ways to create. This is an opportunity to help invest in a young theatre company in a similar manner. To invest in a show that plays on heartstrings, examines thoughts of love and relationships, all driven by the curiosity of an innocent young woman—even if you can’t buy a ticket. It’s an opportunity exercise true patronage of the arts. We need your support to get this accomplished, and not simply the money (which is graciously appreciated), but your minds, hearts and enthusiasm as well... Thank you for considering our company.

So, say I want to give more than $2000—could you use it?

That's so sweet of you. Yes, we could absolutely use it. The more money we are able to raise,  the more sophisticated the sets,  the more elaborate the costumes, and, perhaps, the longer the run. That's sounds kinda cool, right?

If all this sounds interesting and worthy of your time and money take a minute and invest. All these people below will be .pleased that you did.

Cast

  • Lanie Novack

  • Sean Verdu

  • Jaryd Smart

  • Sean Cummings

  • Adeline Mann

  • Wren Schuyler

  • Willa Bograd

Board of Directors

  • Kristin Honiotes

  • J Murray D'Armand

  • Nicholas Kemner

  • Chris Arneson
story_txt:
The Wit is putting on... wait a second, who is The Wit? The Wit is a Denver based company that was started 3 years ago with the vision of creating vital, genuine and dynamic theatre. To us, theatre has always been nothing less than a way of life—meaning it penetrates (totally a good enough reason to use the word penetrate) and influences nearly every single aspect of daily life. In our three years of existence we’ve come to learn that we are not alone in this. We have spent our formative years cultivating the dream of turning our reality into the thing that we call Lifestyle Theater.So The Wit is putting on Sarah Ruhl’s Eurydice? You may be familiar with the myth of Orpheus and his journey into the Underworld to save his true love, the nymph-ish Eurydice, from the clutches of Hades. Eurydice is based on the same Greek fable, but approaches from a different angle—hers. Her curiosity causes her fall from earth and brings her to a world where she must remember who she is. She experiences her fate as a child, lost in the carnival of the strange wonderland into which she plummets. Love and letters are exchanged between worlds and we are challenged to see if fate can be remade. As most myths come from history, here we are shown the unique and enchanting tale from hers.Why are we asking for money?Simply, producing quality theatre is costly. One must account for license fees, space rental, costumes, sets and other costs that inevitably crop up along the way. In addition to basic production costs, this show also boasts some amazing technical aspects—like an elevator, that rains. Your funding will not only fuel this production, but also future projects and helps pay our actors and crew who make all of this possible. Now you know why we need the money. The question now is, why should you give it?First of all, we have worked up a whole slew of excellent perks that will not only bring you ‘round the theatre, but will also engage you in the production itself—we’ll even throw in a walk-on role if you’ve the right fare! Additionally, you will be helping to cultivate the growth of a company that is not only focused on enriching the artistic lives of the audience, but also trying to build an independent lifestyle based in art and creative experience. Risks & ChallengesProducing theatre is no easy feat. It demands time, money, enthusiasm, and creative effort. These resources aren’t abundant in most theater communities. The Wit is unique. Having spent our time growing a dedicated, enthusiastic,and independent creative community, we have developed each of those resources from within. Except for the money. This early on, most other theatre organizations quickly pursue funding in the form of grants or various subsidies. The Wit does not. We believe the surest way to do make good theatre is if the audience keeps paying for it. One dollar, one ticket, one vote. This notion keeps us constantly adapting and trying new ways to create. This is an opportunity to help invest in a young theatre company in a similar manner. To invest in a show that plays on heartstrings, examines thoughts of love and relationships, all driven by the curiosity of an innocent young woman—even if you can’t buy a ticket. It’s an opportunity exercise true patronage of the arts. We need your support to get this accomplished, and not simply the money (which is graciously appreciated), but your minds, hearts and enthusiasm as well... Thank you for considering our company.So, say I want to give more than $2000—could you use it?That's so sweet of you. Yes, we could absolutely use it. The more money we are able to raise,  the more sophisticated the sets,  the more elaborate the costumes, and, perhaps, the longer the run. That's sounds kinda cool, right?If all this sounds interesting and worthy of your time and money take a minute and invest. All these people below will be .pleased that you did.Cast
Lanie Novack
Sean Verdu
Jaryd Smart
Sean Cummings
Adeline Mann
Wren Schuyler
Willa Bograd
Board of Directors
Kristin Honiotes
J Murray D'Armand
Nicholas Kemner
Chris Arneson

story:
The American Century Cycle Project

The Lower Bottom Playaz, Inc, a non-profit theater troupe is Oakland's premiere North American African theater company. The Lower Bottom Playaz, Inc purposefully use performance as a way of increasing social awareness, providing an entry point to community concerns, as well as to stimulate, celebrate and enhance understanding of ourselves and others through the shared experience of live theater. The Lower Bottom Playaz, Inc. utilizing the performing arts to create a more conscious and compassionate public sphere, as well as to inspire, nurture, challenge, educate and empower artists and audiences, intend to foster the enlightenment of more conscious and compassionate communities and to inspire in all of us the willingness to explore new ideas, generate dialogues concerning class, the social order, expanded ideas of literacy, and diversity. We take great pride in presenting theater that is more than entertainment. We create transformative theater.

     We started The American Century Cycle Project in 2011  with the production of Gem of the Ocean by August Wilson. August Wilson is considered by critics to be among the best American playwrights and his American Century Cycle is one of the greatest accomplishments of the American theater. The ten plays that compose this quintessential piece of Americana are performed around the globe but no troupe has ever undertaken the onerous task of presenting the ten plays in the order of the decades representing a century of American history from the off center lens of North American Africans. The chances against a small company from Oakland CA being the first to do so are astronomical yet here we are on the eve on that momentous achievement!

     We have produced the first eight plays of the ten play cycle. In our           Season16. Continua: The American Century Cycle Project, we complete the production of the Cycle with King Hedley, II and Radio Golf.   We invite you to join us as we walk into theater history with the completion of the chronological production of The American Century Cycle by August Wilson.

We Need You

  • We need $8,500.00 to complete the production of our 16th Season. Your generous donation will help to stage King Hedley, II and Radio Golf. You will help to pay performers, buy costumes,light the theater, pay our stage crew, pay for the rights to the work, build sets for both productions and allow us to offer discounted ticketing to marginalized and at-risk groups.
  • We want to share the excitement so we have some great perks to get you into a red carpet mood to support our red carpet season! We deeply appreciate every donation no matter how small. Give what you can to help us in our efforts. For those in a space to dig deeper please check out the perks and pick the one that feels right for you. They are all great!
  • You can make your donation tax deductible by selecting not to perk yourself and 100% of your donation is tax deductible. Please see perks for cash value of perk if you select a perk -- everything above cash value is tax deductible.
  • All funds raised will benefit The Lower Bottom Playaz, Inc in their production of Season16. Continua: The American Century Cycle Project and their other work in community.

Be a Star:

Art has the ability to reflect or inspire reality and theater is a wonderful place to explore the art of being human. The Lower Bottom Playaz are a committed community based troupe that engages community that is just discovering the richness of live performance while offering first class performances that enthrall the most seasoned traditional theater goers.  The commitment to August Wilson and the immense effort  its taken to produce the first eight of the ten plays is a measure of The Lower Bottom Playaz commitment to produce the finest theater possible and their determination to be the first troupe to stage the entire Cycle. The Lower Bottom Playaz really are more than entertainment, they  pay artist and offer substantial opportunities to artist of color, provide access to marginalized audiences by reaching out to groups who don't have the opportunity to enjoy theater, provide a free summer theater program for youth providing a wholesome environment that teaches performance skills and critical literacy, offer free training to aspiring actors along with the opportunity to employ the skills gained , and have provided over one-thousand first theater experiences in their seventeen years of existence. Your contribution can help us continue to be "Community theater at its most committed" and make theater history by completing the Century Cycle.

We invite you to be a vital part of our most exciting year ever. Your support is the push we need to cross the finish line. Please make a donation to help us complete the production of Season16. Continua: The American Century Project.

We Refuse to Fail

Most community theater troupes fail in their first year. We refuse to fail and that's how we got to where we are today. We started out as a gypsy troupe. We became the resident troupe in an outdoor theater where we did over thirty productions. When that theater elected to go dark we became the only troupe to ever do live theater in The African American Library and Museum in Oakland. We were among the inaugural troupes in residence at The Flight Deck in Oakland. We are known for making great theater from talent and determination. Be a part of our triumphant red carpet season and walk with us as we walk with August Wilson. We will complete the Cycle and with your help it will be a red carpet year!

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Please share this campaigning with your networks.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • We appreciate in-kind contributions.
  • Please see our website for our wish list!

story:
(translation for perks is here <|:o) )

                    POURQUOI FAIRE UN DON?/WHY MAKE A DONATION?  

Le but principal de cette recherche de financement est de couvrir les frais pendant la période de création du spectacle de janvier à mai 2016.

Dans le cadre du projet, la période de financement avec Indiegogo est prévue pour:

- le cachet du conseiller artistique

- du studio de répétition

- la confection des costumes

/

The main objective of this financial campaign is to cover costs during the creation process of the long version of the show from January to May 2016.

As part of the project, the financial recruitment with Indiegogo will be invested in:

- counsellor/technician remuneration

- rental of the rehearsal studio

- costume fabrication


  C'EST QUOI?/ WHAT IS IT?

Clown en Devenir désire vous présenter le fruit de ses efforts et vous invite à participer à ce collectif artistique né de la collaboration entre trois acadiens gradués du département d'art dramatique de l'Université de Moncton, N.-B.

Nous sommes présentement en période de création pour notre tout premier spectacle en salle:

                                                      Clown en Devenir

                                                    Au pays des Clowns


/

Becoming Clown wishes to present the _ and invites you to take part in this art collective born from the collaboration between three acadians graduated from the theatre department at Université de Moncton, NB.

We are currently in the creation process for our very first in-theatre show:


                                                       Becoming Clown

                                                         In Clown Land

             

Spectacle multidisciplinaire de 45 minutes offert à un public de tous âges disponible à partir de l’été 2016. Interprété par Audrey James Blanchard, Frédéric Melanson et Stéphanie L. Belanger.

De mai à juillet 2015, nous avons monté un spectacle-laboratoire d’une durée de 15 minutes lors de sessions de création avec Audrey James Blanchard et Stéphanie L. Belanger, dirigées par Frédéric Melanson.

Nous avons présenté notre laboratoire dans divers lieux et événements, tels que: La Tohu (QC), Le Festival du Cirque de Dieppe (N.-B.), La parade du père Noël à Montréal (QC), Carnaval Carmagnole (QC)...

Également, nous offrons en tout temps de l’animation lors d’événements communautaires et corporatifs.

/

A 45-minute multidisciplinary show offered to an audience of all ages, coming in summer 2016. Interpreted by Audrey James Blanchard, Frédéric Melanson and Stéphanie L. Belanger.

From May to July 2015, we put together a 15-minute laboratory/experimental show during creation sessions with Audrey James Blanchard and Stéphanie L. Belanger, directed by Frédéric Melanson.

We have presented the laboratory in many places and events, such as: La Tohu (QC), Le Festival du Cirque de Dieppe (NB), The Christmas parade in Montreal (QC), Carmagnole Carnival (QC)...

We also offer animation services at all times for communal or corporate events.


MISSION

Revaloriser le travail des artistes par l’engagement social, communautaire et environnemental.

Grâce au projet Clown en Devenir, nous souhaitons utiliser l’art au service de la société et rejoindre des communautés qui n’ont parfois peu ou pas d'accès à l’art et à la culture.

Pour ce faire, Clown en Devenir s’implique avec l’organisme humanitaire Clowns Sans Frontières et va participer à des missions humanitaires pour faire des apparitions dans divers lieux, tels que: les hôpitaux, les orphelinats, les centres de retraite, les réserves autochtones, les camps de réfugiés, etc.

Également, en promouvant la conception des décors faits à partir de matériaux récupérés, le projet souhaite encourager le respect de son environnement.

/

Revaluate artists' work through social, communal and environmental commitment.

By way of Becoming Clown project, we hope to use art to serve society as a whole and to reach communities that sometimes have little to no access to art and culture in general.

To do so, Becoming Clown is getting involved with the humanitarian organization Clowns Without Borders and plans to participate to various humanitarian missions, appearing in many different places such as hospitals, orphanages, retirement centres, native reserves, refugee camps, etc.

Also, by promoting the conception of the show as made with recovered/recycled materials, the project wishes to encourage the respect of our environment.


INSPIRATION

Inspiré du jeu clownesque que l’on retrouve en Russie avec la famille Semianyki, du jeu corporel de Michel Courtemanche, du Muppet Show et d’Alice au pays des merveilles, ce spectacle est un voyage au coeur de soi. Puisqu’il n’y a pas deux clowns pareils, il n'y a donc pas un seul et unique pays de clown; chacune des réalités affrontées par nos trois personnages est totalement différente, représentative de leurs personnalités respectives.

Notre travail de création s’oriente vers un spectacle multidisplinaire qui inclut la marionnette, les acrobaties, le jeu clownesque/physique et la musique en direct.  

/

Inspired by the clown approach as presented in Russia by the Semianyki family, the physical theatre done by Michel Courtemanche, the Muppet Show and Alice in Wonderland, this show is a journey inside oneself. Since there are no two clowns alike, there is also no single Clown country; each of the realities confronted by our three characters is entirely different, representative of their respective personalities.

Our creation process is oriented towards a multidisciplinary act that includes puppetry, acrobatics, clownish/physical theatre and live music.


Encouragez l'engagement, donnez généreusement!

Encourage commitment, donate generously!


Vos donations vont permettre à notre équipe de:

Your donations will allow our team to:

  • Partir en mission avec Clowns sans Frontières. // Go on missions with Clowns Without Borders.

  • Faire des apparitions dans les hôpitaux, orphelinats, camps de réfugiés, centres de retraite. // Appear in hospitals, orphanages, refugee centres, retirement centres.

  • Donner des représentations du spectacle en salle au Québec et au Nouveau-Brunswick en 2016. // Present the 45-minute in-theatre show in Quebec and New Brunswick in 2016.

  • Faire la tournée des festivals pour présenter le spectacle dans la rue. // Tour in festivals to present the outdoor show.  


                                                     ÉQUIPE/TEAM

Coordonnatrice et interprète / Coordinator and performer : 

                                                           Stéphanie L. Belanger

Relations de presse et interprète / Press relations and performer : 

                                                         Audrey James Blanchard

Metteur en scène et Interprète / Director and performer :

                                                             Frédéric Melanson

Conseillère financière / Financial advisor :

                                                                 Célia Kodja

Mentor:

                                                                Julie Duguay

Crédit Photos:

                                                           Rachelle Richard-Léger

_____________________________________________________________________________

                                                   CLOWN EN DEVENIR                                                    

 INFO:  

438-837-5368

clownendevenir@outlook.com

http://clownendevenir.wix.com/danslarue // www.facebook.com/clownendevenir


       N'OUBLIEZ PAS DE PARTAGER LA  PAGE SUR VOS RÉSEAUX SOCIAUX!!!

             MERCI POUR VOTRE GÉNÉROSITÉ ;o)


           DON'T FORGET TO SHARE THE PAGE ON YOUR SOCIAL NETWORKS!!!

            THANK YOU FOR YOUR GENEROSITY ;o)


 https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/clown-en-devenir/x/11470068#

 MERCI BEAUCOUP!/THANK YOU VERY MUCH!

****************************************************************************

Avertissement: attendez-vous à des effets secondaires, tels que: vous retrouver en enfance, avoir une envie soudaine de jouer avec un inconnu et même remarquer une augmentation de votre créativité.

Warning: expect side effects such as: reconnecting with your inner child, having the sudden urge to play with a person you've never met before, and even experience an enhancement in creativity.


    REMERCIEMENTS/ THANKS

 Clowns Sans Frontières        Circus Stella

 http://www.clownssansfrontieres.ca/http://www.circus-stella.com/

«Les services offerts sont rendus possibles grâce à la contribution financière d'Emploi-Québec.»

"The services offered are made possible thanks to the financial contribution of Emploi-Québec."

Faire des apparitions dans les hôpitaux, orphelinats, camps de réfugiés, centres de retraite. // Appear in hospitals, orphanages, refugee centres, retirement centres.


Donner des représentations du spectacle en salle au Québec et au Nouveau-Brunswick en 2016. // Present the 45-minute in-theatre show in Quebec and New Brunswick in 2016.
Faire la tournée des festivals pour présenter le spectacle dans la rue. // Tour in festivals to present the outdoor show.  

                                                     ÉQUIPE/TEAM
 Coordonnatrice et interprète / Coordinator and performer : 
                                                           Stéphanie L. Belanger
 Relations de presse et interprète / Press relations and performer : 
                                                         Audrey James Blanchard
 Metteur en scène et Interprète / Director and performer :
                                                             Frédéric Melanson
 Conseillère financière / Financial advisor :
                                                                 Célia Kodja
 Mentor:
                                                                Julie Duguay
 Crédit Photos:
                                                           Rachelle Richard-Léger

438-837-5368
clownendevenir@outlook.com
http://clownendevenir.wix.com/danslarue // www.facebook.com/clownendevenir

       N'OUBLIEZ PAS DE PARTAGER LA  PAGE SUR VOS RÉSEAUX SOCIAUX!!! 
             MERCI POUR VOTRE GÉNÉROSITÉ ;o)

           DON'T FORGET TO SHARE THE PAGE ON YOUR SOCIAL NETWORKS!!! 
            THANK YOU FOR YOUR GENEROSITY ;o)

Warning: expect side effects such as: reconnecting with your inner child, having the sudden urge to play with a person you've never met before, and even experience an enhancement in creativity.

  Clowns Sans Frontières        Circus Stella

story:
A fundraiser to help a young Ontarian soar to new heights.

Dawson Handy, 16, was recently selected to represent Canada at the International Dance Organization - Hip Hop competition in Italy, October 2015.

Dawson is a talented young man, from the small country town of Clinton, Ontario.

He grew up with a passion for dance, excelling specifically at Hip Hop.

One can't deny this 16 year old has skill... it's quite remarkable in fact and hard not to get drawn into his performance.

To be invited to represent Canada on an international stage is a huge honour and a life-changing experience for Dawson.

We are fundraising to help get him there. 

As you can imagine, the cost of flying to Europe with all expenses is not small. In fact, it's many thousands of dollars...  Unfortunately this kind of trip is not funded by grants from the Canadian government. It comes directly out of pocket.

So he needs a little boost from friends in the industry!

What We Need 

  • $6000 will cover all costs.
  • Every dollar will go directly to covering the costs of the trip.
  • If the goal is not reached, every cent donated will still make a difference.

The Impact

Young talents like Dawson need every ounce of support from the community to take a leap and kick start their career.

Have you ever had a dream? A goal in life that you wanted so much?

This is a dream opportunity for Dawson.

For dancers, dance truly is their life. They live and breathe it. The skills needed don't come overnight. They take endless hours of hard work, physical and mental determination. The result is something beautiful to watch, something that draws you in as a viewer and affects you viscerally. 

Now imagine representing your COUNTRY while enacting your passion. Pretty incredible...

The truth is, dance is a tough industry to break into. 

The jump from a small country town dance studio to the booming world scene is huge. And it can be scary.

So let's get behind this inspiring young man.  

Donate now through this webpage.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you don't want to contribute, or don't have the means to - no problem.

Help Dawson by spreading the word. MAKE SOME NOISE about this campaign!

Use the indiegogo share tools to share this on Facebook.

SINCERELY... THANK YOU. 

LET'S GET BEHIND DAWSON AND BOOST HIM TO REPRESENT CANADA IN ITALY!!!!

story:
About The Video Games

Winner of the Encore! Producers' Award and the Robot Teammate + The Accidental Party “Woulda, Coulda, Shoulda” Award. The Video Games is a live-action stage combat, audience-interactive, scripted and partially-improvised show that pits your favorite video game characters against each other to determine who will take the title of “Player One”. It is a blend between the popularized “Hunger Games” series and characters from video games ranging from Super Mario to Mass Effect. Every performance, the audience decides the fate of each of the competitors. No one show is exactly like the last.

Seeing something done on screen is one thing. Doing it live? Game over.

What We Need & What You Get

What we need:

  • Upgrade our costumes and weaponry.
  • Rehearsal space large enough to facilitate a cast of 40.
  • Performance spaces.
  • To pay our actors and choreographers what they rightfully deserve. 
  • Marketing materials such as postcards, posters, online ads, t-shirts, etc.
  • To cover travel expenses for Long Beach Comic-con (Long Beach, CA), Nerd Con (Escondido, CA), Charm City Fringe (Baltimore, MD), Comikaze (Los Angeles, CA), New Orleans Fringe Inc. (New Orleans, LA), Tucson Fringe Theater Festival 2016 (Tucson, AZ), FringeNYC 2016 (New York, NY), San Francisco Fringe Festival 2016 (San Francisco, CA), San Diego Fringe 2016 (San Diego, CA) and Edinburgh Festival Fringe 2016 (Edinburgh, Scotland, UK).
  • Upgrade our special effects and gore.
  • Cake; because we have a lot of birthdays!
What you get:
Depending on your donation, we will give you: t-shirts, tickets, a meet-and-greet with the cast, autographed paraphernalia, an appearance at your party or event (up to 4 characters), or even a private performance! And, our thanks and love. <3 

The Impact

"One of my most cherished childhood memories was playing Banjo-Kazooie and Mario Kart with my dad in the basement. My most cherished possession is a Pokemon Yellow Version that my younger brother saved up his quarters and dimes to buy me for my tenth birthday. When I felt lonely, I would turn on Legend of Zelda: Ocarina of Time and play for hours; solving dungeons and saving the world from Ganondorf's evil clutches. Video games hold a special place in my heart. With the production that we have, it warms my heart and makes me relive all of those moments that I hold near and dear. 

And I know that I'm not alone. 

After each show, we've had people hug us, thanking us for helping them relive their childhoods again. We've had children tell us that we have inspired them to explore new and exciting games and stories. We've had adults congratulate us on capturing the excitement and joy that they felt all those years ago. 

Video games touch people's lives in more ways than one. We want to share that with you."

- David Evan Stolworthy; co-creator of The Video Games. 

Risks & Challenges

"We've been working on this production for over a year and have discovered many things about the project, ourselves, and others. Our production is something that has never been done before; partnering stage combat, improvisation, and audience-interaction to create an immersive experience that changes each night. 

We've also made a strong bond with the cast and crew of this production. Honestly, this is the most supportive, hardworking, and understanding group of people I have had the pleasure of working with! 

However, without proper funding, we will have to table this project for the time being. We're currently extended through the month of July for the Hollywood Fringe Festival 2015 after receiving two awards! We also received word that we have been accepted into the Charm City Fringe Festival (Baltimore, MD), Nerd Con (San Diego, CA), as well as Long Beach Comic-con (Long Beach, CA). We'd like to continue the momentum and even be able to tour the show across the country with state of the art costumes and weaponry. 

We need coins to continue, or it's GAME OVER."

- Jared T. Pixler; co-creator of The Video Games

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Please share this page with your friends and family who love theatre, video games, The Hunger Games, or anyone who just loves to help the arts! 
  • Follow us on Twitter: @TheVideoGamesMB, @mbstage.
  • Like our Facebook page: www.facebook.com/thevideogameslive
  • Come to our extension! We are currently performing at The Actor's Company (916 N Formosa Ave, Los Angeles, CA 90046) every Friday and Saturday @ 11pm through the month of July! Tickets are $15 per person. More information is available at theencoreawards.com/2254.

story:
TERRA FIRMA DANCE THEATRE NEEDS YOUR SUPPORT!

Terra Firma Dance Theatre (TFDT)  kindly invites your support and contributions  in reaching our objective of $3250, to assist in producing our DC-area premiere of  "Mockingbird", the Kaatsbaan-award winning ballet at the prestigious ...

VelocityDC DANCE FESTIVAL 2015!!!


Please take a moment to read on, and help us to reach (or exceed) our goal!

Your support is critical in fulfilling our objectives.....EVERY amount helps.

A Coveted Performance Opportunity at VelocityDC DANCE FESTIVAL 2015
TFDT is pleased to announce it's relocation to our nation's capitol, Washington, DC!
What better way to launch our unique, high-octane signature flair than to share our selection to the region's premiere dance happening, VelocityDC Dance Festival. TFDT was selected from a highly-competitive field of applicants to perform this season, and we couldn't be more thrilled!
We are looking forward to pioneering our way down the path to our new home, and "colonizing" the DC-dance landscape....but we can't do it alone. Your contributions will provide direct support and underwrite the dancers of TFDT; rehearsal space; travel and lodging and creative production development.
On October 15th and 16th, 2015 the dancers of TFDT will take the Harman Stage by storm, in the area-premiere of Mr. Loungway's "Mockingbird".  A significant occasion to launch and introduce new audiences to the award-winning work of TFDT, providing a catalyst to further opportunity for the upcoming season.  We look forward to sharing the stage with notable DC-performing arts stalwarts, Suzanne Farrell Ballet and The Washington Ballet, and invite your support in achieving this milestone.
Your assistance has a deep, far-reaching and long lasting impact and extends far beyond just the scope of this festival, continuing to enable us in providing no-cost to low-cost tickets to underserved audiences to our upcoming performances; remunerate world-class dancers and choreographers that are featured in our season; deepen, broaden and diversify our community outreach efforts;programming and expanding our arts-education programs.
 Kindly consider supporting Terra Firma Dance Theatre, and know that your contribution assists in ensuring arts-accessibility and programming that is of the highest caliber.  All contributions are tax-deductible, and we extend the utmost gratitude.


WHY YOUR SUPPORT MATTERS

Thanks to your past valued support in past seasons, we were able to create a solid foundation that will serve as a springboard as we continue to fulfill our mission objectives in providing affordable and accessible dance of high-artistic merit. 

To share a small sampling of what your past support has enabled:

-Kaatsbaan International Dance Center Residency 2014; producing and performing two critically-championed works.

-We successfully met our fund-raising goals; presenting a full-Spring season featuring the work of Artistic Director, Stuart Loungway; former Cedar Lake dancer, Manuel Vignoulle; and recent Princess Grace-fellowship recipient Loni Landon

-Traveled to Poland, by invitation, to perform at Krakow Nights...an annual arts festival

-Educational-development and outreach projects with Helen Pickett in Forsythe-improvisational techniques.

-Shared the stage with stars of NYCB and ABT in relief efforts for the Philippines, coordinated by Ashley Bouder-NYCB principal

....and much much more

 In expanding the breadth of our activities during the 2015/16 season we invite your support as we undertake this treasured opportunity to immerse ourselves fully in the creation of a new work, and utilize it as a catalyst to expand our ambitious programming and objectives for the following season in our new home.

TO LEARN MORE ABOUT TERRA FIRMA DANCE, please visit www.tfdance.com

·     

About Terra Firma Dance Theatre

 Terra Firma Dance Theatre (TFDT), under the guidance of Artistic Director, Stuart Loungway, serves as a cultural think-tank for the dance landscape of Washington, DC and beyond.

Promoting an environment that cultivates dialogue and the exchange of creative ideas as exemplified through our dance performance, educational outreach and experimental theater initiatives. Our primary focal points are underserved populations and non-traditional theatergoers in order to introduce them to the power of the arts as a life changing force. As a rapidly rising contemporary ballet company, the core of our work focuses on movement as the primary language of basic human interaction and communion.

In providing a risk-free environment of diversity, TFDT emphasizes the value of dance as a medium to enrich, empower and engage all members of the community via its high-quality, accessible and affordable programming.

As vanguard caretakers of the art form of ballet, we actively seek to promote new audiences and heighten their awareness and willingness to move away from “traditional and typical dance models”. With a responsible eye to the future of ballet, we work to provide a progressive and contemporary experience, with the understanding that ballet will not look as it once has.

The interwoven philosophical, societal and political issues of the 18th and 19th centuries, that once informed and governed the creation and understanding of new dance work and art in general, no longer exist. It is with this notion in mind that we embark upon our mission to present a new and viable model that preserves ballet as a current and relevant art form, which carries the potential to provide a deep and long lasting impact upon its audience members

Terra Firma Dance Theater is comprised of 5 high-caliber dancers: Izabela Szylinska (formerly of Polish National Ballet), Lester Badenoch (former dancer w/ Atlanta Ballet, American Repertory Ballet, North Carolina Dance Theatre), Tiffany Mangulabnan (current soloist, Ballet Next; former Principal- Philippine Ballet Theatre); Lukasz Zieba (freelance dancer, Poland, Ailey School professional-track aspirant); Jessica Miller (recent SUNY Purchase graduate)

The company has steadily increased in its capacity with the generous support of the Geraldine Dodge Foundation; New Jersey State Council for the Arts; Hyde and Watson....and supporters such as YOU!

About the Director

Stuart Loungwayis the Founder/Artistic Director of Terra Firma Dance Theatre. His training began with Tania Lichine, Irina Jacobson, and John Clifford before receiving a full scholarship to the prestigious School of American Ballet. He began his professional career performing with the Houston Ballet and Joffrey Ballet, before joining San Francisco Ballet Company and continuing as a Principal Dancer with American Repertory Ballet. He has performed soloist and principal roles in work by David Bintley, James Kudelka, George Balanchine, William Forsythe, Mark Morris, and many others. Mr. Loungway maintains an active schedule as a master teacher, choreographer, performer, and served on the dance faculty at Mason Gross School of the Arts, Rutgers University. Selected as “Who’s Hot” by National Dance Critics Association Chair Karyn Collins, Mr. Loungway’s choreography, as expressed by Robert Johnson of Dance Europe, is “elegant and evocative” and “bodes well for the future of dance.” His work and company have been featured in the national dance publication Pointe Magazine.

His work has been featured at Ballet Builders/New Choreographers on Pointe. He is the recipient of the Individual Fellowship in Choreography, awarded by the New Jersey State Council for the Arts ( a branch of the National Endowment for the Arts), in recognition of the high artistic merit of his work. He has served as an Artist- in-Residence at Rutgers University, Desales University, and most recently choreographed work for the students of SUNY PURCHASE.  He has served as the Ballet Master for Roxey Ballet; as well as a principal faculty member at Joffrey Ballet School , in addition to teaching ballet technique and contemporary ballet at Steps and Peridance. His work and company were selected to be featured at Jacob’s Pillow. He currently is on the faculty of the Peridance Certificate Program; where he also teaches numerous advanced and professional-level ballet classes; he also serves as a company

He is the recipient of the Individual Fellowship in Choreography, awarded by the New Jersey State Council for the Arts ( a branch of the National Endowment for the Arts), in recognition of the high artistic merit of his work. He has served as an Artist- in-Residence at Rutgers University, Desales University, and most recently choreographed work for the students of SUNY PURCHASE.  He has served as the Ballet Master for Roxey Ballet; as well as a principal faculty member at Joffrey Ballet School , in addition to teaching ballet technique and contemporary ballet at Steps and Peridance. His work and company were selected to be featured at Jacob’s Pillow. He currently is on the faculty of the Peridance Certificate Program; where he also teaches numerous advanced and professional-level ballet classes; he also serves as a company

story:
APC Mission

The mission of the Alliance Performance Center of Tucson (APC), is to provide a single location where Tucson’s many, creative performance companies may present their works to appreciative audiences. Theatrical works that illuminate relative human conditions; celebrate the creative arts, theatre, dance, music; and, enjoy the capacity of theatre to entertain, inspire, think, and educate. 

Tucson’s many creative companies produce full seasons of contemporary and classical works, comedy, drama, farce and more, in  original styles, themes and orientations. We have a unique ability to conform the theatre space into various configurations, making each production singular. The APC theatre space is intimate, giving the audience members the feeling of being involved. Most important is, this is run by experienced theatre people. 

Most of Tucson’s theatre companies have had to rehearsed in basements, living rooms, hallways, porches, churches and rented temporary facilities. Some have actually rehearsed in parking lots and allies. 

In addition, APC and it’s resident producing company, the Tucson Alliance of Dramatic Artists (TADA), will be creating classes for youngsters from 6 to 16, young adults from 17 to 25 and even for the older generation interested in learning about theatre. Other individuals and companies will likewise be conducting classes. APC is also planning a Summer Theatre Camp Series. 

Our performance arm, TADA, is dedicated to producing original plays, never before produced on stage. You may have an opportunity of being the first audiences to see the next Tony winner. 

TADA’s Children’s Productions will present children’s shows on many weekends throughout the year, such as the return Active Imagination Theatre. 

WE NEED YOU    

We are currently looking for our new home. A location has been selected. Designs are in the works. HOWEVER, IF YOU HAVE A SUITABLE LOCATION YOU’D LIKE TO DONATE, please let us know. But, as any 501(c)(3) Non-Profit organization, we still need helpWe are asking for funding to help defray the costs of leasing, interior construction,  and maintaining this facility. Our new home,will provide rehearsal space and variable configurations for performance space. It is ADA compliant with PLENTY OF PARKING, which most facilities cannot offer, including handicap- spaces near the entrance

Your donation will help to support and/or underwrite: 

  • Purchase of equipment over and above what we already own
  • Additional seating, as needed
  • Sound equipment
  • Maintenance of the property
  • Eventually, remuneration for an Executive Director
  • The monthly lease payment
  • Building of the facility

THE SIGNIFICANCE   

Non-affiliated theatre companies in Tucson, (Those without their own performance space), enjoy an average total attendance of approximately 17,500 attendees during the regular season, considered to be September thru Mid-May. Many companies have begun to perform during the summer months as well. This would add approximately 4,200 to 5,000 additional seats, for a total of 21,700 to 22,500.  In addition, we will receive revenues from dance troupes, string and brass quartets, solo performers, magicians, even meeting space, and more. 

We would like to make the new APC facility the THEATRE CENTER of Tucson.  One single, central  location. You won’t have to remember which theater you’re going to attend. One location makes it convenient for all. And, the central facility, will bring in new audiences from Tucson’s North and East sides. Essentially, this will be a true Performing Arts Community Center.

The 15-member APC Board of Directors consists of Actors, writers, directors, theatre administrator, technicians and more, people who have approximately 300 years of total experience in theatre and performing arts. We know what to do, but, we need your help to do it. 

YOU CAN HELP APC

Please, spread the word. Share on social media, send an email, come see a show, tell us about your experience. Tell a friend. We want to hear from you. MOST IMPORTANTLY, GET INVOLVED. If you are in Tucson, we’d love to meet you. Perhaps you’ll find a home with APC.

story:
Mozongi au Congo-Brazzaville

Joignez-vous à nous pour soutenir la tournée de Mozongi au Festival International de Théâtre, Danse et Cirque du Congo (FITHEDAC) du 3 au 11 octobre 2015.

Mozongi (Retour), pièce de groupe créée en 1997 et reprise en 2014 pour célébrer les 25 ans de la compagnie, a permis à Zab Maboungou/Compagnie Danse Nyata Nyata d’être Lauréat en danse du 30e Grand Prix du Conseil des Arts de Montréal pour cette œuvre exceptionnelle de corps et d’esprit chorégraphiée par Zab Maboungou et interprétée de façon époustouflante par les interprètes.

Une occasion unique pour les artistes d’aller à la rencontre d’artistes, d’art et de culture dans le pays où Zab Maboungou a vu naître sa passion pour la danse.

Danseurs : Luis Cabanzo, Sarah Elola, Karla Etienne, Gama Fonseca, Jeimy Oviedo Musiciens : Adama Daou et Elli Miller-Maboungou

Zab Maboungou/Compagnie Danse Nyata Nyata

Credo : Les arts, les savoirs et les personnes; les personnes, les arts, les savoirs.

Zab Maboungou/Compagnie Danse Nyata Nyata est née d’une vocation profonde pour l’art, c’est-à-dire ses œuvres et son rôle dans la société : ces deux aspects sont au cœur de de la mission de l’organisme voué à créer des œuvres chorégraphiques et musicales, mais aussi littéraires et didactiques qui témoignent de la volonté de développer l’art de la danse contemporaine, sur un plan qui ne se limite pas à la création et à la production de spectacles mais qui embrasse toute l’activité du développement artistique (recherche, formation et éducation, création et production).

Après plus de 25 ans de présence active sur tous les fronts, la Compagnie a acquis une réputation enviable tant au Québec qu’à l’étranger.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Congo-Brazzaville Tour

Join forces with us in support of Mozongi’s tour to the Festival International de Théâtre, Danse et Cirque du Congo (FITHEDAC – Congo International Festival of Theatre, Dance and Circus), October 3rd – 11th 2015.

Mozongi (Return), a group work created in 1997 and restaged to celebrate the company’s 25 years, enabled Zab Maboungou/Compagnie Danse Nyata Nyata to earn the Conseil des Arts de Montréal 30th Grand Prize Laureate in Dance for this exceptional work of body and Spirit choreographed by Zab Maboungou, with a breathtaking performance by the cast.

A unique opportunity for artists to encounter other artists, art and culture in the country where Zab Maboungou first discovered her passion for dance.

Dancers : Luis Cabanzo, Sarah Elola, Karla Etienne, Gama Fonseca, Jeimy Oviedo. Musicians : Adama Daou and Elli Miller-Maboungou.

Zab Maboungou/Compagnie Danse Nyata Nyata was founded due to a deep vocation for art, for creative works and their role in society. Together these two aspects make up the backbone of this arts organization, whose mission is to create choreographic and musical works, but also literary and didactic productions based on its commitment to develop the art of contemporary dance, not only in terms of creating and producing shows, but also encompassing the full range of artistic development activities (research, training and education, creation and production).

After 25 years of active and engaged presence on all fronts, the Company has earned an enviable reputation both in Québec and abroad.

story:
Let Us Introduce Ourselves!

Hello!
Grace House Productions is very excited to take their inaugural show 'Gruesome Playground Injuries' by Rajiv Joseph to the Chicago Fringe! 

After waving good-bye to foggy San Francisco and setting their sights on bright and sunny Los Angeles, four friends teamed up to combine theatre and film into one beautiful experiment. Thus Grace House Productions was born. With joy that can only be expressed by shouting to the heavens, they will be performing their labor of love in Chicago's Gift Theatre, September 5th, 6th, 11th, 12th, and 13th, 2015.

As the title implies, this show gives the audience an opportunity to see some seriously gruesome injuries. But not the ones you're thinking of! These are the physical and emotional injuries that we inflict on ourselves and each other every day. This play focuses on Dougie and Kayleen, two unlikely friends with a kindred spirit, and how the wounds they inflict on one another not only pave the road of their 30 year-long friendship, but also their lives.

So, you might be asking yourself, "How does film fit into all of this?!" Since the play spans 30 years, cinema (in the form of projections) will act as an interactive vessel so our audience feels like they have jumped through time with Dougie and Kayleen.
It is our sincerest wish that after we return from Chicago, we would love to take this show back on the road and spread the love around California in the cities that we know best: San Francisco and Los Angeles. 

Roll Call! (Who We Are)

FRANNIE MORRISON
(Kayleen)
Frannie is a Seattle native – later adopted by San Francsico where she studied Theatre at San Francisco State University. She performed in and around the Bay Area – notably Spare Stage’s Oleana and the West Coast Premiere of A MAZE put on by Just Theater. Since moving to Los Angeles, Frannie has been fortunate enough to work on a variety of projects on all plains of the industry including the web-series Actors Untitled, California Shakespeare Company’s As You Like It, the film Jersey Boys (2014 - just don’t blink!) And now, embarking on this journey with Grace House! She is so thankful for all the opportunities that come her way and the wonderful people she gets to share and grow with as well as learn from. She wants to thank all for their support on this project. Now let’s get “Gruesome!”

DANNY JOHN FORD
(Doug)
Danny is an actor and comedian who currently resides in Los Angeles. If you do happen to run into him on the street or in a local haunt of his, he will probably talk about his new-found love of being a beach bum, but this has not always been the case. Danny has spent most of his young acting career performing in San Francisco and the outside bay area. Some of his previous performances in the bay area include Russ Horvath's 'Search for the Springsteen Highway' at the Exit Theatre, Les Miserable and Almost, Maine with Marin Summer Theatre for which he received the 2014 Broadway World award for best actor. Danny is very excited to perform in Chicago and tell this beautifully crafted story.

TEA TOPLAK
Director
Téa Toplak is a director and actress with both stage and film experience. Her love for the visual/performing arts began when she landed the role of the Evil Bridge Troll in her 3rd grade production of "The Three Billy Goats." That, along with her love of classic and expressionist film, led her to pursue the arts through education, eventually graduating from SF State University with a B.A. in both Drama and Cinema (Cum Laude) in 2011. She has directed well-known published works – such as Anthony Nielsen’s Normal – as well as original by emerging new playwrights, receiving audience and panel selected awards. When she’s not preoccupied in the theater or chasing down the next freelance production gig, she enjoys playing dress-up, taking pictures, and quoting Casablanca. “We’ll always have Chicago…” Or somethin’ like that:)


HAZELETTE GARNER
Stage Manager

Hazelette Garner is an Actor and Stage Manager residing in Los Angeles, CA. In 2013, she received her BA in Theatre Performance and Management from San Francisco State University. Hazelette, went on to stage manage Marin Summer Theater's Rent, which won the Broadway World San Francisco Award for Best Local Musical. She has also worked with Livermore Valley Opera's productions of Amahl and the Night Visitors (Stage Manager) and Rigoletto (Asst. Stage Manager). Notable roles include Polonius in Hamlet, Mazeppa in Gypsy, Marjorie Newquist in Little Murders.


Here's Our Goal... And How You Can Help!

When deciding what we wanted our financial goal to be, these are the things we took into consideration:

The Now                                                                                                                                     

 -Travel Expenses                                                                                                                                   -Accommodations (Housing)                                                                                                           -Props/Costumes/Make-up                                                                                                              -Set/Projections

Production Costs (72%) that include sets, props, costumes, as well as any registration fees and performance rights that are required for the festival.
Travel & Board (20%) which will afford us a roof over our heads as well as transportation to and around Chicago for the festival.
Promotions (8%) covering the cost of any advertising and marketing materials used for the show.
*All of the donations received will strictly be used to cover these costs. Any overhead will be used to fund future productions of the show as well as our community outreach plans.

The Future                                                                                                                                       

 Because we are a budding theatre company, it is our hope that we'll be able to play, create, and work on many more shows after this one. If all our dreams come true with this campaign and we end up EXCEEDING our goal OR if we come under budget with our Fringe Festival necessities, we plan on using the extra money for shows to come.

How We Plan to Give Back!

In addition to creating more shows, we here at Grace House believe in giving back to the community, as well. As we have all gone to school to study our passion, we understand the impact The Arts have had on society as a whole. Whether it be for the freedom of expression, escapism, or just some fun on a Friday night, theatre and cinema have played an important role in shaping culture and the human condition throughout history. Having our roots in philanthropy and social awareness, we are dedicated to giving back to the community in our High School Outreach Program. 

As stated above, we hope to continue our journey onward from Chicago to the West Coast, depending on the success of our fundraising campaign. With that being said, any additional funding will go towards the goal of bringing this show to local high schools along our cross-country journey. 

Should we reach or surpass our goal, we would be able to set aside a percentage of funds to put on performances and talkbacks at high schools (upperclassmen only!) throughout our run. 

We are really excited about this idea, as it would offer the chance for students to see a professional production using two of the most beloved forms of media -- theatre and film. Not only that, but the particular play we have chosen to perform includes lessons on life, love, and the pursuit of happiness - all important lessons on compassion and connection taught and learned through the open arms of performing arts. 


Other Ways to Lend a Hand!

As thespians and theatre enthusiasts, we know all about financial struggles. So if you are not able to help with donations, we also accept good vibes and lots of love on our social media accounts! Please help us spread the word on our Facebook, Instagram, and Twitter pages. Any support is welcome and much appreciated!

journey.

aside a percentage of funds to put on performances and talkbacks at high schools (upperclassmen only!) throughout our run. 
We are really excited about this idea, as it would offer the
chance for students to see a professional production using two of the most
beloved forms of media -- theatre and film. Not only that, but the particular
play we have chosen to perform includes lessons on life, love, and the pursuit
of happiness - all important lessons on compassion and connection taught and
learned through the open arms of performing arts. 
   
Other Ways to Lend a Hand!


As thespians and theatre enthusiasts, we know all about financial struggles. So if you are not able to help with donations, we also accept good vibes and lots of love on our social media accounts! Please help us spread the word on our Facebook, Instagram, and Twitter pages. Any support is welcome and much appreciated!

story:
My name is Rebekah Brown. And I like to dance. 

I like everything there is about dance - the people, the creation, the lighting, the costumes, the sweat, the music, the drive, the injuries, the teaching, the determination, the passion and the liberation. 

I've taken a roundabout way to get here, but I'm finally here. My very own dance company! This is something I've been dreaming about since I was...oh, I don't know, 13 years old, when I got into my first company, Ashland Regional Ballet. I was so thrilled to be part of something that took such dedication, time, and energy. It was more than fulfilling - being a company member not only taught me about dance, but it also taught me about life and what it means to take pride in what you do and follow through with a commitment. I want to provide that environment for my dancers. Check out the company here and the dancers here. Oh, and stay tuned for more pictures and videos along the way!

We need money.

As a new company, we are starting from nothing. We want to share, but it will take more Benjamins than I have in my pocket. (Actually, I think I only have some Washingtons...) I'm asking you to step up and decide to make a contribution to our company. And guess what, it's a tax write-off!

Why we need money.

All of the money contributed to this campaign will go directly into the company fund. Anything left over will be funneled into the next project.

Here's a breakdown of our costs:
Theatre Rental & Technicians: $1300
Rehearsal Space: $700
Dancer Compensation: $2000
Photos/Marketing: $500
Costumes: $300
Micellaneous: $200

In the "Perks" section, there are special incentives if you'd like to sponsor something in particular. Benefits too!

What if we don't get the money.

Here's the thing. The show will go on, whether we reach our goal or not. The budget I've set up is conservative, yet allows for some wiggle room. However. If we don't reach our goal, we may have to cut corners - and no one likes cut corners. So help us out and maybe we will even exceed our goal! 

What if you can't give any money.

If you can't contribute, I TOTALLY UNDERSTAND. I've been there myself. If you still want to help out, let me know! Whether it be helping out the day of the show or just spreading the word by passing out postcards, anything helps.

THANK YOU!

story:
THE ELEPHANT IN EVERY ROOM I ENTER

Gardiner Comfort & Kel Haney's strikingly intimate solo show will be making its world premiere at La MaMa in New York City, October 15th-31st. After a successful workshop production in La MaMa's The Club in Fall 2014, this piece is ready to be presented in a fully realized production that will open your eyes to the experience of living with Tourette Syndrome, as you follow Gardiner on his travels to the Tourette Association of America's National Conference in Washington, DC.
Join us in this exciting adventure, as we create this groundbreaking piece that will change everyone's understanding of living with Tourette's, in NYC and beyond.

Incredibly Top-Notch Theatre

All contributions will support the creation and promotion of our show :

  • Compensation for everyone involved in the production: designers, choreographer, stage manager, associate director, press rep, technicians, videographers and more
  • Rental of projection equipment 
  • Set, costume, and lighting design, building upon our workshop production, to further heighten the performances visual aspects
  • Additional marketing and advertising costs--to get as many people as possible being aware of and seeing the show

A Disability Uncovered

Tourette's is much maligned in the public eye today, often relegated to a base joke in a comedy showing someone unable to stop swearing. Our play looks to blow that stereotype wide open: an honest examination of the complex and varied difficulties involved with the disability. The awareness that this piece will bring can play a serious part in completely changing the world's view of this syndrome.

A Total Joy to Watch

Alongside the education and awareness ELEPHANT brings, the play is an absolute thrill to experience. A show of comedic portrayals (wild dancing, and a touching memoir all performed by one man) will leave you ecstatic as well as informed. You haven't seen a piece like this before, and it can only happen with your contributions! 

Donate! Share! And Come See Us!

Along with whatever you can afford to give, we'd so appreciate you passing on this page to others who might be interested, as well as (of course) coming to the actual production! Tickets and other info can be found at:

  • http://lamama.org/the-elephant-in-every-room-i-enter-2/
Thank you so much for your help in realizing this incredibly important and exhilarating piece!

story:
Maples Repertory Theatre, North Missouri's Professional theatre, is a not for profit organization located in Macon, a town of 5,500. In 2004, the theatre opened its first season of three shows. Eleven years later, the current season includes six full-scale productions, two cabaret concerts, and a series of small "Afterglow" cabarets. This amazing growth, according to Artistic Director Todd Davison, is due to the support of theatre lovers from across the region. 

About This Project

We have carefully planned this upgrade to include things we need, not just want. The computers we currently use are very old and slow and on the brink of crashing and never coming back alive. Although we do backups periodically, we have new information coming in almost daily and want to make sure we have a safe place to store it all.

Even more importantly, we want to make sure our patron's experiences with Maples Rep are positive; no waiting a long time for your receipt to print, being told to "bear with us just a little longer" when our computers freeze, or being dropped mid-call because our phones' batteries can't last a whole conversation.

We want our patron's experiences while working with the box office and staff to be a reflection upon the experience you can expect from attending a show. We hope to be able to prove to the public that we are a respectable theatre with incredible talent to offer, and we believe this technology upgrade will help us immensely with that objective.

Other Ways You Can Help

We need all the help we can get spreading the word. Please share our campaign however you see fit!
