story:
Ripple of Hope: One Teacher's Journey to Make an Impact 

Hi! I'm Karen Sklaire and I'm excited to present the premiere of my autobiographical solo show Ripple of Hope: One Teacher's Journey to Make an Impact.

Since 2010, I have been developing a solo show that began as a published piece I wrote about my early experiences working as a drama teacher in the South Bronx.  The show, Drama at the Point ,has now evolved into a new play that goes deeper into the teacher’s journey .

"Everything about this little gem of a play is pure gold.  Ms. Sklaire’s writing and performance are irresistible"- Stagebuddy.com

I teamed up with the perfect director- Padraic Lillis (Best Director:New York City International Fringe Festival 2013, Indie Theatre Person of the Year), who directed successful shows related to cutting edge school-related issues such as bullying (Lee Kaplan’s Bully)and school shootings (Adina Taubman’s A Line in the Sand).

"Devastating and should be required viewing" - Washington Post (Bully)

Ripple of Hope, the result of our collaboration, focuses on my 10 year journey in the public school system and the all too common experience of a teacher trying to influence the lives of young people in a meaningful way  while dealing with budget cuts, high stakes testing, and the demonization of teachers.

Teachers Need a Voice

Now is the time to get this show out there!  With tremendous public debate on the future of our country’s public school system,  I am excited, in my own small way, to be that voice and present this unique and highly entertaining perspective to the debate.

What's Happening Now

I am thrilled to announce that I have been accepted into the 2015  Washington DC Capital Fringe Festival (a highly selective theater festival in the D.C. area) this summer. In addition I JUST GOT ACCEPTED into the 2015 New York International Fringe Festival!!!! YAY!! 

Why I need your help

Much like my journey as a teacher, mounting this show and getting it out in front of audiences is not something that I can do alone. The combined cost for DC and NYC is $8000. 

Participating in two major Fringe festivals in the same summer gets pricey! I need help paying for: 

  • Festival Entry fees;
  • Marketing and publicity;
  • Rehearsal space; and 
  • Travel and lodging expenses.
  • Technical crew
  • Director fees
  • Insurance

 You'll receive cool perks for donating and Ripple of Hope is sponsored by Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts organization, so your donations are  tax-deductible. 

 I am certain that if I get this out around the country in various festivals, that many teachers and parents will find themselves empowered and inspired. Your donations will help make this a reality. Big or small ... every penny counts!! Whether $5 or $500- all donations will be put to good use. 

 Other ways to Help...

Please help me spread the word to friends and family about this -- send emails and connect with me on Facebook and Twitter. Please use the Indiegogo Share Tools (see below) and let's get the word out to as many people as we can!

Thank You!

 Every day I find some inspiration in my classroom.  I don’t know where I would be today if it wasn’t for some incredible teachers in my life who helped me really believe that anything is possible. Of all the accomplishments in my life and all the performing and stand-up I have done, nothing beats making a difference in someone’s life. Ripple of Hope enables me to carry what I have learned from the classroom, share it with the community and  ignite some of the passion that inspired me.

story:
The Beanfield


Breach Theatre is an emerging theatre company of graduates from Warwick University.

The Beanfield is a collaboration with Guardian award-winning video artist Dorothy Allen-Pickard - combining live performance with documentary film in a multimedia show about state violence, civic freedom and national heritage. 

Okay, so that was our snappy tag line for all our publicity, but we want to tell you a bit more than that.  We want to explain a bit about the show and where it came from, give some background on the Battle of the  Beanfield and tell you about the project's progress so far. 

Photography by Alex Powell, at Warwick Arts Centre

Making the Show

This year is the 30th anniversary of the Battle of the Beanfield, which we wanted to commemorate with a historical re-enactment. 

On route to begin the 1985 Stonehenge Free festival to celebrate the summer solstice, the Peace Convoy of new-age travellers suffered a brutal assault by the police. It had been co-ordinated by Thatcher's government to uphold an injunction around the stones and to break the travellers' movement.

The police set-up road blocks and attacked vehicles, eventually chasing them off the road into a farmer's beanfield in Wiltshire. There, police burned travellers' mobile homes, took their children into social services, and made the largest civil arrest since World War II. It was a huge display of police brutality resulting in hundreds of arrests but zero convictions. There has never been an official inquiry. 

Our show features interviews with a journalist, a police officer, a traveller and an author of a book on the Beanfield, each of whom give their perspective on the events of that day to help inform our re-enactment as we endeavour to recreate an event that affected hundreds with only a six person ensemble on location in Wiltshire.

During our show, we also try to give the audience an experience of the Stonehenge summer solstice in 2015 - a police-sanctioned but de-politicised night of revelry around the famous rocks. 

We need your help to take the production to the Edinburgh Fringe. 

What We Need & What You Get


We've all put a lot of time, love and money into this project but in this final stretch we need your help! 

Our target is £500, which will contribute towards venue hire, marketing the show, and technical costs. 

Venue Hire

From 7th-22nd August we're performing at The Space on the Mile at the Edinburgh Fringe, and need your help to cover the venue hire. 

Marketing 

Marketing is a vital part of any Edinburgh show. The company will be taking to the streets every day to flyer festival-goers to make sure we can share the show with the greatest number of people possible, and we need help covering the cost of materials to make this happen. 

Technical Support

The show blends live performance with film footage and in order to deliver these elements to a high quality, we have to cover certain costs including lighting, and a transportable screen. Your donation would contribute to the hire of this equipment.

Photography by Alex Powell, at Warwick Arts Centre

The Perks 

Not only are we offering you eternal gratitude, friendship and love - but a wide range of perks to say thank you for your generous donations. From postcards to t-shirts featuring our gorgeous publicity (by Antoine) to live show stills from our Warwick Arts Centre performance (taken by Alex Powell) and access to video content which our 50-minute running time demanded be cut (shot by our very own co-director Dorothy). 


The Impact


The Beanfield has had developed through showings at Warwick Arts Centre and Theatre 503's Edinburgh preview season. 

Have a watch of the Vimeo link above for reactions to the Warwick show. 

Audiences have responded so positively to the project and it has provoked discussion and outrage about what happened at the Beanfield. This show could really make a difference, exposing people to what happened in 1985 and asking to audiences reflect on police brutality and their own civil liberties. 

Other Ways You Can Help


Because, we get it. You might not be in a place to contribute but that doesn't mean you can't help. If you're as passionate about the project as we are help us get our campaign out there by sharing the link. 

The show itself needs an audience so it'd be fantastic if you could share our Facebook events, trailer and videos.

This is such an important project to us, any help you could give us would make the world of difference. 

Over and out, 

Breach Theatre & DAP

Billy, Ellice, Max, Anna, Grace, Tom, Amanda and Dorothy

story:
Short Summary

Hi,

I'm Claire, a Melbourne based actor, writer and producer. 
I'm producing my own show Battlefield Blues for its World Premiere for the 2015 Melbourne Fringe Festival at the Abbotsford Convent. This is a family friendly show and I'm looking forward to bringing it to the families in the City of Yarra and beyond in Melbourne. We have an amazing cast and crew on board for this exciting project.


I am funding the show entirely on my own as we have not received funding, so I am seeking support by raising funds to cover venue hire and props for the season.

What we need

$890 will cover our venue fee at the Abbotsford Convent where we are performing (a well known arts precinct and historical site in Melbourne). 

$110 will cover a portion of our props. Apart from me putting my own money into the show ($3,000 in total) we are raising funds by selling Cadbury Chocolate boxes and gaining in kind support from local companies. Any funds raised will help us have a chance of putting on the best show we possibly can for the school children and parents of Yarra and also provides a chance for the show to break even and possibly make a profit. This would mean that all the creatives on board (actors, directors, designers, stage managers) have a better chance at getting some remuneration for their work and time. 

Have a read below- the play is a real laugh and I'm proud we'll have this as an option for families at this year's Melbourne Fringe festival.

What You Get

Become a Pawn, Knight, Bishop, Queen or King with our 'Perks' on offer including:

* Social media shout outs for you and/ or your business

* Tickets to the show

* Photographs with the cast

* BE in the show- VIP experience

Please have a look at each level to see what you can get for supporting this fun show.

The Impact

You're helping local Melbourne artists put on a strong and entertaining kids show in the September school holidays as part of the Melbourne Fringe Festival and means you're helping us not only promote and assist the artists in the show but also exposing more children and families to the world of theatre, getting people outdoors and interacting as a community through an interactive experience whilst creating the opportunities for new audiences to come to the beautiful arts precinct and historical site that is the Abbotsford Convent. We are also excited this is the first time the Abbotsford Convent will have an outdoor roving show! You will be supporting a joyous creation with benefits for the whole community!

Other Ways You Can Help

ANY amount is greatly appreciated! If we do not reach our goal,  money donated will be fully going into the cost of hiring the grounds of the Abbotsford Convent for 14 shows.

If you can't donate - that's fine! We would greatly appreciate any media shout outs (see our Facebook and Twitter links below) or just tell your friends or family about the show if you think it sounds fun!

Thank you so much and we can't wait to get this show running!

BATTLEFIELD BLUES

A comedy by Claire Pearson

A chessboard in peril. A Queen missing. A King who just feels like a nap.

Battlefield Blues- an interactive outdoor roving comedy adventure about chess pieces that are alive (yes, alive!) for all ages at the Abbotsford convent these September holidays.

Directed by Elizabeth Millington (Melbourne Theatre Company's Women Director's Program 2014, Melbourne International Comedy Festival, Poppy Seed Festival 2015). Written and produced by Claire Pearson (shortlisted twice for Queensland Young Playwright's Award, Anywhere Theatre Festival, Brisbane 2013).

Presented in the style of Monty Python with a twist of Horrible Histories and a dash of medieval warfare – you've never seen a game of chess quite like this!

Audience members help heroic Knight, Churny save the Queen...and the day! Along the way audiences meet Maddington (the Bishop who wants it all), The Pawns (who don't have a thing at all) and the King (who likes making things 'official' because he's got it all). Using the natural surroundings of the Abbotsford Convent grounds to create an immersive outdoor experience- this will be an hour of fun and intrigue!

A family friendly show for 8 + years

VENUE: Abbotsford Convent

1 St Heliers Street, Abbotsford

DATES: 22 -26 September, 29 September- 3October

TIMES: 4pm daily, plus 2pm shows Wednesday and Saturdays (60mins)

TO BOOK TICKETS: visit melbournefringe.com.auor call 9660 9666.

story_txt:
Short
Summary


Hi,

I'm
Claire, a Melbourne based actor, writer and producer. I'm
producing my own show Battlefield Blues for its
World Premiere for the 2015 Melbourne Fringe Festival at the Abbotsford Convent. This is a
family friendly show and I'm looking forward to bringing it to the
families in the City of Yarra and beyond in Melbourne. We have an
amazing cast and crew on board for this exciting project.

I
am funding the show entirely on my own as we have not received
funding, so I am seeking support by raising funds to cover venue hire
and props for the season.

What
we need

$890 will
cover our venue fee at the Abbotsford Convent where we are performing
(a well known arts precinct and historical site in Melbourne). 

$110 will cover
a portion of our props. Apart from me putting my own money into the
show ($3,000 in total) we are raising funds by selling Cadbury
Chocolate boxes and gaining in kind support from local
companies. Any funds raised will help us have a chance of putting on
the best show we possibly can for the school children and parents of
Yarra and also provides a chance for the show to break even and possibly make a profit. This would mean that all the creatives on board (actors, directors, designers,
stage managers) have a better chance at getting some remuneration for their work and time. 

Have
a read below- the play is a real laugh and I'm proud we'll have this
as an option for families at this year's Melbourne Fringe festival.

What
You Get

Become
a Pawn, Knight, Bishop, Queen or King with our 'Perks' on offer
including:

*
Social media shout outs for you and/ or your business

*
Tickets to the show

*
Photographs with the cast

*
BE in the show- VIP experience

Please
have a look at each level to see what you can get for supporting this
fun show.

The
Impact

You're
helping local Melbourne artists put on a strong and entertaining kids
show in the September school holidays as part of the Melbourne Fringe
Festival and means you're helping us not only promote and assist the
artists in the show but also exposing more children and families to
the world of theatre, getting people outdoors and interacting as a
community through an interactive experience whilst creating the
opportunities for new audiences to come to the beautiful arts precinct and historical site that is the Abbotsford Convent. We
are also excited this is the first time the Abbotsford Convent
will have an outdoor roving show! You will be supporting a joyous
creation with benefits for the whole community!

Other
Ways You Can Help

ANY
amount is greatly appreciated! If we do not reach our goal,  money
donated will be fully going into the cost of hiring the grounds of the Abbotsford Convent for 14 shows.

If
you can't donate - that's fine! We would greatly appreciate any media
shout outs (see our Facebook and Twitter links below) or just tell
your friends or family about the show if you think it sounds fun!

Thank
you so much and we can't wait to get this show running!

BATTLEFIELD
BLUES


A
comedy by Claire Pearson

A
chessboard in peril. A Queen missing. A King who just feels like a
nap.

Battlefield
Blues- an interactive outdoor roving comedy adventure about chess
pieces that are alive (yes, alive!) for all ages at the Abbotsford
convent these September holidays.

Directed by
Elizabeth Millington (Melbourne Theatre Company's Women Director's
Program 2014, Melbourne International Comedy Festival, Poppy Seed
Festival 2015). Written and produced by Claire
Pearson (shortlisted twice for Queensland Young Playwright's Award,
Anywhere Theatre Festival, Brisbane 2013).

Presented
in the style of Monty Python with a twist
of Horrible Histories and a dash of medieval warfare
– you've never seen a game of chess quite like this!

Audience
members help heroic Knight, Churny save the Queen...and the day!
Along the way audiences meet Maddington (the Bishop who wants it
all), The Pawns (who don't have a thing at all) and the King (who
likes making things 'official' because he's got it
all). Using the natural surroundings of the Abbotsford Convent
grounds to create an immersive outdoor experience- this will be an
hour of fun and intrigue!

A
family friendly show for 8 + years

VENUE:
Abbotsford
Convent
1
St Heliers Street, Abbotsford

DATES:
22 -26 September, 29 September- 3October

TIMES:
4pm daily, plus 2pm shows Wednesday and Saturdays (60mins)

TO
BOOK TICKETS: visit melbournefringe.com.auor
call 9660
9666.

Adults:
$20 Kids: $12.50

story:
Votre contribution
Suite à la consécration publique de Ravages à Montréal, et à la critique qui ne tarit pas d’éloges, nous sollicitons votre aide pour achever notre tournée à Québec les 6, 7 et 8 mai 2015 à la salle multi du complexe méduse. Alan Lake Factori(e) est passé à travers de multiples étapes de création et, tout au long de ce projet, nous avons pu compter sur le support de fidèles partenaires. Aujourd’hui, nous avons besoin d’un dernier coup de pouce pour aller jusqu'au bout de ce cycle de présentations. Votre appui nous permettrait d'atteindre notre objectif final, de mener ce projet à son succès!

Vos contributions appuieront tous les membres de l’équipe d’Alan Lake Factori(e), afin que tous les collaborateurs puissent être rémunérés à leurs justes valeurs. Le milieu de la danse à Québec est en pleine effervescence, et il le restera tant que les projets qui y prennent forme seront diversifiés. Alan Lake Factori(e) participe à la richesse de ce terreau fertile. Votre aide encouragera par la même le renouveau chorégraphique, tout en contribuant à maintenir active cette dynamique créatrice dans la ville de Québec.

L'équipe Alan Lake Factori(e) pour Ravages, c'est :
Chorégraphe: Alan Lake, avec la complicité des interprètes
Interprètes: Dominic Caron, David Rancourt, Esther Rousseau-Morin et Arielle Warnke St-Pierre
Conseillère artistique: Annie Gagnon
Scénographe: Julie Lévesque
Compositeur: Antoine Berthiaume
Concepteur lumière: François Marceau
Concepteur vidéo: Louis-Robert Bouchard 
Direction de la photographie: François Gamache
Monteur : Jason Arbour
Coloriste : Éric Denis
Direction Technique : Antoine Caron
Graphiste: Isabelle Lapierre
Communications: Ariane Plante et Marion Gotti


Après le succès de ses précédentes, la nouvelle œuvre d’Alan Lake, Ravages, pousse encore plus loin le langage artistique de son créateur. Déterminante dans son cheminement, cette création apparaît comme un tournant majeur dans son parcours en tant que chorégraphe. Sa narration abstraite invite le spectateur à plonger dans un univers brut, mais fragile, une épopée symbolique à la croisée du périssable et de l’immuable.

« Ravages est à la fois dynamite et matière première, douce bohème de prés et urgence amère. Pièce étoffée de plusieurs couches qui se superposent sans défaut de couture. »  - Audray Julien, Dfdanse (17 avril 2015)

« Rencontre fort réussie de la danse, la vidéo et l’installation, Ravages réussit à faire tomber les barrières entre ces trois mondes. Les éléments s’y rencontrent et s’y répondent, donnant au final une œuvre touffue, mystérieuse, chargée de symboles et qui reste en tête bien après le tomber du rideau. » - Iris Gagnon-Paradis, La Presse (15 avril 2015)

« Ravages est une expérience sensorielle qui stimule notre être entier. Amateurs de danse, de cinéma et d’arts visuels, vous trouverez de quoi vous éblouir dans l’interrelation de ces arts. En quelques mots : sublime, métaphorique et unique! » - Eve Tessier, Les Méconnus (18 avril 2015)

Ravages, a été présentée à Montréal par Danse Danse à la Cinquième Salle, à la Place des Arts, du 14 au 18 avril 2015. Cette création sera diffusée à La Rotonde, centre chorégraphique contemporain de Québec les  6, 7 et 8 mai 2015. 

Vous pouvez aussi apporter votre soutien à l'équipe sous d’autres formes:

  • Venir voir les représentations de Ravages qui se tiendront le 6, 7 et 8 mai à la Salle Multi de Méduse : 541, rue Saint-Vallier Est, Québec, QC
  • Partager notre projet sur Indiegogo et sur votre page Facebook
  • Parler de notre projet et faire la promotion de notre spectacle à votre réseau
  • Acheter un espace-publicitaire dans le programme du spectacle
    •

Désormais figure incontournable de la scène émergente en danse contemporaine à Québec, Alan Lake a développé une signature artistique forte. Lake explore en profondeur la relation entre le corps, l’image, l’installation sculpturale et la matière brute.

« Pour moi, l’art peut aider le monde à être beau et meilleur. J’aspire à construire un langage qui transporte provisoirement les corps vers des états poétiques, pour qu’ils rencontrent le monde, pour qu’ils touchent et donnent à voir. » - Alan Lake

« La Place des Arts et Danse Danse ont donné carte blanche à Alan Lake, un artiste talentueux de Québec qui s’impose désormais au-delà de sa ville d’origine par une signature forte, teintée de son parcours en arts visuels. Ravages se présente comme un dialogue entre film, matière et danse alors que le chorégraphe transforme la Cinquième Salle en un lieu poétique de tous les possibles. » - Les programmateurs de Danse Danse.

Alan Lake Factori(e) est une compagnie de danse contemporaine pluridisciplinaire créée et portée par Alan Lake, chorégraphe, interprète, réalisateur et artiste en arts visuels. Basée à Québec, la compagnie est dédiée entièrement à la création et à la diffusion d’œuvres chorégraphiques, d’installations et de films d'art qui mettent en scène le corps, fragile, et son mouvement modelés par l’artiste. La compagnie se consacre à promouvoir la danse contemporaine et la recherche chorégraphique par le biais de spectacles, d’ateliers, de stages, de conférences et d’autres activités connexes.

POUR PLUS D'INFORMATION: http://www.larotonde.qc.ca/spectacle/ravages/
http://www.alanlake.net/

Crédits Photos : © François Gamache

Une création soutenue par le Conseil des Arts et des Lettres du Québec, le Conseil des Arts du Canada et l'Entente de développement culturel de la ville de Québec.
Partenaires à la création: La Place des Arts, La Rotonde, les Productions Recto-Verso, Studio Élément, Spira Film, Circuit-Est et O Vertigo.

story:
Short Summary


With only a month to go and exciting times ahead, the clock is ticking and we are al hugely excited about getting started in Edinburgh. At the moment we are working on our publicity campaign and printing our posters and flyers as well as reaching out to CRUK researchers and staff who will be joining us in Edinburgh as well. Lots to be keeping busy with! 
We've now secured performance funding through support from the Edinburgh CRUK Centre but any donations would still be hugely appreciated and will go straight to CRUK.
Tickets are now available to buy here! https://tickets.edfringe.com/whats-on/tissue

Cancer Out Loud is a student led organisation organising and supporting cancer related charities and events to get people talking about cancer OUT LOUD!
 
One in two people are diagnosed with cancer in their lifetime. 
 
 
Sally is that one, and Tissue is her story.
 

But Sally’s story is not just her story. It’s the story of her mother and her brother, her best friend and her ex, her boss and her doctors. Powerful, sometimes abstract and often darkly funny, Tissue explores many of the painful issues surrounding a cancer diagnosis in the 1970s. In the 1970s, when the play was written, cancer survival rates were 1 in 4. Today 2 in 4 people will survive cancer, and CRUK researchers hope to make that survival rate reach 3 in 4 over the next 20 years.

After each performance there will be chance to ask questions during an informal panel discussion and Q&A with a local cancer survivor and staff from the Western General Hospital & CRUK Edinburgh Centre. Find out more about how the patient journey has changed in the last 40 years, and what things we still need to improve.

Following the success and positive response to our performances of Louise Page's Tissue  in Edinburgh, October 2014 and April 2015, we are now performing again for 5 days at 'The Space on Niddry Street' at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival from the 24th - 29th August 2015 to raise awareness and get people talking, thinking, and understanding more about cancer. Our production is in close association with the Cancer Research UK Edinburgh Centre and all profits raised from ticket sales will go directly to the Cancer Research UK. 

'Tissue' is presented in a special arrangement with Samuel French London

What We Need & What You Get

Volunteer members of staff and patients from the Cancer Research UK Edinburgh centre

Local CRUK staff are supporting our Edinburgh Fringe Festival registration fee as well as developing our marketing plan but we need to raise a further £1330 to cover the venue hire, play rights and technical hire. 

Here is a brief breakdown of costs: 
Venue: £850 (5 performances in the Upper Theatre, Niddry Street)
Play rights: £340 (5 performances charged at £68 each) 
Public Liability Insurance: £80

In order to show our gratitude, every £15 donor will receive a free ticket to one of our Fringe performances. 
Any additional funds raised will be donated directly to Cancer Research UK 

The Impact

Your donation, however big or small will have a huge impact on the success of our production and on our campaign to get people talking about cancer out loud. Even if our production means that one person changes the way that they think about cancer or gets themselves checked out then that is our job done. 


By producing and performing this play, we are one step closer to winning the battle against cancer - people's perception of it as a disease, and the seminal role of researchers, scientists and doctor. 


In 2014, we organised a number of 'pop-up' performances around Edinburgh, supporting the wonderful charity Coppafeel. We read poems and spoken word in public spaces to get people talking and thinking openly about cancer. The response was wonderful, so please see our pictures and videos for more information. 


Other Ways You Can Help

Please like our Cancer Out Loud Facebook page, follow us on Twitter to keep up to date with our adventure. Spread the word! If you are interested in watching our performance, tickets are now available to buy here: https://edinburghfestival.list.co.uk/event/4961...

story:
Short Summary

Digested Disney is a 90-minute, audience interactive parody of all the Disney animated films performed by Sean and John and directed by Sam. Digested Disney will be performing at the Long Beach Playhouse on January 15, 16, 22, and 23 at 8pm and January 17 at 2pm.

What We Need 

Your support will offset the cost of theater rent, props, costumes, set pieces, marketing, printing, and travel.

What You Get

In recognition and gratitude for your support, we humbly offer you these great gifts:

  • Tickets to the show and FastPass access
  • Bits and pieces of our dignity 
  • Personalized gifts 
  • Other wacky items

Risks & Challenges

Since we follow the "Show Must Go On" rule, we will perform Digested Disney without props, set pieces... and costumes. Please help us perform this show with costumes.

Other Ways You Can Help

We will accept Disney donations (memorabilia, props, and other items)

What We Need  Your support will offset the cost of theater rent, props, costumes, set pieces, marketing, printing, and travel.
    What You Get In recognition and gratitude for your support, we humbly offer you these great gifts:  Tickets to the show and FastPass access
Bits and pieces of our dignity  Personalized gifts  Other wacky items    Risks & Challenges  Since we follow the "Show Must Go On" rule, we will perform Digested Disney without props, set pieces... and costumes. Please help us perform this show with costumes.   Other Ways You Can Help We will accept Disney donations (memorabilia, props, and other items)

story:
The above video is a test shoot that pretty accurately displays the capabilities of our film equipment for this dance video. This is one of the many different ways that we can shoot a dance video. The stabilizer and camera combo create a stunningly captivating breadth of movement and image quality that will contribute dramatically to the movement of a dancer.

Who is Conor Biddle?

I am a passionate dancer and a passionate filmmaker. I go to Emerson College and specialize in dance cinematography. The only person who can properly shoot a dance video is a dancer themselves. A non-dancer does not quite understand the way the body needs to be captured and the way that the body can move nor the way the camera needs to move in sync with the music. 

What is this project?

This project is an essay on the importance of dance, the importance of culture, and the importance of Boston to all of us. 

Our hope is that we can get one dancer from each of the popular dance studios in Boston (Urbanity, Static Noyze, Dance Complex, Green Street Studios) as well as one dancer from colleges (Emerson, Harvard, Northeastern, BU, MIT, Suffolk) to be a part of our video. All of this will be not only to make a breathtaking video full of talent but to bring the dance community closer together as a whole.

The video will open with a shot of multiple dancers walking down the street laughing. The music will begin to pick up and they'll look at each other and all run in opposite directions.

The music picks up more as we follow each dancer to their personal favorite spots in Boston. Each dancer dances in their favorite spot as a stabilized shot moves with the music and with the dancer capturing their emotion, style, and technique.

Soon after, all of the dancers run into each other and they have a final freestyle session as a stabilized shot runs down the line of dancers and then moves out to show them all, each utilizing their own passion for dance and their love of Boston to drive their movements.

Potential Locations in the Video

Winter Street Amid the Crowd

Gazebo in the Common

Longwharf

Faneuil Hall

Silhouette in Colored Yoga Studio

Harvard Square

Where is my money going?

Your money is going towards the proper film equipment, dancers, and music producer to shoot a gorgeous and compelling video.

What's the point?

The point is that dancers are some of the most athletic, soulful, and remarkably talented people in this world and their recognition falls flat on a macro and micro level. 

Our goal is to get dancers from different studios, schools, backgrounds, and training regimens to find their favorite location in Boston and do what they love to do.

Our goal is to help dancers feel like they have material that they can show off to people. 

Our goal is to help dance become more popular and for dance films and cinematography to become far more common than they are.

Dancing is one of the most amazing things that humans are capable of. 

This video is about community, love, dance, unity, and Boston.

We promise to shoot a stunning, artistic, creative, and worthwhile piece spread across the beautiful city of Boston, MA.

Here is a list of our main goals:

  • Bring together the dance community
  • Have dancers earn money
  • Market all dancers in video
  • Seamlessly integrate all studios and college logos into video to market them
  • Create a visually stunning video
  • Create a video showcasing Boston’s rich sense of community
  • Showcase Boston’s many beautiful locations
What could this hold for the future?

If we can get this project funded and produce the vision that we have, it could very easily kickstart a dance video production company that could bring:
  • Heavily discounted professional grade group Dance Videos
  • Heavily discounted professional grade solo Dance Videos
  • Creating websites for solo / group dance companies
  • Bring together dance studios and colleges
  • Create "Community of Dancers - New York Edition" (and other cities)
  • Create "Community of Dancers" for other styles of dance
  • Create a true community of dancers among all institutions in Boston and eventually the country.
If this project gets funded, we will become a production company dedicated to bettering the lives of dancers and helping unknown people and organizations be know.

If this project gets funded, we will become a production company dedicated to bettering the lives of dancers and helping unknown people and organizations be know.

story:
Thank you for watching the above clip of one of several songs that will be perfomed in CULT MODEL!

From the creator of the international off-Broadway hit and recent LA Times Critics’ Choice “Confessions of a Mormon Boy” comes Steven Fales’ new 60-minute solo comedy CULT MODEL at the Hollywood Fringe Festival June 2015. CULT MODEL explores society’s harrowing cult-susceptibility and his own Obsessive Cult Disorder. With hilarious parables and parodies Fales takes on each of the many cults he’s let run his life as he takes each layer of clothing off!

Welcome, brothers and sisters! It takes a lot of money to launch a new show: festival fees, rent, costumes, publicists, promotion, publicity photos and the right team and all kinds of hidden extras that Mormon modesty won't allow to be listed but can be named in private!

Please take a look at the fabulous perks and help Mr. Fales take his thought-provoking, heartwarming, and heart-racing work to the next level in Los Angeles. Questions, requests, comments direct to fales.steven@gmail.com. THANK YOU for supporting "Mormon Boy" in the past and for your continued support. He's becoming much more than "Mormon Boy"!

“Fales knows how to sell it.”—New York Times; “A masterful storyteller and one hell of a writer.”—SF Examiner; “Fales is easily among the best, if not the best, solo performers in the business.”--David Clarke, BroadwayWorld.com

This world-premiere of CULT MODEL began as a stand-up show Fales called CULT! written while bored out his mind on days off during a ten-week run of “Confessions of a Mormon Boy” at the Coconut Grove Playhouse in Miami in 2003. Later that summer he performed it as a presentation at the 2003 Sunstone Symposium in Salt Lake City (the Mormon International Fringe Festival) and was performed as a benefit for the Utah AIDS Foundation at Wise Guys Comedy Club before being shelved. Fales found the hostility against him so great that he was afraid that he would be kept from seeing his children as the non-custodial parent if he continued to perform it. At the time, his ex-wife was raising the children very Latter-day Saint. He also had a few more cults to try before letting them all go. Now that the children are grown, the gloves are coming off. He’s fighting for all of us to kick our cult habits and learn to think and act for ourselves.

Fales quips, “There’s not a cult I haven’t tried . . . or wanted to. Today I’m cult free. I feel pretty naked. But that might not be such a bad thing. Still, I’m looking for a new cult. Are you it?"

Steven Fales is an award-winning veteran of the Edinburgh Fringe Festival, two New York International Fringe Festivals (Overall Excellence Award), the International Dublin Gay Theatre Festival (Oscar Wilde Award Nomination), Atlantic Fringe Festival (Overall Fringe Hit Award), Acts of Faith Festival and countless others.

This is the first of many 60-minute solo shows he is working on including “When All Else Fales” and “Simply Undetectable”. His 90-minute solo plays in “Mormon Boy Trilogy” include “Confessions of a Mormon Boy”, “Missionary Position” and “Prodigal Dad”. His cabaret acts include “Mormon American Princess” and “Mormon American Cowboy”. He has performed his work from Lincoln Center to Joe’s Pub; from Halifax to Houston; from London to Los Angeles. He received an Outer Critics’ Circle Award Nomination for the off-Broadway run of “Confessions of a Mormon Boy” at the SoHo Playhouse. Fales holds an MFA in acting from the University of Connecticut. Fales was an LDS missionary to Portugal and is an Eagle Scout. He holds extensive credits in film, television and theatre for the LDS Church as well as mainstream.

www.mormonboyonline.com

story:
Rhum and Clay Theatre Company are going back to Edinburgh Fringe! We’d love your support to take our latest show 64 SQUARES up there.

We are Rhum and Clay Theatre Company. Our work has been described as ramshackle and cinematic and is often put under the heading of ‘physical theatre’. Occasionally we do forward rolls but mostly we like to tell stories in mischievous and surprising ways. 64 SQUARES is our fourth Edinburgh Fringe show and our sixth show since the company was born, crawling out of the primordial soup and into life in 2011.

The company is run by Chris, Julian and Matt (under the watchful eye of producer Sarah).

Much like the Avengers* we have assembled a crack team of people for this project:

CAST

Julian Spooner

Matthew Wells

Róisín O’Mahony

with Fred McLaren on drums


Additional devising by

Charlotte Dubery

Sacha Plaige

Jess Mabel Jones


CREATIVE TEAM

Directed and Scripted by

Christopher Harrisson

Designer

Amelia Jane Hankin

Lighting Designer

Geoff Hense

Producer

Sarah Wilson

Publicity Design

Christopher Harrisson

Photography

Richard Davenport

*Not at all like the Avengers, unless the ability to make awesome Fringe theatre is a superpower**

**It isn’t.


64 SQUARES, 

7.30pm, Big Belly (Underbelly Cowgate) 

6th-30th August 2015 (not 18th)


64 SQUARES is a one man show performed by three actors and a drummer.

"You might have noticed there are four of me. Don't worry. You'll get used to it."

B wants to tell you about his life and the choices he's made. The problem? He's been split into four and can't remember what happened. A tale of madness, memory and chess with a live percussive score. Adapted from Stefan Zweig's 'The Royal Game'.

Photos of the show here: http://tiny.cc/bqfvxx


This going to Edinburgh malarkey is an expensive business, but for our company it’s a rather essential showcase for our work. As such, by pledging your support to Rhum and Clay, you’d be paying for lots of really useful things. This is the breakdown. Prepare for numbers in…

3...

2...

1...

Because we like you and you like us enough to support our project, it’s only right that we give something in return. We’re offering some lovely ‘perks’ ranging from a thank you to the opportunity to play chess against one of us (none of us are amazing at it, so there’s a good chance of a self-esteem boost for you included in the package)


Taking the show to the Fringe is hard (masochistic) work, but it’s where we’ve had so many of our breaks as a company. This will be our fourth show at the Fringe and the festival’s capacity to provoke and shock and seduce still takes us by surprise. It’s a place full of clowns and acrobats and a cappella groups (so many) and gritty urban monologues and taiko drummers and also critics and theatre programmers and festival promoters. It’s where the world can see our show and it’s essential for the long, long, long life of 64 SQUARES (we hope).

story:
Our Story

Talking Horse Productions’ vision comes to life as actors bring character-driven scripts to life in the heart of Missouri. The Talking Horse Theatre is an intimate black box setting where we focus on telling compelling stories rather than lavish sets and costumes. We are a community-supported, non-profit organization and our programs are made possible by generous donations of members of our community. Your donation will help us continue to improve the audience's experience and comfort.

What We Need & What You Get

Convertible Riser seating will provide "the best seat in the house" for everyone in the audience.  Not a whisper or a smirk will be missed once we are able to obtain these luxurious risers.  A small portion of the funds will go towards building an eagle's nest for our technical booth, freeing up additional space for seating.  

To add a little punch to your donation dollar, we are offering some great Talking Horse swag.  Check out the perks for each level of donation. 

The Impact

Professional-grade risers which can be re-configured will improve the versatility of the space and the vantage point of the audience. By eliminating the huge elevated stage and using the floor as our performance area, we can configure our seating in a great variety of ways.  This allows us to tailor our performance space to the best advantage for every show.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word about our campaign.  If you have ever performed in or attended a show in our venue, you understand the great impact these risers will make for us.  If you have not, please visit an upcoming performance, and be prepared to be blown away!

Share the campaign with friends on facebook and twitter; Talk it up with that wealthy uncle looking for worthy causes to support; Respond to compliments on your new Talking Horse Hoodie by directing friends to our Indiegogo link!

And that's all there is to it.  Happy Trails!

story:
About The Show

One day a man stepped in front of a train. One day a man discovered how genes control behaviour. One day I fell over wearing a giant bear suit. Life can change, our genes can change, our minds can change. Let’s talk.

Amy wonders if she’s mental. She wonders this a lot. She’s not sure if this is a politically correct thing to say out loud – but she has been told that talking definitely helps. When Amy was four, her father jumped in front of a train. The event bleeds into her present, leaving a trail of half memories about the man that was; a legacy of wonder.

One Under is a solo performance which uses treatment models and live gameplay to unlock how talking is a gamechanger, with the power to alter our genetic fabric and social norms.

Performed By Amy Fleming

Directed By Natalie Scott

The Vaults Festival: 17th – 21st February at 9.30pm

Venue: The Cage

Who We Are
The Lab Collective creates live performance which transcends traditional forms to produce visceral experiences for the audience. Treading the line between theatre, installation and live art, The Lab Collective empower the audience to collaborate in our performances. ​​​We have worked in a variety of traditional and non traditional performance spaces, exploring and playing across disciplines to ​generate an innovative theatrical experience.​​​​​​​​​​​​

We are now a Charity!  In 2013 we gained charitable status, so you can rest easy knowing that your donation will be used for exactly what it should be. 


A bit of background...
We began developing One Under in 2015 for Ming Beast's international Festival Point Blank Range and have since been invited to perform as part of The Vault Festival 2016.  my comes from a background in Molecular Medicine; before becoming a performer she trained at Trinity College Dublin and as always felt a strong connection between theatre and science.  One Under has been a great opportunity to explore how these disciplines can work together.

We'd like people to feel empowered to talk about mental health, and to lose the fear of encouraging others to talk too.  There's so many times it can feel awkward, or daunting to bring mental health to the table - we're afraid of causing offence or of using the wrong language, so often we clam up.  We hope that One Under will inspire people to see talking about their mental health in a fresh light and get people talking about what's important. 

Contributions to our campaign will make a massive difference to the depth of the project, and what we will be able to achieve in the future!

What We Need & What You Get
Part of the performance is a real live experiment and this is a really crucial part of the show!   Studies have shown that talking therapies can change 

-  We're looking to raise £750 to get Amy's brain scanned twice over the course of the rehearsal process - to see how talking therapy changes the fundamental structure of her brain. 

-  We also want to pay people a fair wage!  your donation will also go towards paying our movement director and technical team. 

The Impact
Every penny truly counts; One Under is at the beginning of it's journey; your contribution will help make a huge impact on the sustainability of the project as we look to touring the show in late 2016 and early 2017.  Our overall budget is £6500, and we have applied to funding for the Arts Council, however your contribution will enable to project to happen, even if we don't get the money we have applied for. 

We want the project to change the way people think about mental health and the stigma attached to it, and believe that theatre, as a public platform, has the potential to reach a broad audience and get people talking! 

The Lab Collective has been producing and making performance since 2008; the show and your donation is in the most capable of hands. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute - don't worry - come and see it instead! Book your tickets here:
http://www.vaultfestival.com/event/one-under/2016-02-17/

We also need everyone to spread the word, so feel free to share our Facebook event:
https://www.facebook.com/events/935280739895827/

Or send us a friendly tweet about the show:
@labcollective

-  We're looking to raise £750 to get Amy's brain scanned twice over the course of the rehearsal process - to see how talking therapy changes the fundamental structure of her brain. 
-  We also want to pay people a fair wage!  your donation will also go towards paying our movement director and technical team. The ImpactEvery penny truly counts; One Under is at the beginning of it's journey; your contribution will help make a huge impact on the sustainability of the project as we look to touring the show in late 2016 and early 2017.  Our overall budget is £6500, and we have applied to funding for the Arts Council, however your contribution will enable to project to happen, even if we don't get the money we have applied for. 

We want the project to change the way people think about mental health and the stigma attached to it, and believe that theatre, as a public platform, has the potential to reach a broad audience and get people talking! 
The Lab Collective has been producing and making performance since 2008; the show and your donation is in the most capable of hands. 

    Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute - don't worry - come and see it instead! Book your tickets here:http://www.vaultfestival.com/event/one-under/2016-02-17/
We also need everyone to spread the word, so feel free to share our Facebook event:https://www.facebook.com/events/935280739895827/
Or send us a friendly tweet about the show:@labcollective

story:
Update: Although the campaign has finished, donations can still be made via Paypal to robleather@ritzcinema.org and all perks will still be honoured for the amount donated (and please use the "Friends & Family" option to save on fees)


There are few buildings in Lincoln that can provoke more nostalgic affection than The Ritz Cinema on Lincoln’s High Street, both due to the appeal of the older and more charming generations of cinematic masterpieces that were shown at the venue, and the realisation it may well be Lincoln’s finest architectural example of a classic Art Deco building.

Many of Lincoln’s old cinemas were unremarkable and quickly declined into nothing but distant memories of buildings that once were, but The Ritz has remained and stood the test of time.

Laying dormant for well over a decade, the building housed the dust covered remains of the original cinema on the upper floors, and has slowly been brought back to life once again with the dreams and ambitions of The Ritz Team, working with the local community, to realise a future which brings this magnificent building back to life as a fully operation period cinematic experience, and community hub for Lincoln’s High Street once again.

We are now 4 years down the line, and the building has had all manner of renovations completed, thanks to a dedicated team of volunteers and help from local businesses (the gallery link at the top of the page has some videos from the early days which give an idea of how much of a state the building was in at the start of the project).

The foyer has been completely renovated, including new plumbing, wiring, new ceiling, re-plastering and decoration, and new flooring.

The auditorium has gone from bare brick, temporary seating, and projection on to a painted wall, to having hand-printed art-deco-style wallpaper, comfy multiplex-style cinema seating, and a proper projection screen.

The public areas of the building have been re-wired, re-plastered and re-decorated. Old toilets and plumbing have been removed. Rooms have been rearranged to create the new toilets, a memorabilia shop, and a "green room" for when we have guests at events.


Many of our "behind the scenes" areas, including the old projection room, have been cleared, re-plastered, re-wired, and re-decorated, ready to be used in the future.

Over the last 2 years or so, we have had many fund-raising screenings of classic films, as well as special events and high profile guest appearances and intimate "Q&A" sessions, and even live music, and the profit from these has enabled us to keep the renovation slowly moving forward. However, there is still a lot to be done, both in the public areas and the "behind the scenes" areas that most people will never see, so the renovation project is still very much ongoing. As we do not receive any income in the form of grants or help from any other public bodies, the only source of funds we currently have is the income from the cinema and our retail area. We are staffed by volunteers, so all the money we make goes straight back into the renovation and running of the building, We always strive to keep our screenings and events as cheap as possible so that we are accessible to the widest audience possible, however the downside of that is that we make very little profit to reinvest into the building from many of our screenings & events, and screenings with poor attendance can easily make a loss.


What We Need & What You Get

For the last 3 years we have been running our screenings from a 15 year old projector that is neither as bright as we would like, nor as high resolution as we would like (another reason for keeping our tickets cheap - we are fully aware that our projection and sound is not up to the level of a commercial cinema), and cannot play direct from a Blu-ray player or allow us to use a PS4 or XboxOne for gaming nights. We are well overdue for an upgrade, however projectors are very expensive so this is where you come in....... 

We are fully aware that raising the amount of money needed to get a new (or nearly new) projector with the specs we need is unattainable - most commercial full HD projectors of the size we need would cost us at least 20 to 30 thousand pounds. However, if we go for something a bit older from a specialist second-hand dealer, then we can get what we need for a fraction of the price.

After doing a bit of research, and shopping around on the internet, we think we've found a projector that suits our purposes, and should,depending on the supplier, cost us in the region of £4000 to £4200. As all donations are subject to fees both to Indiegogo and the payment provider, which come to around 8 to 10% of every donation, we have decided to set the goal of our fundraising campaign at £4500 (as it's a nice round number)

We have tried to come up with as wide a range of perks as possible to cover both a good range of donation amounts, as well as a range of cinema-related perks that will hopefully appeal to newcomers as well as our regulars. We've also included some corporate perks, so any small (or large) businesses out there that would like to contribute and get their business advertised on our big screen, there are some options for you as well.

We have gone for the flexible-funding approach so that even if we don't attain or target, we will still get to use your donations and you still get to use your perks. If this happens, then we will still be upgrading the projector, but we will have to set our sights a little lower. If, however, we manage to exceed our funding goal, then we have the possibility of going for a more expensive projector, and/or purchasing spare bulbs (most projectors at this level have multiple bulbs that costs £100's of pounds each) and cabling etc. If we manage to raise significantly more than our initial target, then we will look at the possibility of upgrading our cinema speakers to improve our sound quality. Whatever happens, will keep everyone updated on what we are intending to buy and where the additional funds will be going, if applicable.

The Impact

A newer, more powerful projector will enable us to show films (subject to the original source) in Full HD for the first time. It will also enable us to show films direct from Blu-Ray sources, as well allowing us to use PS4 and XBoxOne consoles for gaming parties for the first time.

The increase in both brightness and contrast levels will further increase the picture quality, bringing us that much closer to the levels of a mainstream cinema, and the newer technology will mean more flexibility with regards to what we can do and the facilities we can offer for private hiring and conferences. It should also as future-proof us for the foreseeable future, as the bulbs and spares are become increasingly difficult and/or expensive to obtain for our ageing current projector.

Raising the funds this way also means that we can continue to keep our ticket and hiring costs as low as possible rather than increasing them to generate additional funds, while still being able to upgrade our equipment - a win for us (we get new stuff, yay!), and a win for you (tickets stay cheap!)

Other Ways You Can Help

We fully appreciate that some people may not be able to spare any money to donate to our campaign, or that some people are not comfortable sending money over the internet. That doesn't mean you can't help us, however, so here are some of the other ways you can contribute to us achieving our goal (and for those of you that have donated, please feel free to help us out as well!):

  • Share this page - campaigns like this are only successful if people know about them. Share this page with your friends and contacts, and if you are that way inclined, keep sharing it!
  • Share our posts on Facebook/Twitter - if you are not already following us on Facebook and/or Twitter, use the links at the bottom of this page. Whenever you see a post about this campaign, share it and retweet it (and even if you don't see a new post, feel free to find an old one and share that!)
  • Talk about the campaign and/or the cinema to your friends and family
  • If you work for a local business that might be interested in one of the corporate perks as a way of getting some local advertising, share the campaign with them
Or, just check out our upcoming films and events, and buy some tickets on the link below (don't forget to bookmark it for easy access) - all money raised from ticket sales and food & drink sales goes straight back into the ongoing renovation and running of the cinema.

The Ritz Cinema & Theatre on Eventbrite

And finally, regardless of whether you have donated or not, or have helped raise awareness of our campaign, thank you for taking the time to visit this page and read this far down!

- The Ritz Cinema management and volunteer team

P.S. If you want to be added to our mailing list so you get a monthly email with what's new and what screenings we have for the coming month, please send an email to robleather@ritzcinema.org (we promise that your email will not be passed on to any 3rd parties). You will also receive a link to a Secret Perk not available through the regular website!

story:
Acknowledging that we live in a society where the people with less or no economic privilege never get to participate, watch, witness, savour sincere art forms due to the unavailability of the same-- we, a group of five women are shaping up an alternative dance theatre production which aims to speak against the rules, the norms that are put around our body, perception and behavior through a new language of performance. It aims to challenge the established norms of what is dance and what is not. The tickets will have no fixed price-- the audience gets to decide it, in that they would also engage directly with the art created.


Now, what do we mean by Urban Ritual? 

প্রাতঃকৃত্য 

/PraatohKrityo/

noun

1. Any work that is done early in the morning.
2. The act of taking dump in the morning. 

Getting up in the morning, brushing teeth, combing hair, taking dump, making love, eating, taking metro, working, going to sleep--this basic pattern of living life is the same no matter where we are, which skin color you have, which caste you belong to, which gender you perform, which class you fall under. All of us perform within this basic design. We as dancers/artists aim to find new movements emerging from the circle of repeated patterns that we encounter in our daily experiences, everyday actions, and belief.

Ritual is not only what emerges inside the circumference of a temple, mosque, synagogue, church but also the transcendence created in our simple lives through the gestures of everyday actions. Acts like walking into an elevator pressing the same button everyday to reach your office, or waiting in the same one hour traffic before reaching your university or a farmer cutting crop, rowing seed-- acts like these always run the risk and potential of being something else in which they will create a different movement, chaos, disturbance, art.  What if we start reading books while doing a headstand? what if we start walking backwards from our office to reach home? 
This temporal aspect of our repeated actions, behaviour, work, lifestyle push us to look for newer signs, codes, movements. It can be summed up in something Pina Bausch has said: "We forget where the movements come from. They are born from life. When you create a new work, the point of departure must be contemporary life -- not existing forms of dance."

Why is It Important to Create a New Language of Movement


If they see breasts and long hair coming, 
they call it woman, 
if beard and whiskers, 
they call it man: but, look, 
the self that hovers in between is neither man
nor woman O Ramanatha!

(Devara Dasimayiyya, a woman poet of the 'bhakti 'protest movement which originated in the 10th CAD)

Right from our childhood, patriarchy teaches us to move in a certain manner. Patriarchy encountered in the streets, at home, in tv commercials, films, schools, propagated by our political leaders. It designs the way our bodies interact with each other and to the world, at large.
Our aim as dancers is to break that  design, explore and discover a new language of bodily movements that will become a part of the dance theatre-- to create newer ways of moving and bodily gestures that breaks and disturbs the binary of gender itself. Binary inevitably gives birth to power relations. "Linga" is the word for Gender in Bangla and it means 'sign' and signs, as we know, keeps changing-- no amount of power can ever map the movement of signs.
When does a body become man and when does it become woman? 

Our Inspiration and What Keeps us Going

As dancers/artists, as individuals inhabiting urban spaces, as we reflect upon the urban rituals, we seek to provide a critique of it. 
As we observe, how the urban life, changing cityscapes, newly growing architecture shape our behaviour and gesture, we also explore how these give way to new movements – movements different from your learnt styles, codes of behaviour, movements which capture/express the everyday (the banal, the common sensical, also the unusual, and the collective unconscious) – movements which show new vocabulary, and thereby redefine what we call “dance”. 
Artists whose works have inspired us are Chandralekha, Teejan Bai, Rasoolan Bai, Pina Bausch, Martha Graham, Uday Shankar among others. 


Making it Available to the People

This dance theatre, taking cues from rituals that emerge out of the urban life experiences, try to dismantle the boxes that society tries to put us in. We are shaping up a piece of art that reflects its own politics through both its process and the final performance. We do not take government funds or corporate help as it goes against our pro-people, pro-azaadi politics and solely rely on crowdfunding, on people. 
Reason why we need your help. Gratitude and love. 

How You Can Participate

The hall rent has already been paid, thanks to our local supporters and comrades! However, we need money for the final performance which will include expensive lights, sound equipments, technicians, a whole set to be created by an artist, print tickets, posters, fliers and flexes for more reach, costumes for the performers. We literally do not have money for any of these above-mentioned equipment, without which the show can't happen. 

Here's the breakdown: 

  • Lights (tech rehearsal+final show) - 600$
  • Sound (tech rehearsal+final show) - 500$
  • Two tech rehearsal space rent - 160$
  • Set design - 200$
  • Floor Mat + Props - 370$
  • Costume - 120$
  • Two 5days Rehearsal Camps - 150$
  • Posters and Flyers - 50$
  • Other (including min. payment to performers for food, transport etc. ) - 150$
  • *Additional fund for future - 200$

*Additional funds will be used towards the costs incurred in the next show this year. 

The first show is on 21st February in Kolkata, India and the second one on 10th of March, 2016.
We need you to help us survive and create alternative art.

Special Note:

If you face problem donating through this IndieGogo campaign you can mail us at dancetheatre2016@gmail.com  OR transfer the donation amount to the following account:

Account no. 30077737372
State Bank of India
Name : Joyraj Bhattacharjee
IFSC SBIN 0004284
Branch : Ganges Garden

But do drop us a mail if you donate and we will include your name in the list of donators and update the amount received on our Facebook page. :)


We are humbled to know that you took interest in our campaign and thank you for coming forward to support us. Spread the word. Come for the show if in India, Calcutta. You can also follow our activities on Facebook and stay connected. Extreme gratitude and love for your support.

story:
About the play

Coming soon to the DC Capital Fringe Festival in July is a brand new original drama known as Cracked by Marcus Salley. 

Cracked was inspired by Marcus Salley's family after the death of his grandfather. The first part of a trilogy, Cracked looks at the early days of his grandparents relationship. Gale McDonald and, self-proclaimed One-Man Motorcyle Gang, Willie "Chick" Brown are complete opposites, but after a wonderful a night out on the town, the two young lovers are brought together are put a journey that threatens to show their family the pits of hell for generations to come. 

Audience reactions of its Virginia based premiere were very strong with many demanded that the sequel premiere the following summer! Audiences who saw the play were amazed by the quality of its writing and wanted to know what happened to these characters who they grew to love in just an hour after their tragic ending.

What We Need & What You Get

The cost of performing at Fringe can be steep for our cast members who are giving up their free time to participate in the festival on top of regular rehearsals. While the benefits are high, we are looking to help our actors out in any way we can by raising funds to take care of transportation on the metro or gas money (DC is an hour commute on a good day), food for those days when they will have to miss lunch or dinner, transportation of the set, advertising (our largest purchase), props and guaranteed payment for both cast and crew.

No matter how much money we receive, all donations will go to the production of the play. To your right, you will find a variety of different tokens of appreciation for donating!

The Impact

In today's society, there are few opportunities to tell a story as black theatre artists. Cracked is a play that not only showcases the talents of black artists of different ages, but also tells a truly American story that can be shared by ALL races. 

Your donations will help a young black playwright let his voice be heard and a story about what it means to protect your family be witnessed by a much larger audience than what the cast and crew have experienced. 

Help make the change we want to see within the entertainment world!

Risks & Challenges

The Rude Mechanicals are very small company that strives to put on multiple shows every year. The summer is our biggest season and the quality of our shows needs to reflect how far we have come. 

The DC audience can either love us or hate us. These donations will help us make the best show that we can and get it recognized at a much larger level.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot help financially, you can still help us out! Share this campaign with your friends on all social media! Make sure you use the hashtag #crazy4cracked so that we can hopefully trend a little bit.
story_txt:
About the play Coming soon to the DC Capital Fringe Festival in July is a brand new original drama known as Cracked by Marcus Salley. 
Cracked was inspired by Marcus Salley's family after the death of his grandfather. The first part of a trilogy, Cracked looks at the early days of his grandparents relationship. Gale McDonald and, self-proclaimed One-Man Motorcyle Gang, Willie "Chick" Brown are complete opposites, but after a wonderful a night out on the town, the two young lovers are brought together are put a journey that threatens to show their family the pits of hell for generations to come. 
Audience reactions of its Virginia based premiere were very strong with many demanded that the sequel premiere the following summer! Audiences who saw the play were amazed by the quality of its writing and wanted to know what happened to these characters who they grew to love in just an hour after their tragic ending.   What We Need & What You Get The cost of performing at Fringe can be steep for our cast members who are giving up their free time to participate in the festival on top of regular rehearsals. While the benefits are high, we are looking to help our actors out in any way we can by raising funds to take care of transportation on the metro or gas money (DC is an hour commute on a good day), food for those days when they will have to miss lunch or dinner, transportation of the set, advertising (our largest purchase), props and guaranteed payment for both cast and crew.
No matter how much money we receive, all donations will go to the production of the play. To your right, you will find a variety of different tokens of appreciation for donating!
    The Impact In today's society, there are few opportunities to tell a story as black theatre artists. Cracked is a play that not only showcases the talents of black artists of different ages, but also tells a truly American story that can be shared by ALL races. 
Your donations will help a young black playwright let his voice be heard and a story about what it means to protect your family be witnessed by a much larger audience than what the cast and crew have experienced. 
Help make the change we want to see within the entertainment world!

story:
History in the Making 

  My name is S. Christopher Boggs. I have been an actor/director/producer and writer within the Little Rock theatre community for a number of years. In late January of 2014, I came up with a crazy idea for a play and pitched it to my wife. She loved it and encouraged me to start fleshing the story out. Roughly a month later, "The Winning Numbers" (TWN) was finished. I reluctantly put the script down for a while, but then quickly picked it up again and began fine tuning it.  It has been my good fortune to be a member of Community Theatre of Little Rock (CTLR) and even more fortunate that TWN was considered for their 2014-15 season. 
 The weekend of April 24th-26th 2015, TWN will have its World Premiere performances at The Studio Theatre, where Community Theatre of Little Rock currently performs. A special VIP show will be held on April 23rd. I can not tell you how excited, nervous, elated and stressed out I have been over the past year and how excited, nervous, elated and stressed I am about the next four months (FOUR MONTHS - AHHHHH!!!). 
   The cast and crew of "The Winning Numbers", along with Community Theatre of Little Rock, are seeking support from donors like you. Donation will go to help offset the cost of building our set, purchasing costume pieces and props, handling publicity, etc., so that all of the revenue from the actual production can go directly to Community Theatre of Little Rock. CTLR will be celebrating its 60th season here in Central Arkansas. The revenue generated from this production will give an added boost to the quality of shows we plan for the 60th and beyond.

 If you have been involved in theatre on any level, you know that sets are used and reused again and again. The wear and tear on set flats, staircases, furniture, props, costumes, etc. can be very costly to the budget. So, new flats, among other necessary items, will help refresh the look and feel of future productions for years to come.   It is my hope, that the funds we raise here on IndieGoGo for this show will help provide CTLR with new flats, furniture and other needed essentials that they haven't had for a number of years. 

So your donations will help us two fold: We will be able to have flats, furniture, etc. for our World Premiere Production of "The Winning Numbers" and CTLR will have new equipment to use for many years to come. 


Synopsis of “The Winning Numbers”

  “The buzz around the offices of Dingle, Martin and Associates is ‘the state lottery is at an all time high.’ For employees like Emily and Max, winning the lottery would mean comfort and happiness. For Roberta, it would mean a better education for her twin sons. Louie would finally be able to buy that house he’s always wanted. Scott could really get ahead of the curve. And for Stacy and Brewster, it might even mean wedding bells. But when things don’t go as planned, and the employees start plotting against each other."


UPDATE: Nov 15, 2014:

  The Cast and Crew of "The Winning Numbers" met at cast member Bob Bidewell's house to have a preliminary read through of the script. This was a chance for everyone to meet and get to know each other. We laughed a lot and began delving into the script. We have a number of veteran actors/actresses in the cast as well as a few new folks. I asked each of them for their reaction to reading the script together as a cast. Here's what they had to say...

Jennifer Baltzley (Stacy) said "Feeling so honored to be cast with such amazing talent!  It's going to be a great show!  Can't wait!"

Bob Bidewell (Brewster) said " You people need to get to work!"

Chris Miller-Marshall (Max) said "I knew I needed to be a part of the show after a few pages and uncountable chuckles."

Danny Troillett (Louie) said "Well-written and fun. Anyone want to go in on some Lottery tickets?"

Jerry Woods (Alex) said "Where are my lines?"

Liz Turner (Emily) said "The characters are lovable and real. *sneeze*"

Kevin Crumpler (Randall) said "That will buy a lot of happiness!"

Terry Harrison (Scott) said  "The script was so much fun. My focus, of course, during the initial read through was on the overall arc of the story and how my character fit into that particular snippet of his life. The fact that I was able to find so many avenues to explore during the rehearsal process showed an innate depth to the writing."

Roben Sullivant (Roberta) said "I was simply thinking how awesome it was to be one of the 'chosen ones' to debut the show. It's well written and hilarious - AND, it's already a drinking game! 'Snort, snort, giggle!' I haven't laughed so hard in a long time!"

Tamara Boggs - Stage Manager said "My husband's brilliant!"

Here's what readers of the script had to say:

Drama Teacher and Actress Jane Balgavy said "Characters that are rich and real interact as we all do - and for one of them, a life changing piece of paper is all they need to change the game!"

Horror Fiction Writer Kat Yars said "The Winning Numbers will keep you laughing from the opening to the very twisted ending. Well developed characters and plot lines will keep you guessing what will happen next. A great play, I cannot wait to see on the stage."

Director and Actor Frank O. Butler said "It's an interesting look at greed, and how it can blind you of many things if you're not careful. It has characters from different walks of life with different motives as to why winning the lottery is important, even if it's a one-in-a-million longshot. I think audiences will definitely identify with at least one of these characters during the course of the show."

Film Maker and Actress Jess Carson said "It's a quirky, fun and engaging piece of writing that will be sure to keep the audience engaged and in giggle fits."

Film Maker Nick "CK" Helms said "With The Winning Numbers, Mr. Boggs has crafted an excellent tale of a seemingly typical office group who band together to try and win the lottery in order to get out of their mundane lives. You can't help but match the characters up with people that you may have worked with in the past and it just makes the story even more humorous. I would definitely recommend this to others in hopes that they will enjoy it as much as I did."

Playwright Betsy Kelso said "In a time of such great financial uncertainty for so many, Chris Boggs has tapped into some truly relevant and compelling themes with 'The Winning Numbers.'"

Drama Professor and Actor Tom McLeod said "...kept me guessing till the very end!"

Actress Lori Ann Freda said ""Boggs has created a lighthearted, funny play that is clever and entertaining! A whimsical story of office life and dreams of winning big!  This is definitely a crowd-pleaser!  Can't wait for the masses to enjoy this great piece!"

Personal friend Melissa Berkey said "Ha!!  All I know is that your script was absolutely fantastic.  It's not often, actually rare, for me to be so excited to read what happens next.  Nonetheless, can't put it down until the very end.  I get bored very easy, but your script was super, fantastic and look forward to another one.  LOVED IT!!!!!!!!!!  LOVED IT, LOVED IT, LOVED IT!!!!!!!!"


About Community Theatre of Little Rock

  "Founded in 1956, Community Theatre of Little Rock (CTLR) is Central Arkansas' oldest and finest theatre tradtion. CTLR is a nonprofit, volunteer organization striving to enlighten, educate and entertain our community.

  Since its inception, CTLR has performed in many venues in Little Rock, Arkansas. In the very early years, The Perish Hall at 9th and Louisiana, Trinity Parish Hall, Robinson Auditorium, a renovated feed store at 609 Center Street and The Medical Center Auditorium provided performance stages. In the 1960’s and 1970’s, National Investors Life Building, the Arkansas Arts Center, Student Union became our venues. The 1980’s found us performing again in the Arkansas Arts Center, UALR, the Excelsior Hotel, The Arkansas Repertory Theatre, Little Rock Garden Council and Hall High School. Capitol Keyboard Theatre became our home until the Arkansas School for the Blind offered us the use of Woolly Auditorium beginning our 2002-2003 season. The 2008-2009 season was an exciting time for CTLR, as we moved to The PUBLIC Theatre downtown. On July 1st, 2014, CLTR moved into The Studio Theatre on 7th Street.

  We continue to provide our community with live theatrical productions of the highest quality, as well as, providing opportunities for talented people of all ages to perform and participate in every phase of producing live theatre.”


How You Can Help:

  Please consider donating to our fund raising efforts. The perks for helping support our efforts are listed and we are looking forward  a great event.

  If you have questions, concerns, etc., please feel free to contact us at any time.


See you on the Boards,

S. Christopher Boggs
Author/Director of "The Winning Numbers"
President/Publicity Coordinator
Community Theatre of Little Rock
