story:
We need your help more than ever 
to make our dream of a greener art world a reality


We at Zata Omm Dance Projects are raising funds to support the world premiere of our upcoming new full-length contemporary dance production, vox:lumen, which will premiere on the 4th to the 7th of March 2015 as part of World Stage at Harbourfront Centre Theatre in Toronto, Canada.

Born of a multi-year creative partnership with ground-breaking researchers at York University and interactive designers Aesthetec Studio, vox:lumen is a formal experiment of the most absolute practicality: a show powered by the idea of sustainability. Lit from energy created by the dancers, the audience and renewable sources, vox:lumen confronts the audience with the most elemental metaphor for understanding – the light we make ourselves. Photo-voltaic solar panels and inverters are set up outside the theatre daytime all week to harvest energy for the production of vox:lumen. A special Energy Fair will be set up in the theatre lobby to educate and encourage public to contribute kinetic energy to vox:lumen’s energy needs . This energy fair will be an educational and interactive experience complementing the final production.

vox:lumen explores a future in which human labour produces energy, and the pleasure of movement integrates technology into the social sphere.  It is about responsibility, adaptability, resilience and sustainability. The 'Will' to move forward...

What Your Funds Will Help Us Achieve

At this stage, we are facing our biggest challenge, as we integrate renewable forms of energy capture. Now we need your help more than ever to make our dream of a greener art world a reality.

Your support for our project will strengthen an important campaign towards green energy and sustainability in the Canadian art world. In addition, you will fuel our Energy Fair equipment and hard-wares, as well as its transportation, and you will be helping us loco-mote through essential hours rehearsal time, artists fees, technical staff fees, rehearsal studio rental fees, and the application of the sustainable energy itself.

Who We Are: Zata Omm

Zata Omm is an acronym for ‘Zen And The Actualization Of Modern Movement’. The company is in a state of constant development with ongoing artistic research to explore the artistic climate, reflect contemporary culture and lead the emerging artistic trends. Zata Omm’s objective is to create multidisciplinary contemporary dance works using meaningful integration of dance, technology and other art forms on stage in order to provide an alternative way of seeing our world, which facilitates our exploration and understanding of the human condition. Zata Omm is a forward-thinking dance company with a unique and compelling aesthetic style and is renowned for its ability to humanize technical and technological elements in dance to create a deep impact and connection with audiences. Our creations are thought-provoking, and often express profound messages or revelations which are valuable contributions to our artistic discipline. Artistic Director William Yong has created more than 60 dance works which have been presented in major venues and festivals worldwide.

The Impact

This remarkable conceptual work of a self-fuelled dance show will impact upon the practices of other theatrical organizations, as well as general public's attention to sustainability and reflect our lives. Through the choices and the collaborative effort that constructs the work, we will challenge the dancers and our audiences to discover revelatory perspectives of the future of our planet. vox:lumen is intended to be exploratory, imaginative and visually innovative. It will challenge the aesthetic boundaries of the theatre by integrating the dance, auditory, technology and visual elements of the performance in novel ways. It will compel audiences to consider how we might leave a healthier city, nation and planet for our descendants.

The idea of a 'self-sustained-show' is one that leaps beyond being a mere production. The potential and afterlife of the piece is significant on both an artistic level and an environmental level. We are committed to sharing knowledge from this experience and on-going research by establishing an educational platform through which we will perform outreach among youth, artists and technologists. We will be starting an important dialogue among the arts, environmental and ecological sectors. We want to demonstrate this concept of sustainability for our future, in the theatrical community and beyond. A special Energy Fair will be set up onsite outside the theatre to educate and harvest energy for the production of vox:lumen. The energy fair will be an educational and interactive experience complementing the final production.

With its constructive, environmentally responsible, and innovative elements evokes the essential spirit that vox:lumen employs an innovative and creative approach to promoting adaptability and sustainability.

           

        


                                

Associated Events

·  vox:lumen World Premiere

(Produced with Harbourfront Centre’s World Stage in association with York University + Aesthetec Studio)

March 4 - 7, 2015 @ 8 pm, World Stage, Harbourfront Centre Theatre

231 Queens Quay West, Toronto, Canada

·  Zata Omm Energy Fair

March 4 - 7, 2015 in the Theatre lobby


For more information on Zata Omm’s vox:lumen, please visit:

http://www.harbourfrontcentre.com/worldstage/voxlumen/

http://www.ontario-sea.org/Page.asp?PageID=122&ContentID=4491

https://vimeo.com/109659107


Other Ways You Can Connect With Us

For more info: www.zataomm.org

Please also follow us on Youtube, Vimeo, Facebook and Twitter!

https://vimeo.com/zataomm

https://www.youtube.com/user/zataommdance

https://twitter.com/zataommdance

https://www.facebook.com/zataommdance

For more information about Zata Omm’s vox:lumen, please visit:

http://www.harbourfrontcentre.com/worldstage/voxlumen/

http://www.ontario-sea.org/Page.asp?PageID=122&ContentID=4491

https://vimeo.com/109659107


Collaborators and Creators

Conceived, choreographed and directed by William Yong.
Dancers: Michael Caldwell, Irvin Chow, Daniel McArthur, Brendan Wyatt and William Yong.
Dance Intern: Will Hamilton
Music Composer: Andrea Rocca
Set designer and technology consultant: Ian Garrett
Workshops technical director and technical consultant: James McKernan with assistants Jonnathan Leong-Sem and Adam Brewer.
Technology designer, props designer and research partner: Mark Argo (Aesthetec Studio) with associate designer Phil So
Lighting designer: Simon Rossiter
Director of strategy and development: Randy S'ad
Production technical director and stage manager: Kirsten Labonte
Dance and technology research strategist and video designer: Elysha Poirier
Creative process outside eye: Andrea Nann
Zata Omm company manager: Samantha Mehra
Energy Fair programme consultants: Ian Garrett, Stephen Trigg and John Wilson.
Documentary film maker: Timothy Garrett
*Images: David Hou

Zata Omm's vox:lumen is produced with Harbourfront Centre's World Stage and in association with York University (The School of Arts, Media, Performance and Design) and Aesthetec Studio. Early stage of technology research was funded by George Cedric Metcalf Charitable Foundation. vox:lumen is sponsored by Bullfrog Power and generously funded by Canada Council for the Arts, Ontario Arts Council, Toronto Arts Council, Harbourfront Centre and TD Friends of the Environment Foundation. Solar Energy devices are sponsored by Better Current and The Living City Campus at Kortright Centre for Conservation. Light-emitting diode (LED) stage lighting is sponsored and costumed made by A.C. Lighting Inc. Energy fair displays sponsored by Asethetec Studio, The Living City Campus at Kortright and Tune Your Ride.

and planet for our descendants.

leaps beyond being a mere production. The potential and afterlife of the piece
is significant on both an artistic level and an environmental level. We are
committed to sharing knowledge from this experience and on-going research by
establishing an educational platform through which we will perform outreach
among youth, artists and technologists. We will be starting an important
dialogue among the arts, environmental and ecological sectors. We want to
demonstrate this concept of sustainability for our future, in the theatrical
community and beyond. A special Energy Fair will be set up onsite outside the
theatre to educate and harvest energy for the production of vox:lumen. The energy fair will be an educational and interactive
experience complementing the final production.
With its constructive, environmentally
responsible, and innovative elements evokes the essential spirit that vox:lumen employs an innovative and
creative approach to promoting adaptability and sustainability.

            
         

                                

Associated Events
· 
vox:lumen World Premiere

(Produced with Harbourfront Centre’s World Stage
in association with York University + Aesthetec Studio)
March 4 - 7, 2015 @ 8 pm, World Stage,
Harbourfront Centre Theatre
231 Queens Quay West, Toronto, Canada
· 
Zata Omm Energy Fair
March 4 - 7, 2015 in the Theatre lobby

Collaborators and Creators
Conceived, choreographed and directed by William Yong.Dancers: Michael Caldwell, Irvin Chow, Daniel McArthur, Brendan Wyatt and William Yong.Dance Intern: Will HamiltonMusic Composer: Andrea RoccaSet designer and technology consultant: Ian GarrettWorkshops technical director and technical consultant: James McKernan with assistants Jonnathan Leong-Sem and Adam Brewer.Technology designer, props designer and research partner: Mark Argo (Aesthetec Studio) with associate designer Phil SoLighting designer: Simon RossiterDirector of strategy and development: Randy S'adProduction technical director and stage manager: Kirsten LabonteDance and technology research strategist and video designer: Elysha PoirierCreative process outside eye: Andrea NannZata Omm company manager: Samantha MehraEnergy Fair programme consultants: Ian Garrett, Stephen Trigg and John Wilson.Documentary film maker: Timothy Garrett*Images: David Hou
Zata Omm's vox:lumen is produced with Harbourfront Centre's World Stage and in association with York University (The School of Arts, Media, Performance and Design) and Aesthetec Studio. Early stage of technology research was funded by George Cedric Metcalf Charitable Foundation. vox:lumen is sponsored by Bullfrog Power and generously funded by Canada Council for the Arts, Ontario Arts Council, Toronto Arts Council, Harbourfront Centre and TD Friends of the Environment Foundation. Solar Energy devices are sponsored by Better Current and The Living City Campus at Kortright Centre for Conservation. Light-emitting diode (LED) stage lighting is sponsored and costumed made by A.C. Lighting Inc. Energy fair displays sponsored by Asethetec Studio, The Living City Campus at Kortright and Tune Your Ride.

story:
Hi, my name is Heulwen and I am raising money for The Imperfect Pearl show to tour in England during May and June this year, and to dates in the autumn in London.  I am executive producer of the show, along with musician Mark Latimer.  You may know Mark as a classical and jazz pianist, but who has recently been suffering from the terrible hand disease dupuytren's contracture, which is slowly and nastily turning his hands into claws.  We wanted to develop a project which Mark could do with his hands.  We discovered this marvellous composer called Domenico Zipoli, who was born in the 17th century in Prato near Florence, who left a settled life to live in the Jesuit Missions of Paraguay.  Then he disappered from the record, but his music was found again mysteriously in a Bolivian Church toilet in 1972. There was relatively little known of his life, but with help from a number of very generous people in Paraguay, Italy and Birmingham, we managed to piece together and breath life into his remarkable story, and produce a new type of action piece, part play, part opera, part concert, with our wonderful but bigou team of countertenor/actor/writer William Towers, soprano Eloise Irving, opera director Emma Rivlin, and a great string trio of Miles Golding, Charlotte Fairbairn and Sophie Gledhill. 
When we did a few pilot performances of The Imperfect Pearl in 2013, we were stunned that the production made people cry.  His is such a lovely story we wanted to tour in 2015 and share it. We need to raise £10,000 to get it to rural venues, where they often don't get this type of production.  Please help us in either donating, or passing on the link to your friends who may be interested in history and Baroque music, though all the family can enjoy our show!  THANK YOU!!

story:
Shakespeare Carolina  Shakespeare Carolina is an award winning ensemble of professional theatre artists and musicians devoted to reimagining the classical canon. Since 1997, Shakespeare Carolina has brought the classics to life in Rock Hill, Charlotte and the surrounding areas with vibrant re-imaginings of classic works, and incredible stagings of contemporary works styled after the works of classical playwrights. 

From Hamlet to Macbeth, Twelfth Night to Richard III, Shakespeare Carolina has never turned away from challenging work. Thanks to our partnership with Winthrop University, the company has stepped up production quality in recent years, culminating this year with Artistic Director Chris O'Neill receiving a Regional Artist Grant from the Arts & Science Council of Mecklenburg County for a new Macbook Pro. 
With this new computer, ShakesCar can step our production up to the next level, but we need your help. QLab Pro is the industry standard for audio and video control programs. This software will allow us to do complex projection and audio syncing and interfacing that we can only dream about now. With your help, we can continue bringing the words of Shakespeare, Moliere, Wilde and other classic artists into the modern world, making theatre relevant for today's students and audiences. 
Please help support Shakespeare Carolina in our quest for better tech and higher production values. Any funds over and above the amount needed for the QLab Pro will go toward the purchase of other lighting, sound, costume and scenic elements. We want to keep raising the bar and showing the Charlotte region what it means to be "bardcore." Give us a hand, join the party, you might find something you've been missing. 
Also, as an added perk, any funds received over and beyond what we need for QLab, will be used to start a theatre scholarship at Winthrop University!

story:
Help to launch The Zoas: I Have Seen the Future, the first performance of the newest showcase for Portland's finest purveyors of music, comedy, theatre, poetry, and television.

The Show:
The Zoas, the brainchild of Portland based professional actor and musician, Matthew Faranda, hopes to bring together many of Portland's most noted and award winning musicians, poets, storytellers, comics, actors and technicians to create a night of theater unlike anything ever seen in this city. Original sketch comedy and stories written by Matthew in the irreverent and absurdist tradition of Ernie Kovacs, The Muppet show, and The State, is paired with diverse musical styles ranging from early jazz to modern rock performed by a live nine piece band led by internationally known jazz trumpeter, Paul Mazzio.  The full cast list for our first show can be found on our website.

Each show will be completely original; showcasing new works of comedy, poetry, storytelling, and music.  With each performance we hope to grow the scope of The Zoas by adding multiple dates, full scale production numbers, local celebrities, and commissioning new musical pieces. To bring this caliber of talent together into one incredible show is no insignificant investment which is why we're looking to raise $20,000 to defray our startup costs and fund our future performances.   


The Podcast:
As The Zoas continues to grow we hope to add a weekly live podcast broadcast from Mazza's Bistro in North East Portland incorporating local luminaries of poetry, philosophy, drama and art. We will also feature interviews with and live performances by cast members starring on our upcoming theatrical productions.  Each podcast will conclude with a lively and comedic trivia match between the two sets of guests.  We will be seeking sponsorships for the podcast to help offset the cost of our theatrical endeavors.

Charity Partnership:
The Zoas takes very seriously its obligation to both the arts and our community. As such, ten percent of our gross proceeds on this first show will be going to CHAP, the Children's Healing Art Project who do invaluable work bringing art therapy to critically ill, chronically ill, and disabled children and their loved ones. CHAP brings the healing power of art to children in crisis through a mobile team of teaching artists working in partnership with hospitals, community organizations, and schools. At CHAP, children are known for their creativity and ingenuity—not by their disease, diagnosis or disability. They are doing incredibly important work right here in our community; bringing joy and comfort to very deserving children.

Take time to find out more about them.

In addition to the donation of a portion of our proceeds, we will also be auctioning off the opportunity to select a song for inclusion on our next performance! All money raised will go directly to CHAP.  The auction will go live at the start of the performance with live updates throughout the show!  You have our word, if you want to hear a song by anyone from Puccini to Pantera, NWA to Crystal Gayle, The Sex Pistols to Air Supply: name the tune, win the auction, and it will be on the next show!  Don't worry; our fantastically talented arrangers can make it happen! It's a ton of fun while helping a great cause! What song would you pick?

Each performance we will be partnering with a different local charity ten percent of our proceeds going directly back into our community.  Check out our website for more information.

Undo the spell that money has cast on your mind. Its loss will not threaten your survival on this planet.

Now give it to us.

Other Ways You Can Help:
If you can donate, then we thank you! Any donation, no matter how small, will help. But even if you can't, you can still make a difference!

Share!

Link people to the campaign, the website and our Facebook pages. You can use the IndieGoGo share tools below to make this easier. Tweet your support; use the hashtag #TheZoasPDX. Follow @the_zoas. Stop strangers in the street, grab them by the face, and explain the shining brilliance of this project with a wild unblinking stare. They will thank you for it.

Preach!


About M. R. Faranda:


Matthew Faranda was born in Reading, PA and grew up in the Philadelphia area. Raised in a music loving family, he began playing the guitar at the age of 9 and started formal lessons at the age of 12.  He began acting professionally at the age of 14 and has never looked back.  He graduated from Ithaca College with degrees in Musicology and European history and later studied medieval music history at Oxford University with Margaret Bent. Matthew moved to the Portland area in 2013 and has been seen in productions with Broadway Rose and Staged! theaters.  The Zoas is his first self-produced endeavor in the city.

story:
Since 1999, Hollywood Hits Theater has been an alternative to the sprawling megaplex movie experience.  With its easy parking, friendly staff, and lower prices, Hollywood Hits has a loyal customer base that appreciates what we can offer over other local theaters.

However, there has been one comment from our customers above all others:

“When are you getting new seats?”

New seats have been the #1 request from our customers, practically since we opened.  And now, we’re doing something about it.

Hollywood Hits is finalizing the contract with Seating Concepts to provide NEW SEATING for all of its theaters, and now you can help!

With your donation, we can finally fulfill our customers’ biggest re quest.

THE SEATS

The seats come from Seating Concepts, Inc., a leading designer and manufacturer of movie theater seating.  We have decided to go with a style that we feel is both comfortable and durable.  The seats are a combination of cloth and vinyl, which will make them a vast upgrade over our current seating, as well as easy to clean and maintain.

In addition to the new chairs, we will be redesigning our seating layout in the theaters to allow for easier access.  No more will you be forced to stand when someone wants to get by.

These seats represent a $250,000 investment, and are the first stage in a multistep renovation, which will eventually include the redesigning and rebranding of the theater. 

WHEN ARE THEY BEING INSTALLED?

Our current goal is to install the seats through the month of September, with all the theaters fully converted to the new seating by October.  We are currently finalizing the new seating layout, as well as the permitting required for such a renovation.

WHAT WILL YOUR MONEY BE FOR

The seats have already been ordered.  However, the cost of installing them, as well as updating the décor in the theater and hallways, is still not covered.  Hitting our goal of $50,000 will allow us to finalize the installation of our new seats, with stretch goals to cover the installation of new carpeting and lighting.

We hope that you see this investment as we see it - an investment not just in some new chairs, but in the future of a small, independent theater.  We, the management team of Hollywood Hits, are committed to this theater for the long term, and hopefully, with your help, we will be here for many years to come.

WHO WE ARE

Opening in 1999, Hollywood Hits has stood as an alternative to the multiplex filmgoing experience.  With easy parking, friendly staff, and lower prices, Hollywood Hits is the best place to see a movie on the North Shore.

The theater was sold in 2014 to Scott Przybycien, who has been with the company since the day it opened.  Scott and his investors have already begun the renovation of the theater.  The projectors have been changed to digital equipment, and the sound has been upgraded in all of our theaters.  These changes were necessary to be completed first, as the entire film industry has transitioned to digital picture and sound.  Now that it has been completed, we can move on to improving the rest of the theater experience for our customers.

story: In July of 2014, The Great Plains Theatre of Abilene, Kansas, a not-for-profit, 501c3 professional theatre burned to the ground. As if this weren't devastating enough, the fire also wiped out the space for our robust youth theatre programming. The programming (known as the Plain Great Players) is a vital part of our community, and the kids themselves have been very active in keeping the programs going, despite no permanent home or the basic supplies needed for productions, workshops, and day-to-day operations. The way these kids have rallied and continue to invest in these programs is inspiring and underlines its importance. Please help us raise the money to build reusable scenery, buy art supplies, invest in some staff to help run these programs, and to keep the heart of our community beating.

story:
“As Time Goes By… In a Galaxy Far, Far Away” is the ultimate mashup, combining the amazingly classic worlds of CASABLANCA and STAR WARS!  AS TIME GOES BY...tells the story of jaded, cynical nightclub owner Rex Starbane who must choose between his personal feelings and what’s best for the galaxy when he unexpectedly comes face to face with the woman who broke his heart years earlier. Throw in some Stormtroopers, some travel visas, an alien nightclub jazz singer, and some smugglers, and you have one of the most entertaining theatrical events in a long time!

”As Time Goes By…. In a Galaxy Far, Far Away” has all of the aliens, intrigue, and usual suspects you’d expect to find in the galaxy’s most wretched hive of scum and villainy. Of all the plays in all the theaters in all the galaxy, this is the one you’ll want to walk into.

Best Director* winner Gary Adamsen (RETURN TO THE FORBIDDEN PLANET, LITTLE SHOP OF HORRORS, JESUS CHRIST SUPERSTAR, CAT ON A HOT TIN ROOF, KEEPING FAITH, HARVEY) returns to  the NYC stage to smash together his two favourite worlds - sci fi and film noir! Written and produced by Christian Clarke. Costume design by Christian Clarke. Sound design by Albona Bogdanovic. Stage Managed by Emma Roup.

Funds raised are intended for production costs of staging, including costumes, sets, rehearsal space rental, and storage space for our off-Broadway production of "As Time Goes By... in a galaxy far, far away"  in early 2016.


*PANSA Award - Little Shop of Horrors, Jesus Christ Superstar

story:
Short Summary

We were  recently selected from an audition to represent the United Kingdom at the World Championship of Performing Arts (WCOPA) in Hollywood, California in 2015. WCOPA is an Olympics style event for performers from all over the world where participants can compete for medals, scholarships and the chance to work with Hollywood directors and other professionals. 

The Urban Warriors would like to represent the UK at the Official WCOPA event in Los Angeles because it would be lovely to represent the UK in a very under rated sport, which although incredibly difficult to do and requiring dedication with training does not have many facilities in which to train at a professional level.  We are trying to raise awareness of the performance aspect, as well as the need for dedicated space for Wushu athletes to train. Indeed we would love to see Wushu recognized as an Olympic sport in the future along with Olympic quality training facilities.

Performance Wushu is very exciting to watch although it does not have much coverage outside of China.  We are hoping to change that through entering and performing at competitions and events worldwide.

And finally as a team we love to perform for audiences, and want to inspire more children and youth , to stay off of the streets and leap into the exiting world of Kung Fu,  it really can change your life….

With your help we will be able to attend the event and represent the UK in the Variety category. We will have the chance to earn a scholarship at some of the most prestigious acting schools in America as well as have the chance to work with and possibly be represented by people in Hollywood. 

What We Need & What You Get

We are creating a campaign in search of funding to allow us to compete at the WCOPA event. We hope to raise £3000 over the next 60 days to help cover:

-Entry fees

-Uniform

-Registration

-Accomodation

If you are a corporate sponsor making a donation you will be listed as a sponsor in the Contestant Directory book published by the WCOPA in America. Your company will also have your logo printed on the national uniform which will be worn throughout the competition and at the National Opening Ceremonies.

We can:

Promote sponsors on our website,

Through Social media,

WCOPA webpage for sponsor promotion

Promote sponsors on all Urban Warrior team wear, and Team UK Competition wear

Mention our sponsors in newspaper articles here or internationally that we are featured in.

Promote sponsors at any other competitions or events that we attend for twelve months after sponsorship is awarded.

Sponsors also have the opportunity to gain new business from clients abroad.

 The Impact

Having the chance to perform at the most prestigious performing arts event in America will be a dream come true and will inspire others to pursue their dreams. The opportunity to showcase our set of skills on one of the grandest stages of all opens opportunities that have never been there before. This could possibly lead to further chances to establish a worldwide name as well as help our team be recognised as being some of the finest performers in the world. We really want to promote Chinese Martial Arts and its entertainment value both here in the UK and internationally.

Other Ways You Can Help

Absolutely anything you can donate would be a massive step closer to achieving our  goal. Please spread the word to people who you think may be able to help.Thank you for taking the time out to visit and for helping us achieve a Team UK place at this event.


And Finally :

  • Help us to get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Share our campaign with your friends on Facebook, Twitter, Snap Chat and other social media
  • Remember to  use the Indiegogo share tools!
Thank You
story_txt:
Short Summary 


We were  recently selected from an audition to represent the United Kingdom at the World Championship of Performing Arts (WCOPA) in Hollywood, California in 2015. WCOPA is an Olympics style event for performers from all over the world where participants can compete for medals, scholarships and the chance to work with Hollywood directors and other professionals. 


The Urban
Warriors would like to represent the UK at the Official WCOPA event in Los
Angeles because it would be lovely to represent the UK in a very under rated
sport, which although incredibly difficult to do and requiring dedication with
training does not have many facilities in which to train at a professional
level.  We are trying to raise awareness
of the performance aspect, as well as the need for dedicated space for Wushu
athletes to train. Indeed we would love to see Wushu recognized as an Olympic sport
in the future along with Olympic quality training facilities.
Performance Wushu
is very exciting to watch although it does not have much coverage outside of
China.  We are hoping to change that
through entering and performing at competitions and events worldwide. 
And finally as a
team we love to perform for audiences, and want to inspire more children and
youth , to stay off of the streets and leap into the exiting world of Kung
Fu,  it really can change your life….
With your help we will be able to attend the event and represent the UK in the Variety category. We will have the chance to earn a scholarship at some of the most prestigious acting schools in America as well as have the chance to work with and possibly be represented by people in Hollywood. 

What We Need & What You Get
We are creating a campaign in search of funding to allow us to compete at the WCOPA event. We hope to raise £3000 over the next 60 days to help cover:
-Entry fees
-Uniform
-Registration
-Accomodation
If you are a corporate sponsor making a donation you will be listed as a sponsor in the Contestant Directory book published by the WCOPA in America. Your company will also have your logo printed on the national uniform which will be worn throughout the competition and at the National Opening Ceremonies.

We can: 
Promote sponsors on
our website, 
Through Social media, 
WCOPA webpage for
sponsor promotion
Promote sponsors on
all Urban Warrior team wear, and Team UK Competition wear 
Mention our
sponsors in newspaper articles here or internationally that we are featured in.
Promote sponsors at
any other competitions or events that we attend for twelve months after
sponsorship is awarded.
Sponsors also have the opportunity to gain new business from clients abroad.
 The Impact

Having the chance to perform at the most prestigious performing arts event in America will be a dream come true and will inspire others to pursue their dreams. The opportunity to showcase our set of skills on one of the grandest stages of all opens opportunities that have never been there before. This could possibly lead to further chances to establish a worldwide name as well as help our team be recognised as being some of the finest performers in the world. We really want to promote Chinese Martial Arts and its entertainment value both here in the UK and internationally.
Other Ways You Can Help
Absolutely anything you can donate would be a massive step closer to achieving our  goal. Please spread the word to people who you think may be able to help.Thank you for taking the time out to visit and for helping us achieve a Team UK place at this event.

   

    And Finally : 
Help us to get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
Share our campaign with your friends on Facebook, Twitter, Snap Chat and other social media Remember to  use the Indiegogo share tools! 
Thank You

story:
What is the Common Room: Heroes vs. Villains?:

Rhapsody Collective, now in its third cycle, is challenging our artists in a way we’ve never explored before! As we do each cycle, we give our teams a theme to create upon. This cycle, we’ve not only given them a theme, we’ve added a subtheme! In cycle 3, we’re exploring The Common Room: Heroes vs. Villains! We will be presenting six brand new plays that all take place on the same set that also capture the essence of the age-old battle, heroes vs. villains!

One of the great challenges is how we can present six potentially very different stylistic plays that all use the same exact room. The COMMON ROOM that has been chosen as our location is the common room of a college dorm. The personalities and situations that occur in this very public yet private place is an amazing location to explore the heroes vs. villains idea. Who are these heroes and villains that inhabit this college?

Why we need YOUR help:

In order to bring these six plays to life, we need your help. This April, we will present our six teams’ plays in true workshop style at Alchemical Theatre Laboratory! Our goal is to charge a suggested donation as admission so you have the opportunity to see all six presentations and not feel as if you need to pick and choose.

This cycle, since we have a more “realistic” theme, we need to create the space for these plays to live in. Part of our budget will be devoted to create an iconic common room. We hope we can fill our space with items including a couch, a coffee table, end tables, a study table, chairs, lamps, and a community board that each team will be contributing an item to.

Where the funds are going:

Our ultimate goal is $5500 and here is how it will breakdown:

Rent our space at Alchemical Theatre Laboratory for tech and performances - $2500

Rent rehearsal spaces for all six teams - $1200

Scenic Elements - $1000

Print Programs and Promotional Materials - $200

Other Production Needs- $600

What is Rhapsody Collective?:

Rhapsody Collective is a group of young theater artists dedicated to creating new works from the ground up. Rhapsody Collective strives to foster new and innovative ideas in a safe environment of peers. The goal is to create, not produce. Over the course of a cycle, the ensemble of actors, directors, playwrights, and dramaturgs are randomly broken up into teams to create a brand new piece. The challenge for each team is “freedom within restrictions.” Each cycle has a theme each piece must incorporate. Additionally, the roles created must be written specifically for the actors on their team. At the end of the cycle, each play will be presented in one harmonious rhapsody.

If we exceed our goal (which would be awesome!), those funds will go to future Rhapsody Collective projects including an abridged Summer cycle, Playground Reads, and the start of Cycle 4 in the fall of 2015!

Who is Rhapsody Collective Cycle 3?:

Samantha Algieri (Actor), Andi Alhadeff (Playwright), Cria Ama (Actor) Courtney Beam (Dramaturg), Michael Bradley (Playwright), Nick Browne (Director), Christina Cervenka (Actor), Zachary Clarence (Actor), Brian Collins (Actor), Jenna Conner (Actor), Felicia Cooper (Actor), Petra Denison (Actor), Julia Devine (Actor), John Donchak (Actor), Kevin Donohue (Actor), Evelyn Dumont (Actor), Gillian Durkee (Playwright), Emily Feinstein (Director), JD Frost (Director), Christo Grabowski (Actor), Matthew Hansen (Actor), Ashley Hevey (Actor),  George Hider (Playwright), Kelly Hubbell (Actor), Colleen Hughes (Director), Molly Jones (Actor), Jo’Lisa Jones (Actor), Ariel Judson (Actor), James Tyler Kirk (Actor), Brian Knoebel (Playwright), Rebecca Knowles (Actor), Preston Maguire (Actor), Andrew Massey (Dramaturg), Jesse McCaig (Actor) Mary Elizabeth McDonnell (Actor), Matthew Menendez (Actor), Sean Patrick Monahan (Playwright), Sophie Moshofsky (Actor), Anthony Ritosa (Actor), Sasha Rivera (Playwright), Alexis Robbins (Actor), Sarah Robotham (Actor), Julia Schonberg (Actor) Lindsey Sherman (Director), Jonathan Taylor (Director), Julia Yarwood (Actor)

Artistic Associates- Julia Warner and Madeline Hickman

For more on Rhapsody Collective, please visit rhapsodycollective.com and like us at facebook.com/rhapsodycollective

story:
The Lift: Love. Desire. Escalation


  • Hi I'm Pooja Prema, director of Rogue Angel Theatre and our 4th season's production "The Lift"-a full-length multi-media ritual/dance play that takes place in an elevator with an intimate audience of 20 at a time.  It features an ensemble of 6 local professional actors, an upright bassist, a saw player, and a piano, as well a music score from Brooklyn-based band ‘Half Waif’,  original film montages, and a little bit of burlesque & drag thrown in for good measure!  We'll have 2 shows per night from June 18-21  &  25-28, at 6 & 9pm (for a total audience of around 320 over 8 nights) .  The Lift is a dance-play exploring the nuances of relationship among human beings, ultimately embracing our universal and complex- and sometimes embarrassing- attempts to love and be loved.  To see more go to rogueangeltheatre.com/thelift


 Who We Are

  •  We are a shape-shifting company of actors, dancers & musicians              (usually all 3 in one).  We're committed to creating multi-sensory theatrical experiences that cross the fourth wall and invite the possibility of personal and collective transformation on all levels.  Our last 3 seasons have added liminality, color, youthfulness, and cutting-edge craft to the Berkshires’ theatre scene, involving over 100 local people, and an overall estimated audience of 800.
  • The Lift ensemble: Meg Agnew, Aaron Brandes, Maziy Broderick Scarpa, Jenny Cavanaugh, Mark Kelso, & Julius Reese
  • Musicians: Maya Mortman (bass) & Meghan Orbek (saw), and Ananda Plunkett (keyboard) & Zubin Hensler (trumpet)
  • The Lift Production Crew: Pooja Prema (director),  Hector Riviera (stage manager), Jaramy Moran (lighting), Elizabeth Orenstein (PR)
  • Artists: Sergio Rico (film), Lisa Vollmer (photography), Michael Vincent Bushy (printmaker) 


New Ritual Theatre

  • Rogue Angel’s work is a “new” genre we call Ritual Theatre that merges the magic of old-world pre-industrial performance traditions with a very modern aesthetic, inquiry, and multi-disciplinary approach. All of our performances are explorations of the cycles of love & loss that make us human. They are shaped by the specific place (site) in which they are created, (in this case an industrial elevator on 3 floors of a building,) and devised using the unique talents and life-stories of each production’s ensemble members, to create an experience that is as personal as it is universal, and sacred as it is profane.  Our goal is to remember for ourselves, and then tempt you into a world of beauty & uncertainty  where we remember what it means to be truly alive & fully human.
  • We love doing what we do!  And we need your fuel to make it happen.  Invest in the NEW culture of local live arts by Supporting us in creating one of the most daring, outrageous & powerful theatrical experiences, right here in the Berkshires. 



What We Need & What You Get

  • Your support goes a long way to helping us pull off this feat!-logistically and theatrically.  All donations are tax-deductable . We need $15,000 to make "The Lift" happen.  This money goes to 4 main areas: 1) Production expenses (production staff stipends, indiegogo expenses campaign & fundraising expenses, insurance and other materials costs including props.)  2) Stipends for the Cast & Crew so everyone gets paid something for all their time, energy and driving. 3) Publicity- printing.  4) Documentation- filming andphotographing the show itself.

  • Our PERKS are pretty amazing.  For the first time ever we have Rogue Angel T-shirts.  They have distressed vintage angel wings on the back that will make you look tough, sassy & classy.  Designed by Moho Designs & silk-screened by hand by us here in the Berkshires.  Additional perks include gorgeous postcards of "The Lift" photos by Lisa Vollmer, tickets to the show of course starting at $100, tickets to the not-to-be-missed-if-you-live-100-miles-of-here "Rogue Angel Gala: A Naughty Kind of Heaven" on May 1st or "All About Love": our closing party- on May 17th at the $250 level. From $500 and up, you get to be up close & personal with me & the company in various ways, and from $1000 and up you get to Pick Your Own Adventure!


Why Support Rogue Angel Theatre?


RA broadens the scope of what theatre & dance means in the Berkshires, adding youthfulness, color, cutting-edge craft and vibrancy to the performing art scene.


• RA is the Only company in the Berkshires dedicated to site-specific devised collaborative work.

• RA is spearheading a new genre called "Ritual Theatre".

• RA is one of 4 theatre companies in the Berkshires created and run by a woman under the age of 35, and the only theatre company run by a woman of color.

• RA targets a diverse age-range of audiences ages 20- 60, with a focus on those age 20-40 who are particularly estranged from live theatre.

• RA works at a grassroots level, cultivating latent talent in local people. To date we have worked with 100+ local people, age 3 to 89, mostly non-professionals.

• RA strives to keep ticket prices affordable- between $15-25 per performance, and we never turn anyone away for lack of funds.

You've helped make our last 3 seasons a success- help us continue our awesome track record.  Isis-Chernobyl in 2012 and the groundbreaking Rites of Passage in 2013 were both crowdfunded.  Can we do this in 2015 again?  Yes! 


Taking the Risk

The Lift is an experiment in theatre, in dance, and its a convergence of ideas, desires and wild inspirations.  There is no guarantee that you will like it.  But of course we hope you'll love it.  By supporting us, you are taking a risk, as we are.  Our risk is that we don't know what exactly this will end up being.  We begin with live materials, not a script or pre-ordained structure.  We put our whole souls into this!  Plus, a lot of time, a lot of LOVE, and ultimately we put faith in the creative process and in the competency of our craft.  In supporting us, you're saying "I want to help these people make some Fresh RISKY art."   The Lift will mean a lot to us, and our hope is that it will also speak to you-  to your depths, your desires, fantasies, past & future.  But chances are you are sure to be welcomed, moved, and challenged.  So come join the adventure with us!


Other Ways You Can Help

  • Please share our campaign with your friends & family- anyone who likes innovation & art.  Every dollar makes a difference!
  • You can use the share tools Indiegogo  which make it so easy to send off an email or post on Facebook.

       Cheers & Thank you!



Feedback

"Pooja's highly original and ongoing work here in the Berkshires is a point of pride for our community, and a source of joy. And joy is important. It is a reason to live."                                                                                                                          -B. Houston, writer, performer, film-maker

"Pooja challenges her audiences to take a risk,
to step into the unfamiliar and unexpected, 
and to intimately engage." 
                                    -Amber Chand, visionary coach, writer, performer


"Haven't been to a show this original in a long time! The use of space, actors and story were truly refreshing and it managed to pull off that almost impossible task of being both serious and fun! I can't wait for Rogue Angel's next production. I'll be in the front row."             -Nicki Wilson, Artistic Director New Stage Performing Arts Center


"Big universal truths as well as the benevolence of ordinary things converge in her delicate frame and big visions. Never afraid to go deeper, she is a conduit for powerful messages longing to manifest themselves in a shared experience that invites us to feel our own human urgency: to be as alive as possible in all states of being. Working with Pooja is like being a small treasure in a grand collage where each piece has been put into a light or frame that hones its unique, intrinsic, terrifying or poetic beauty. This is only possible because of her faith in the depth and experience of every soul...  because of what she believes is possible in each traveler on the way..."                                                                    -Laura Geilen, clown, teacher, dancer

 “I have watched with astonishment and pleasure the creations of the gifted choreographer, performance artist, musician and writer Pooja.  Her events – part theatre, part meditation, part visual poetry – are stunning, evocative, and like all great art, leaves you a changed personand like all great art, leaves you a changed person after witnessing them.  She is a true original, and I find her capacious creative spirit and remarkable productions, appearing like magic in fields, neighborhoods, alleyways, and industrial tunnels, to be in."                                                                     -David Scribner, senior editor The Berkshire Edge  

GREAT BARRINGTON — It wasn’t your typical evening of theater in the Berkshires. The instructions on the play’s flier sounded almost like those of a 1990s-era outlaw rave:  Assemble in a certain parking lot, where organizers will appear and lead you, on foot, to the undisclosed location of the festivities.

On the third and final night of producer-director Pooja Ru Prema’s “Isis-Chernobyl,” about 100 theatergoers assembled in that Housatonic parking lot. Guides appeared and walked them over to a nearby warehouse, where each attendee signed a liability waiver before strolling through the first floor to the outdoor site of the play, beneath a railroad overpass.

Based on ancient Egyptian myths and a vision of the end of the world, the show was part theater, part dance, with an improvised cello accompaniment thrown in for good measure.

This ethos was reflected in the one amenity offered. At intermission, audience members were poured hot cups of “uncertain-tea.”

                                                                                  -from The Boston Globe, Jeremy Goodwin

"Pooja challenges her audiences to take a risk,to step into the unfamiliar and unexpected, and to intimately engage."                                     -Amber Chand, visionary coach, writer, performer
"Haven't been to a show this original in a long time! The use of space, actors and story were truly refreshing and it managed to pull off that almost impossible task of being both serious and fun! I can't wait for Rogue Angel's next production. I'll be in the front row."             -Nicki Wilson, Artistic Director New Stage Performing Arts Center

"Big
universal truths as well as the benevolence of ordinary things converge in
her delicate frame and big visions. Never afraid to go deeper, she is a
conduit for powerful messages longing to manifest themselves in a shared
experience that invites us to feel our own human urgency: to be as alive as possible in all
states of being. Working with Pooja is like being a small
treasure in a grand collage where each piece has been put into a light or
frame that hones its unique, intrinsic, terrifying or poetic
beauty. This is only possible because of her faith in
the depth and experience of every soul...  because of what she
believes is possible in each traveler on the way..."                                                                    -Laura Geilen, clown, teacher, dancer
 “I have watched with astonishment and pleasure the creations of the gifted choreographer, performance artist, musician and writer Pooja.  Her events – part theatre, part meditation, part visual poetry – are stunning, evocative, and like all great art, leaves you a changed personand like all great art, leaves you a changed person after witnessing them.  She is a true original, and I find her capacious creative spirit and remarkable productions, appearing like magic in fields, neighborhoods, alleyways, and industrial tunnels, to be in."                                                                     -David Scribner, senior editor The Berkshire Edge  


GREAT BARRINGTON — It wasn’t your typical evening of theater in the Berkshires. The instructions on the play’s flier sounded almost like those of a 1990s-era outlaw rave:  Assemble in a certain parking lot, where organizers will appear and lead you, on foot, to the undisclosed location of the festivities.
On the third and final night of producer-director Pooja Ru Prema’s “Isis-Chernobyl,” about 100 theatergoers assembled in that Housatonic parking lot. Guides appeared and walked them over to a nearby warehouse, where each attendee signed a liability waiver before strolling through the first floor to the outdoor site of the play, beneath a railroad overpass.
Based on ancient Egyptian myths and a vision of the end of the world, the show was part theater, part dance, with an improvised cello accompaniment thrown in for good measure.
This ethos was reflected in the one amenity offered. At intermission, audience members were poured hot cups of “uncertain-tea.”
                                                                                  -from The Boston Globe, Jeremy Goodwin

story:
Southern Railroad Theatre Company

Bringing the Southern Experience, one hush puppy at a time!

The Southern Railroad Theatre Company has been presenting award winning, critically acclaimed theater in the San Francisco Bay Area since 2008.

We've had the  pleasure of working with some of the best theater companies, theatre makers and artists the Bay Area has to offer. In 2013, we were invited to New York City for Altruistic Theatre Company's Bare Knuckle Theatre Fest. We've been working to build creative alliances with other companies including the immersion experience theatre producers, Incentives to Intrigue.  In 2014, we presented our annual showcase reading of new plays, this time titled INDEPENDENCE: Do Tell! We collaborated with writers and directors from Wily West Productions, Pacifica Table Readers and Pear Avenue Theater.  Later in 2014, we were invited to participate in the Eugene O'Neill Foundation's Eugene O' Neill Festival where we presented A RAZING IN MISSOURI, written and directed by Susan Jackson.

Now, we've been invited back to Manhattan!  This time for the Midtown International Theatre Festival's 2015, Mid Winter Madness Fest.  Directed by Ann Thomas, co-producers Diana Brown and Susan Jackson will represent the Southern Railroad Theatre Company at the festival in Susan Jackson's two-handed comedy/drama IN SITU.  And this time we'll have three performances during week two of the festival.

What starts off as a pleasant afternoon of teasing between Henri and Beth (best friends forever) on a very hot summer day in Charlotte, North Carolina turns into a modern Southern gothic tale of two secrets too many.  They discover that what draws them together may ultimately tear them apart.

Featuring Susan Jackson as Beth and Diana Brown as Henri

Photo by Stacy Marshall


You can help us bring our unique brand of the Southern Experience to the Midwinter Festival by donating to our IndieGoGo Campaign here.  Help fuel Southern Railroad Theatre Company's 2015 New York City performances. We'll be grateful if you do.  And you'll get to be an an associate producer of our second NYC appearance and the New York debut of Susan Jackson's play IN SITU.

Performance Dates:

Monday, February 16 at 8:45 PM

Thursday, February 19 at 7:45 PM

Saturday, February 21 at 5:45 PM

Venue: The Roy Arias Studios, Stage II -300 W. 43rd St., 4th floor, New York, NY

Where your contribution will be used:

  • We'll use your contributions to prepare the production for the festival and to travel to NYC to represent.
  • Our Goal of $4,700 will go to pay for rehearsal space rental, to compensate our director and collaborators. It will fund economy airfare and lodging, enabling Diana and Susan to travel to NYC and perform IN SITU in the festival. And go to pay for advertising to market our participation in the festival and to document the project.

Even if we don't receive our entire funding goal, any contribution will help us to accept the invitation to perform and make our 2015 Festival appearance possible. as well as ensure the continued artistic growth of the Southern Railroad Theatre Company.

In thanks for your support:

  • You'll receive inside access to the production process through special posts and video updates.
  • Souvenirs from our NYC Midwinter Festival experience.
  • At certain levels, Producers will enjoy producing credit in the program, a special performance of IN SITU in San Francisco in the spring of 2015.  An "afternoon BBQ"  with the cast of IN SITU and other Southern Railroad Company Members. All of you will receive our sincere gratitude!

As an independent producing company, we are used finding ways to self fund. Even if we don't receive our entire funding goal, any contribution will help us to accept the invitation to perform and make our 2015 Festival appearance possible. Your support and contributions also ensure the continued artistic growth of the Southern Railroad Theatre Company.

Your contributions will go to help us make the most of our second NYC appearance:

  • This opportunity to meet and work with NYC theatre artist will increase our community of collaborators will increase our knowledge of theatre and refresh our perspectives.  We hope to use the opportunity to forge new creative partnerships, possibly bringing New York artists to work with us here in the San Francisco Bay Area, increasing our community at home and on the East Coast.
  • As always a portion of our proceeds will go in support of a charity.  In the past, we've supported Tornado Relief in Joplin, MO., Puppy Rescue Mission, 
  • SF Suicide Prevention and Rocket Dog Rescue.  
  • Southern Railroad Theatre Company has been presenting award winning, critically acclaimed theatre in the Bay Area since 2008. 

Risks & Challenges:

We're excited to face the challenge of bringing a San Francisco based company to a NYC festival.  Co-producers, Brown and Jackson have marketed and presented performances in NYC in the past will rely on what they've learned from those experiences as well as working with the Festival marketing and PR representatives.  We'll also be using online marketing to reach the general public. In addition to reaching out to our existing NYC theatre community.

Other Ways You Can Help: 

  • Not everyone can contribute financially.  Your good wishes, sharing our story on social media and introductions to your New York friends are just as valuable and appreciated!
  • Indiegogo share tools are a great way to do just that!
  • Thank you!!!!

story:
In Cahoots Theatre is a new Philadelphia-based activist theatre company founded by Tori Mittelman and Madison Auch. Here at In Cahoots we believe that theatre can and should be used as a tool to show societal strife and bridge the gap between all aspects of life. Theatre should not be an event for the privileged, but an experience accessible to anyone willing to be thrown into the world with us. In Cahoots strives to work with as many different disciplines as possible, ranging from scientists, painters, musicians, mathematicians, etc. Theatre should not set up a divide between societal structures, but break them down and create a new form of artistic expression. 

For our inaugural production, we will be bringing Ron Whyte's Pulitzer-prize nominated Disability: A Comedy to the 2015 Philadelphia Fringe Festival. After hearing about the play in a conversation with a cast mate, Tori was determined to find the script to this never-been-published play; a few weeks and many emails later she was able to track it down, and will now be directing its Philadelphia premiere this September! 
 
Disability: A Comedy follows Larry, a 29-year old quadriplegic who has only left the small apartment he shares with his overly-doting parents a handful of times. Desperate for an escape, he puts out an ad looking for a "sexy rich girl, 21 to 29. Object: running away and living happily ever after." However, when Jayne shows up at his door, he soon realizes he's about to get into much more than he bargained for... A story of overcoming obstacles and seeing people for who they truly are, Disability: A Comedy is sure to intrigue and inspire audiences of all kinds. 

So Here's What We Need From You!

In order to bring this touching and thought-provoking show to the Fringe, we need your help! After carefully looking at our budget, we have determined that we will need to raise about $5,000 to make this dream a reality. 

The support we receive from contributors will help to cover the cost of:

* Advertising/Promotional Materials
* Fringe Fees
* Set/Lighting/Sound/Costumes/Props (anyone have a spare electric wheelchair?)
* Rehearsal Space
* Performance Venue Rental
* Salaries for Actors/Designers/Production Team

No contribution is too small! (Plus, look at those perks! Your very own Vivaldi doll? It's all you've ever wanted! Dinner with the company? Score!)


Who We Are

Tori Mittelman, founder, and Madison Auch, founding member of In Cahoots Theatre Company, met in 2006 while both living in Fairfax, Virginia during high school. Fast friends and like-minded artists, they started working together early on to create provocative pieces of theatre; in 2010 they put up a production of Don Nigro's Seascape with Sharks and Dancer, in which Tori directed and Madison played Tracy. While attending school in Wisconsin, Tori created a devised project, Traveling to a Strange Place, that focused on feminist issues with classmate Mona Maclay. It was during this endeavor that the term In Cahoots was coined, after a professor of Maclay's and Mittelman's used the term to describe the pair's friendship and unconventional method of collaboration. After Tori moved to Philadelphia in the fall of 2014, In Cahoots Theatre was created, and is thrilled to be producing their first show in the Philadelphia Fringe next fall. 

Tori Mittelman was born in Pensacola, Florida and from there, moved all over the world as a Navy Brat.  She began writing and directing plays at a young age, with her first real showcase writing the moving ten-minute play about Moses- starring her as Moses. From there, Tori went on to study at the University of Wisconsin- Stevens Point where she earned her degree in BFA Acting with a minor in Peace Studies. She is currently working as a literary intern at the Wilma Theatre in Philadelphia. 

Madison Auch graduated from The University of the Arts in 2014 with a degree in Musical Theatre.  She is an adventurous and compassionate individual who brings her passion for telling stories and her desire to provoke audiences into everything she does. Her ardor and sincerity as an actor, singer, teaching artist, and musician shine through her work, and she attacks each project with commitment and professionalism, maintaining the belief that the most productive environment is one in which the desire for knowledge fuels a sense of curiosity and questioning, while also allowing for a playful exploration of the material. Madison strives to encourage audiences to maintain a sense of flirtatious curiosity, questioning the world they live in and never settling for the easy answer.


Other Ways You Can Help

Not able to contribute at this time?  There are other ways you can help us!

*  Like our Facebook page, follow our Twitter and Instagram, and check out our website to keep up to date with our work on this and future shows!

* Come on out to see Disability: A Comedy in the Philadelphia Fringe Festival this fall!  

* Spread the word! Share our Indiegogo with your friends; the more people we can reach, the better!


Thank you so much from the bottom of our hearts, and please join us on our adventure to bring this production to life!

                                                             - Tori, Madison, and the In Cahoots team
