story:
"Enthusiasm is the most important thing in life."  — Tennessee Williams
                              A timeless masterpiece.  An innovative collaboration.

                               ISLAND PRODUCTIONS PRESENTS:

               

                    You can leave a broken home, but can you ever really escape it?

WHAT IS THIS STORY ABOUT?

"[The Glass] Menagerie reveals the story of family members whose lives form a triangle of quiet desperation, each struggling with an individual version of hell while simultaneously seeking escape from the gravity of each other's pathologies."   —  Robert Bray
 
And in this quiet triangle of desperation, lives a story about three people who love each other. Tennessee Williams writes about the universal.
We are raising money to shed light on something you thought you knew - home. "How beautiful it is and how easily it can be broken"  — The Glass Menagerie.

This is a Canadian Production of Tennessee William’s classic. It explores the plight of the single mother raising two adult children on her own. Williams offers to the audience, something we can examine and digest through tears and laughter.

Why is this play relevant today?

Today, the electronic world is changing into the digital world. There is revolution and evolution going on as a result, and the whole nuclear family concept is in great flux. Individualism versus collectivism is an ongoing debate and a paramount theme in the breakdown of the family unit. 

It is significant to take something like THE GLASS MENAGERIE, and mount it at this particular time because it is a great metaphor for change and reflective of all things topical. It looks both backward and forward in time, outward and inward. It depicts heroes and victims that we can all relate to. As John Lahr states, “it also broadcasts William’s dramatic goal – to redeem life, through beauty, from the humiliation of grief.”

WHO'S INVOLVED?

Directed by Mel Tuck

Associate Director Sean Sullivan

Set and Costume Design by Diana Capstick-Dale
Sound Design by David Cieri
Set Construction by David McLeod

Cast in order of appearance:

Andrew Coghlan as Tom
Lynne Griffin as Amanda
Gina Leon as Laura
Michael Germant as The Gentleman Caller

SEPTEMBER 7- 25 @ PAL STUDIO THEATRE
PREVIEW SHOW September 6th.
581 Cardero Street, Vancouver.

TICKETS available HERE!

WHY TELL THIS STORY TODAY?

From director Mel Tuck: The greatest playwrights come forward when society is changing. Chekhov and the revolution. Shakespeare and the Renaissance. Homer, Euripides and Aristophanes in Greece and the city states. Williams and the end of the antibellum period and WWI. The beginning of post-war future. We are in this similar kind of transition now. The world is changing hugely. The "Dinosaurs" are like Amanda holding desperately on to the past and with that holding on some people will be sacrificed. Like Laura is. Like Syrians and natives in Africa. Amanda is a terrifying person, but she's funny. So are dinosaurs.

                           

                   Karen Austin (as Laura) and Director Mel Tuck (as Tom) - 1968

And so...

When a writer tells a story that has to be told...

                     

                    

               
When a director lifts the vision off the page and creates a world in which we are transported to...

  

                                

                                                                Director Mel Tuck

     


When an actor artfully and truthful inhabits a character, humanizing the written experience...

     

When the atmosphere of a play is enhanced by the subtle dynamics of light and sound...

Here he is by the way, our composer extraordinaire... DAVID CIERI

    


When the set illuminates social and economic, private and public, personal and political tensions of a world written by TENNESSEE WILLIAMS...

                                           

                           Stage and Costume Designer (Diana Capstick- Dale)

 
THEATRE IS ELECTRIFYING.
This is something to strive for, isn't it?  


WHY THEATRE?

In an age where most communication is through some media filter like the Internet, Twitter, Facebook, Google, Television and Film, there is something spiritual in people sitting and focused in a direction and exploring the human experience in a human manner whether it's through humor or drama. The energy of the live experience transcends anything mechanical. We need to keep our ears as alert and active as our eyes. And our brains and senses as sharp as we possibly can. The live experience is the source — Director Mel Tuck


WHY ARE WE RAISING MONEY?
We started small as an independent company, in an effort to create a unified approach to the work, selecting evocative material well-suited to the company and written by the greats.

 For more information: www.island-productions.ca

In the past, we personally invested money in our productions and had individual donors generously support us.

We are growing the size of our company for this production and this includes:

A production that represents our unique Canadian vision.
A ensemble cast from both Vancouver and Toronto.
An extended run of performances.
A highly-skilled set and costume designer.
An accomplished composer designing the music.
A professional set construction artist.
An acclaimed Canadian director with an extensive number of past productions.

What are we doing next?

After our Vancouver run, we are taking the play to Toronto!

WHO ARE WE?

   


We are an ensemble of artists from the two major English-speaking theatrical centres in Canada: British Columbia and Ontario.

Mel Tuck (Director) : is a highly regarded pioneer of Canadian theatre, a director of international reputation and an innovator in acting training technique and philosophy. His Career spans over fifty years, Mel founded nine theatre companies and has directed over three hundred plays across Canada. He headed the drama department at Ryerson University for thirteen years and originated and ran the Gastown Actors Studio conservatory for twelve years. Mel holds a BFA from the University of Alberta and has been recognized in the form of three ACTRA and two Genie nominations. After a near-absolute three decade hiatus from performing, Mel has returned to acting last fall, starring in the 2015 Crazy8s thriller Under a Glass Moon, the upcoming short drama With Dad and the short comedy Legally Speaking. He will be appearing this year in the feature films The Confirmation opposite Clive Owen, the independent Canadian drama Floating Away, and CBC’s Full Flood.

Sean Sullivan (Associate Director):

Sean Sullivan has directed rarely, but with enthusiasm. His production of Genet’s ‘The Balcony’ received Los Angeles Drama-Logue Awards for production, director and lead actress. He has also directed ‘What The Butler Saw’ on Sanibel Island, FLA. and ‘Jeeves and Wooster’ in Nevada City, CA.

Sean’s life has revolved around the theatre from birth. His mother was an actress, director of education and dramaturge at the Tony-Award winning Old Globe Theatre in San Diego, where Sean’s professional career began as well, performed in twelve plays. Other favourite roles include; his award-winning solo performance in Baby Redboots’ Revenge, (called ‘a virtual Nijinsky of performance art’ by the New York Times, and directed by his wife, Lynne Griffin, in New York, Poland, the Czech Republic, Toronto, Los Angeles, San Diego and Hamilton), Norman in The Dresser and Davey/Leon in The Voice of the Prairie, (where he met and fell in love with Lynne).Sean’s recent Toronto productions; The Castle, (The Storefront),The Merry Wives of Windsor, (Shakespeare Bash’d, 2015 Toronto Fringe), Liver, Out At Sea, (Storefront Theatre), A Midsummer Nightmare, (The Great Hall), Potosi, (Tarragon, Toronto Fringe), and The Seagull, (with the Chekhov Collective, (Berkeley Street Theatre). Selected film credits: God and Country, (upcoming), Wayne’s World, Back To The Future III, Who’s That Girl?, Foolproof and The Howling VI. Selected TV credits: Damien, Hemlock Grove, Good God, The Associates, (Gemini nominee, series regular), Across The River To Motor City, Poor Tom is Cold, Babylon Five and Quantum Leap.

For more information, visit www.babymonsterproductions.ca

Diana Capstick- Dale (Set & Costume Designer):

Diana Capstick- Dale was born in Johannesburg, South Africa. She studied fine art at the University of the Witwatersrand and graphic design at the École des Beaux Arts et Arts Appliqués in Lausanne, Switzerland. She worked as a graphic designer before moving to the UK where she studied for a Masters degree in Stage Design at the Central School of Speech and Drama. Her work includes costumes for Chicago (Embassy Theatre, London), sets and costumes for Yerma (Embassy Theatre, London), Guys and Dolls (Bloomsbury Theatre, London), Judy (Oldham Coliseum, Oldham) as well as working with students on productions at the Central School of Speech and Drama. She has recently co-written a book on Art Deco Collectibles to be published in April 2016.

David McLeod (Set Construction):                                                                          After a long absence from the acting field, David re-entered the performing arts world by becoming a labourer in the construction departments of the t.v. and film industry. With a stated desire to become a carpenter he carried lumber, loaded and unloaded trucks with scenery and swept floors the size of aircraft hangars for three years; all the while taking any opportunity to develop the skills of cutting and building with wood,  now an apprentice with the carpentry team of one of the most respected crews in Vancouver, David is thrilled to apply himself to helping to create the world of this extraordinary play for artists whose worth he has already witnessed first hand. 


CAST:

ANDREW COGHLAN (Tom): Andrew was born in Edmonton, Alberta. He currently lives in Toronto. Andrew has studied at the VOICE INTENSIVE at UBC. He has studied with Michael Sims and Larry Moss. THEATRE: Four Dogs and a Bone, Italian American Reconciliation, Last Train To Nibroc, Lobby Hero, Almost Maine. FILM/TELEVISION: The Invisible (Disney/Dreamworks), The A-Team (20th Century Fox), Alcatraz, Fringe (Bad Robot/Warner Bros.), Eureka (NBC Universal), Psych (Universal)  

LYNNE GRIFFIN (Amanda) "is what director David Ellenstein describes as "a heavy-weight" in the industry. Her credits span more than 5 decades and include print, film, television and theatre. She was a child model and actor, appearing in multitudes of commercials and even hosting a children's television show in Toronto. Lynne went on to become a stalwart of Canadian television and a formidable presence in the theatre, where she was a regular at the Shaw and Stratford festivals and myriad other important companies throughout the country. Her diversity is awe inspiring - she starred with Peter Ustinov in King Lear at Stratford, and only a few years later with Max Von Sydow, Dave Thomas and Rick Moranis in the film, Strange Brew. She was gruesomely murdered Black Christmas along with Margot Kidder and others. That film starred John Saxon and Olivia Hussey. Her IMDB page is a who's who of world cinema "  - Jeanmarie Simpson


    


GINA LEON (Laura) : Gina was born Johannesburg, South Africa. She is a Vancouver based actress, visual artist and art teacher. She studied Theatre and Art History at the University of Toronto, Visual Art at the College of Art and Design in Sydney, Australia, and Acting at the New School for Drama in NYC. Her abstract paintings have been showcased in Vancouver and New York City (The William Bennett Gallery and The Rockefeller Center). THEATRE: A Weekend Near Madison (The Cultch – Vancouver Fringe Festival), The Dreamer Examines His Pillow (PAL), Seminar (PAL), The Seagull (NYC) Epitaph for George Dillon (Off-Broadway, NYC), A Young Lady of Property (NYC), A Midsummer Night’s Dream (NYC), Turn of the Screw (NYC), Almost Maine (Studio 1398,Vancouver), Under Milk Wood (Waterfront Theatre), The Oresteia of Aeschylus, Mistero Buffo, The Servant of Two Masters (University of Toronto). FILM/TELEVISION: “Girlfriends Guide to Divorce” (Bravo), “The Killing” (Fox), “Twist of Faith” (Lifetime), "Untold Stories of the ER".

    


MICHAEL GERMANT (The Gentleman Caller): Actor & Producer at Island Productions. Michael was born in Moscow and raised in Montreal. He has studied at the Montreal School of Performing Arts, Acting Studio Montreal, Concordia University, UBC, VFS, Michael Howard Studios, and Austin-Tuck Studios. THEATRE: Tommy in John Patrick Shanley’s The Dreamer Examines His Pillow, Martin in Theresa Rebeck's Seminar, Norris in Alan Ball's Bachelor Holiday, Stuyvesant Student in The New York Monologues, Lu Dahai in Cao Yu's Thunderstorm. FILM/TELEVISION: War for the Planet of the Apes (20th Century Fox), Arrow (Warner Bros. Television) , Continuum (Showcase), High Moon (Universal Cable Productions).


RISKS and CHALLENGES:

  • When we think of theatre towns, we conjure up the image of New York, London, Berlin, and Toronto, but productions and audiences are everywhere. Is there demand in Vancouver? YES, YES, YES!
  • When we think of talent or artistry...  we know that these traits are not limited to any one time or place... Why can't Vancouver be as prolific as any other theatre town?

  • This is a play in which past and present tensions manifest on stage, as they do in a dysfunctional family dynamic. While our production is a classical rendering of a classical play, every aspect of it is relevant to a modern audience. We believe the best way to do this is to honor what we call “The Williams’ Aesthetic”. The major challenge in this approach is to create with utmost specificity, the world in which Williams writes about. Specificity in story-telling is universally effective. To meet the demands of this challenge, we have started our process long in advance and this has included dramaturgical studies of the play/playwright. Williams’ family life occupies a huge presence in this play and there is great information at our disposal. We have also created a marriage between veterans and young professionals of the theatre as our ensemble consists of both. This dynamic has already created a kind of work ethic and synergy that has proven very effective.


Creating a high standard of theatre keeps the theatre running!

Where does the money go? Here is a visual:


    For more information check out our website at www.glassmenagerie.ca

     

    Spread the word and THANK YOU you for your support!
story_txt:
"Enthusiasm is the most important thing in life."  — Tennessee Williams
                              A timeless masterpiece.  An innovative collaboration. 


                               ISLAND PRODUCTIONS PRESENTS:


                

                    You can leave a broken home, but can you ever really escape it? 
WHAT IS THIS STORY ABOUT?"[The Glass] Menagerie
 reveals the story of family members whose lives form a triangle of 
quiet desperation, each struggling with an individual version of hell 
while simultaneously seeking escape from the gravity of each other's 
pathologies."   —  Robert Bray And in this quiet triangle of desperation, lives a story about three people who love each other. Tennessee Williams writes about the universal. We are raising money to shed light on something you thought you knew - home. "How beautiful it is and how easily it can be broken"  — The Glass Menagerie.This is a Canadian Production of
Tennessee William’s classic. It explores the plight of the single mother raising two adult children on her own. Williams offers to the audience, something we can examine and digest
through tears and laughter. 
Why is this play relevant today?
Today,
the electronic world is changing into the digital world. There is revolution
and evolution going on as a result, and the whole nuclear family concept is in
great flux. Individualism versus collectivism is an ongoing debate and a
paramount theme in the breakdown of the family unit.  
It
is significant to take something like THE GLASS MENAGERIE, and mount it at this
particular time because it is a great metaphor for change and reflective of all
things topical. It looks both backward and forward in time, outward and inward.
It depicts heroes and victims that we can all relate to. As John Lahr states,
“it also broadcasts William’s dramatic goal – to redeem life, through beauty,
from the humiliation of grief.”
WHO'S INVOLVED?Directed by Mel TuckAssociate Director Sean Sullivan Set and Costume Design by Diana Capstick-DaleSound Design by David CieriSet Construction by David McLeodCast in order of appearance: Andrew Coghlan as TomLynne Griffin as AmandaGina Leon as LauraMichael Germant as The Gentleman CallerSEPTEMBER 7- 25 @ PAL STUDIO THEATREPREVIEW SHOW September 6th.581 Cardero Street, Vancouver.TICKETS available HERE!
WHY TELL THIS STORY TODAY?From director Mel Tuck: The greatest playwrights come forward when 
society is changing. Chekhov and the revolution. Shakespeare and the 
Renaissance. Homer, Euripides and Aristophanes in Greece and the city 
states. Williams and the end of the antibellum period and WWI. The 
beginning of post-war future. We are in this similar kind of transition 
now. The world is changing hugely. The "Dinosaurs" are like Amanda 
holding desperately on to the past and with that holding on some people 
will be sacrificed. Like Laura is. Like Syrians and natives in Africa. 
Amanda is a terrifying person, but she's funny. So are dinosaurs.                                               Karen Austin (as Laura) and Director Mel Tuck (as Tom) - 1968And so...When a writer tells a story that has to be told...
                      

                                     When a director lifts the vision off the page and creates a world in which we are transported to...                                     
                                                                Director Mel Tuck
      

When an actor artfully and truthful inhabits a character, humanizing the written experience...

     


When the atmosphere of a play is enhanced by the subtle dynamics of light and sound...
Here he is by the way, our composer extraordinaire... DAVID CIERI
     
When the set illuminates social and economic, private and public, personal 
and political tensions of a world written by TENNESSEE WILLIAMS...

                                            
                           Stage and Costume Designer (Diana Capstick- Dale)  

THEATRE IS ELECTRIFYING. This is something to strive for, isn't it?  
WHY THEATRE?

In an age where most communication is through some media filter 
like the Internet, Twitter, Facebook, Google, Television and Film, there
 is something spiritual in people sitting and focused in a direction and
 exploring the human experience in a human manner whether it's through humor or drama. The energy of the live experience transcends anything 
mechanical. We need to keep our ears as alert and active as our eyes. 
And our brains and senses as sharp as we possibly can. The live 
experience is the source — Director Mel Tuck

WHY ARE WE RAISING MONEY?We started small as an 
independent company, in an effort to create a unified approach to the 
work, selecting evocative material well-suited to the company and written by the greats.


 For more information: www.island-productions.ca
In the past, we personally invested money in our productions and had individual donors generously support us. 

We are growing the size of our company for this production and this includes:A production that represents our unique Canadian vision.A ensemble cast from both Vancouver and Toronto.An extended run of performances.A highly-skilled set and costume designer.An accomplished composer designing the music.A professional set construction artist. An acclaimed Canadian director with an extensive number of past productions.What are we doing next?After our Vancouver run, we are taking the play to Toronto!WHO ARE WE?    We are an ensemble of artists from the two major
English-speaking theatrical centres in Canada: British Columbia and Ontario.
Mel Tuck (Director) : is
a highly regarded pioneer of Canadian theatre, a director of international
reputation and an innovator in acting training technique and philosophy. His Career spans over fifty years, Mel founded nine theatre companies and has
directed over three hundred plays across Canada. He headed the drama department
at Ryerson University for thirteen years and originated and ran the Gastown
Actors Studio conservatory for twelve years. Mel holds a BFA from the
University of Alberta and has been recognized in the form of three ACTRA and
two Genie nominations. After a near-absolute three decade
hiatus from performing, Mel has returned to acting last fall, starring in the
2015 Crazy8s thriller Under a Glass Moon, the upcoming short drama With Dad and
the short comedy Legally Speaking. He will be appearing this year in the
feature films The Confirmation opposite Clive Owen, the independent Canadian
drama Floating Away, and CBC’s Full Flood.Sean Sullivan (Associate Director): 
Sean
Sullivan has directed rarely, but with enthusiasm. His production of Genet’s
‘The Balcony’ received Los Angeles Drama-Logue Awards for production, director
and lead actress. He has also directed ‘What The Butler Saw’ on Sanibel Island,
FLA. and ‘Jeeves and Wooster’ in Nevada City, CA.
Sean’s
life has revolved around the theatre from birth. His mother was an actress,
director of education and dramaturge at the Tony-Award winning Old Globe
Theatre in San Diego, where Sean’s professional career began as well, performed
in twelve plays. Other favourite roles include; his award-winning solo
performance in Baby Redboots’ Revenge, (called
‘a virtual Nijinsky of performance art’
by the New York Times, and directed by his wife, Lynne Griffin, in New York,
Poland, the Czech Republic, Toronto, Los Angeles, San Diego and Hamilton),
Norman in The Dresser and Davey/Leon
in The Voice of the Prairie, (where
he met and fell in love with Lynne).Sean’s recent Toronto productions; The Castle, (The Storefront),The Merry Wives of Windsor, (Shakespeare
Bash’d, 2015 Toronto Fringe), Liver, Out
At Sea, (Storefront Theatre), A
Midsummer Nightmare, (The Great Hall), Potosi,
(Tarragon, Toronto Fringe), and The
Seagull, (with the Chekhov Collective, (Berkeley Street Theatre). Selected film credits: God and Country, (upcoming), Wayne’s World, Back To The Future III, Who’s
That Girl?, Foolproof and The
Howling VI. Selected TV credits: Damien,
Hemlock Grove, Good God, The Associates, (Gemini nominee, series regular), Across The River To Motor City, Poor Tom is
Cold, Babylon Five and Quantum Leap.
For
more information, visit www.babymonsterproductions.ca
Diana Capstick- Dale (Set & Costume Designer): Diana Capstick- Dale was born in Johannesburg, South Africa. She 
studied fine art at the University of the Witwatersrand and graphic 
design at the École des Beaux Arts et Arts Appliqués in Lausanne, 
Switzerland. She worked as a graphic designer before moving to the UK 
where she studied for a Masters degree in Stage Design at the Central 
School of Speech and Drama. Her work includes costumes for Chicago 
(Embassy Theatre, London), sets and costumes for Yerma (Embassy Theatre,
 London), Guys and Dolls (Bloomsbury Theatre, London), Judy (Oldham 
Coliseum, Oldham) as well as working with students on productions at the
 Central School of Speech and Drama.  She has recently co-written a book
 on Art Deco Collectibles to be published in April 2016. 
David McLeod (Set Construction):                                                                          After a long absence from 
the acting field, David re-entered the performing arts world by becoming

industry. With a stated desire to become a carpenter he carried lumber,

to develop the skills of cutting and building with wood,  now an 
apprentice with the carpentry team of one of the most respected crews in
 Vancouver, David is thrilled to apply himself to helping to create the 
world of this extraordinary play for artists whose worth he has already 
witnessed first hand. 


CAST:

Alberta. He currently lives in Toronto. Andrew has studied at the VOICE

Fringe (Bad Robot/Warner Bros.), Eureka (NBC Universal), Psych (Universal)  
LYNNE GRIFFIN (Amanda) "is
what director David Ellenstein
describes as "a heavy-weight" in the industry. Her credits span more
than 5 decades and include print, film, television and theatre. She was a child
model and actor, appearing in multitudes of commercials and even hosting a
children's television show in Toronto. Lynne went on to become a stalwart of
Canadian television and a formidable presence in the theatre, where she was a
regular at the Shaw and Stratford festivals and myriad other important
companies throughout the country. Her diversity is awe inspiring - she starred
with Peter Ustinov
in King Lear at Stratford, and only a few years later with Max Von Sydow,
Dave Thomas and Rick Moranis in the film, Strange Brew. She was gruesomely murdered
Black Christmas along with Margot Kidder and others. That film starred John Saxon and Olivia Hussey. Her
IMDB page is a who's who of world cinema "  - Jeanmarie Simpson 
     


GINA LEON (Laura) : Gina was born
Johannesburg, South Africa. She is a Vancouver based actress, visual artist and
art teacher. She studied Theatre and Art
History at the University of Toronto, Visual Art at the College of Art and

Festival), The Dreamer Examines His Pillow (PAL), Seminar (PAL), The

MICHAEL GERMANT (The Gentleman Caller): Actor
& Producer at Island Productions. Michael was born in Moscow and raised in

story:
Studio 570 utilizes the concept of found space theater on our mission to engage ​the local arts community​. Our audiences experience theater in different environments to challenge the current expectation of attending live performances. We explore projects including modern, classic, and derived plays, as well as musical theatre and cabaret-style concerts. Together​, the Studio 570 team, and local businesses collaborate to bring artistic opportunities to audiences, actors and volunteers alike.

Our Mission: To produce captivating musicals, plays, new works and experiences through innovative storytelling and purposeful design, with the use of found spaces and unique locations, while cultivating a meaningful understanding and appreciation of the artistic process with a community of all ages through education and engagement.

Company Vision: To become a theatre company that is respected locally, recognized regionally and known nationally, and to elevate central Pennsylvania to national prominence as a unique, viable destination for world-class professional theatre.

 

experience. engage. explore. together

story:
The name on everybody's lips is gonna be Adolf.

Here she is, boys!
Here she is, world-ish!
Here’s ADOLF!

Start spreading the good word, ‘cause Mein Comps is gearing up for world domination... err... tour. A ridiculous 2018/2019 world-ish tour! Where it’ll stop, nobody knows! Just kidding. The full show’s coming back to Chicago, plus first-time engagements in New York, Pittsburgh, London (!!!), and more. Dates, theatres (and that’s theatre with an -re), and casting coming soon.

There will also be a one-man edition of the show traipsing around the 2018 U.S. fringe festival circuit. Applications have been sent in to Minneapolis, Providence, San Diego, and San Francisco. Announcements will be made as lotteries are performed.

Mein Comps, written by and starring the shrewd, undomesticated, and Chicago-based Tyler Anthony Smith, is a gaaaaay fantasia on irrational international themes, in a which a certain dictator sells discounted theatre tickets. Mhmm.

It's just another typical day for Adolf Moira Angela Hitler. Hungover. Sore. Constantly on the phone, dealing with fools who want orchestra seats to Cats at bargain prices. But wires are crossed when a mysterious customer from a month ago wedges his way into our fabulous trainwreck of a leading man's heart. Will Mademoiselle Hitler end his streak of sleeping around and settle down? Will he sober up in time to remember that today's the day he has an audition for the role of Amanda in yet another revival of The Glass Menagerie? Are you more confused now than when you started reading this semi-synopsis?

Money, money, money...

It must be funny in a rich man's world, huh? Well, in order to make Adolf Moira's funny world-ish tour go off without hitch, she needs some dough. It's a real biotch playing the Beggar Woman, but in order to get your art out of the womb, you gotta push. Push it real good.

The goal is to raise $3,000. That's chump change for folks who use the phrase "chump change." This will cover the costs of theatre rentals and travel.

Yes, yes, yes. Of course you get something if you donate, you grubby minxes.

  • $10 - A THANK YOU in the show program. You know you've always wanted the be thanked on a page in a booklet that is likely to be left on the floor of a theatre.
  • $25 - You get a thank you, and a TICKET to a performance of the full version of the show in a city of your choosing. Unfortunately, Tyler has not much control over any potential fringe tix.
  • $50 - The thank you. The ticket. Plus, a PERSONALIZED POSTCARD from the one and only hot mess express Adolf Moira Angela Hitler.
  • $100 - Every prize that you've read about so far, plus a 2019 12-MONTH CALENDAR featuring Adolf Moira in all sorts of sticky (literally and figuratively) situations.
  • $200 - All of the above, and ASSOCIATE PRODUCER CREDIT. You wanna be a producer? Now's your shot! Think how glorious your new Tinder bio will be. "I love brunch, my gal pals, and I'm the Associate Producer of an uber fringey play about Adolf Hitler selling discounted theatre tickets." Consider yourself wed.

It goes without saying that we live in a trying world. Laughter is necessary. Via Adolf Hitler? Sure, why not. Ridiculous theatre thrives when it is catapulted forward by humorous social commentary. Corrupt, insane - the descriptives can go on for days - men can only be matched when they are presented in a way that embarrasses them. That is this show. But, like, in a fun way, of course. By taking a Tonya Harding to Hitler's name, Mein Comps takes down the vile legacy of the famous dictator by allowing an audience to do what he would simply lose his shit over - it allows them to laugh at him. Besides reintroducing audiences to the land of the ridiculous, a form of performance that of course still exists, but is overshadowed lately by the "real" and the "raw," this show will hopefully remind you that we have to laugh at what terrifies us. In laughter we can find sweet, sugary revenge.

After you donate (if you can), consider sharing on ye olde social media in order to help spread the word! And give the show's page a like on Facebook in order to stay up to date on tour locations, dates, scandalous photos and videos, etc.

http://fb.com/meincomps

story:
When Audrey and Ron get a divorce, they take the rest of the country with them. Waste, Fraud and Abuse is the tune-packed tale of a presidential campaign gone bananas, with protesters in the streets, shady deals in the boardroom, sex in the war-room, and a walrus in the bathtub! It's a fast paced and wry evisceration of the love of politics and the politics of love.
We're three years into this project. We've had an overwhelmingly  successful blowout preview performance, and have been wood-shedding ever since, adding songs, cutting lines and sharpening jokes. It's ready, it's damn good and it's the best thing Dave and I have ever done. We've got a pro director in Bryna Kearney and we're offering travel stipends  and show vouchers to attract the best cast possible. We've even got a real theater: The 13th Street Rep! Now that we've found a home for our baby you can help us pay the rent and bring the dream to life! 

We're poor and it's expensive. Here are some of the costs broken down.

Rental: $3,375.00
Show Vouchers for Actors/Director: $2,520.00
Travel Stipends for Actors/Director through rehearsals: $840.00
Rehearsals: $750.00
Publicity: $400.00
Auditions (Space rental and Accompanist Fee): $350.00
Refreshments for performances: $300.00
Insurance: $200.00
Sets: $200.00
Props: $200.00
Tech rehearsal (renting for time and payment to the house technician): $195.00
Dress Rehearsal: $120.00
Band/Cast music rehearsal: $120.00

It adds up! We appreciate all the help we can get. The show is solid, funny, insightful and we promise it will entertain. You'll be giving a large cast, band, and crew a great experience and realizing a dream for Dave and Dan.
story_txt: When Audrey and Ron get a divorce, they take the rest of the country with them. Waste, Fraud and Abuse is the tune-packed tale of a presidential campaign gone bananas, with protesters in the streets, shady deals in the boardroom, sex in the war-room, and a walrus in the bathtub! It's a fast paced and wry evisceration of the love of politics and the politics of love.We're three years into this project. We've had an overwhelmingly  successful blowout preview performance, and have been wood-shedding ever since, adding songs, cutting lines and sharpening jokes. It's ready, it's damn good and it's the best thing Dave and I have ever done. We've got a pro director in Bryna Kearney and we're offering travel stipends  and show vouchers to attract the best cast possible. We've even got a real theater: The 13th Street Rep! Now that we've found a home for our baby you can help us pay the rent and bring the dream to life! We're poor and it's expensive. Here are some of the costs broken down. Rental: $3,375.00Show Vouchers for Actors/Director: $2,520.00Travel Stipends for Actors/Director through rehearsals: $840.00Rehearsals: $750.00Publicity: $400.00Auditions (Space rental and Accompanist Fee): $350.00Refreshments for performances: $300.00Insurance: $200.00Sets: $200.00Props: $200.00Tech rehearsal (renting for time and payment to the house technician): $195.00Dress Rehearsal: $120.00Band/Cast music rehearsal: $120.00It adds up! We appreciate all the help we can get. The show is solid, funny, insightful and we promise it will entertain. You'll be giving a large cast, band, and crew a great experience and realizing a dream for Dave and Dan.

story:
Franklin County's New Home for the Arts

When the town of Turners Falls asked the community what to do with the Shea Theater, a group of us imagined a place that would serve all of us — artists, families, students, elders, youth, businesses, and nonprofits — who make our homes here.

Now, we have a rare opportunity to create something amazing: an arts center and community space for the 21st century. 

Building upgrades and great programming will make the Shea a regional destination, a center of conversation, and a headquarters for Franklin County’s cultural and economic revival. 

With 330 seats, the Shea is the perfect venue to encourage the growing local arts scene. 


What Will Do at the Shea?

Dude, what won't we do at the Shea? 

Seriously, our new board of directors wants the Shea to welcome and represent every one of us. We'll bring great musicians, dancers, and actors here from around the country.

We have amazing talent right here, too, and we already have incredible partners ready to work with us, including:

  • Amherst Ballet
  • Double Edge Theatre
  • Egg Tooth Productions
  • Four Rivers Charter Public School
  • Green River Festival Productions
  • Greenfield Community College
  • Lisa Leizman Dance Company
  • MASS MoCA
  • Paintbox Theatre
  • Peter Blanchette and the Happy Valley Guitar Orchestra 
  • Pioneer Valley Jazz Shares
  • SHOW Circus Studio
  • Signature Sounds
  • Starlight Youth Theater
  • The Ha Ha’s
  • Tony Margherita Management
  • Turners Falls Riverculture
  • Welcome Yule
  • Young Shakespeare Players 

The Shea is Looking Great!

We've been quietly raising money to make the Shea more beautiful and comfortable than it's ever been. Volunteers have been painting and repairing the building, top to bottom, and you're going to have to see the new lobby and bar to believe it. It's simply gorgeous.


You Can Help Us Finish the Job

We're so close to having the Shea finished. But without great sound and lighting, we can't easily attract the amazing performers we'd all love to see here. That's where you come in.

We need to raise $50,000 to finish making the Shea a really great venue:
  • A world-class sound system that works for live music, theater, and more.
  • A great theatrical lighting system.
  • Complete renovations to restore and beautify the theater.

With your help, we will have the best-sounding, best-looking, most intimate performance venue in the area. 

Help Us Light Up the Shea!

Please give what you can. Donations at any level will help. If you can give more, we have some nice perks available. Mostly, though, you will have the satisfaction of helping to make the Shea Theater a fantastic place for the arts in our community.

story:
The Lightbulb Moment

Chamber Arts House, Berkeley, CA, one night in July 2015:

Adina had just finished singing a famous aria that is sung by the character of Laetitia from The Old Maid and the Thief: "Steal me, sweet thief"

She sat down next to Rachel on the stairs.

"I love that opera!  I sang the role of Miss Todd in college," said Rachel.

"I've never sung the whole role of Laetitia," replied Adina.

In a flash of inspiration, these two Bay Area singers locked eyes and a simultaneous thought burst out of their mouths "We should do that opera together!"

You see, the life of a singer in any community is very often dictated by variables outside of their control.  And, at that moment, Rachel and Adina decided to take control and bring "The Old Maid and the Thief" alive through their own grit, legwork, stamina, and of course, talent.

So they decided to start their own company, The Opera Lounge.

Why call ourselves “The Opera Lounge”? Well, both Adina and Rachel recognize that the opera art form is due for a revolution.  Non-opera fans have an impression about opera, that it is stuffy, expensive, un-relatable, and an art form for the elite.

The Opera Lounge is dedicated to mounting performances in comfortable, non-traditional venues where an audience, be they opera novices or established fans, can witness a professional level opera experience in a very casual setting.

Dedicated to the talent rich musical community of the SF Bay Area, The Opera Lounge looks to provide opportunities for professional performers.  Musicians know that the SF Bay Area always needs a new opera company to serve their community.

We ask for your help with a donation.  Please help two singers who aim to provide their voices and their operational talents to a new opera venture in the SF Bay Area.  Let us show you what we love!

We invite you to come into our “living room,” lounge around and experience our very first production, Gian Carlo Menotti’s “The Old Maid and the Thief” in May 2016.

What We Need & What You Get

  • The Opera Lounge is funding 100% of this project themselves.  What ever monies are raised go 100% towards compensating all of the music professionals who have committed themselves to this project.
  • In addition to stipends, there are other costs: stage set and design, performance license fees, props, costumes, etc.
  • Any leftover monies will be saved for future productions by The Opera Lounge.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Please help us get the word out! Share our campaign with your contacts on Facebook, Twitter and LinkedIn
  • Be sure to use the easy Indiegogo share tools!
  • Volunteer!  Want to help?  We can put you to work.  Contact us at omattsf@gmail.com to find out how.
  • Come see the production!  Tickets sold through Eventbrite: http://tinyurl.com/theoperalounge

story:
Short Summary

#nofilter is a cross artform production largely focused on mental illness and includes topics such as suicide,  self harm, bulimia, dissociative identity disorder, post traumatic stress disorder, addiction and abuse. #nofilter had it's World premiere at the 2016 Adelaide Fringe Festival which was an acclaimed a sold out success. 

Never in our wildest dreams could we have ever imagined the impact this show would have on its audience nor how important it's message would be. We knew what it meant to us as a cast as the entire production was based on true events and the struggles we face and continue to fight on a day to day basis. (Im so proud of the cast for sharing this and baring themselves)  

We are amazingly fortunate to have been invited to showcase #nofilter in the Festival d'Avignon this July, in Avignon; France. Our home will become the Garage International based at the Hotel Mecure Pont d'Avignon. The festival is the largest contemporary arts festival in the world and is in its 70th year. However we need to start fundraising in order to get the cast there. We need your help to take the first step towards touring this show around the world and continuing to show how important supporting mental health awareness is. 

Together we can achieve this goal. 

#followyourdreams

 

 What We Need 

Passports,Flights,Accommodation...... OH MY !

Flights... We have a cast and crew of 13. We need approximately $24,700.00 to get everybody there.

Accommodation for our 15 show season, which doubles as storage for our sets and props. $3000

  • If we don't reach our desired goal (which we will, by launching only positive rockets) we will put the money towards our original goal of touring the production through regional South Australia, Australia and future international touring. 
  • Velvet Chase Productions has already pitched the idea to the South Australian Government Minister for the Arts and Mental Health, with a view to make #nofilter age appropriate for Australian schools; which was received with great anticipation.
#somuchroomforgrowth

The Impact

Already in our short run at the 2016 Adelaide Fringe we appear to have had an impact on many of those who shared the experience of #nofilter. 

BroadwayWorld.com Review - Barry Lenny 

"#NOFILTER Is One Of The Most Incredible Pieces That You Will Ever See" and "It should definitely tour to other festivals and have productions mounted in all capital cities and major population centres, with governments and departments dealing with mental health getting behind it to ensure that this happens. I see no reason why this should not tour overseas and, in fact, it should.". 

Review by Adelaide Fringe Photographer - Trentino Priori 

"Tonight's performance of No Filter was no less than a five stars with heart wrenching scenes that left me in tears, what a cast, what a show and amazing music score "#nofilter sadly you have missed it at this years ADELAIDE FRINGE"   

Here are a few reviews from the fringe goer review site TalkFringe.

"This show has everything, singing, dance, short film, acting and spine tingling music and performances. You really feel you get a look deep within the minds of each character. Impossible to walk out at the end of this without feeling you’ve experienced your own feelings unfiltered." - Rowan G.

"Absolutely loved #nofilter. It was not just a show but more like an experience you felt a part of. I smiled and also shed tears though the performance whilst relating to different scenes. I was taken back by the pure talent and emotion shown by the performers. Definitely recommend this show to all especially anyone interested in mental health. This show is dark, confronting, emotional, mesmerizing, tear jerking and so much more. Do yourself a favour and do not miss this show." - Sonya H.

"An amazing local Adelaide show around mental illness. It's raw and confronting and gets everyone talking, which is what needs to happen more in today’s society. It isn’t just a show; it’s an experience with different forms of performance utilising the whole space. Many shed tears with the issues that were touched on. The performers were amazing. And the song choices were astounding. They have just put on 2 encore shows this weekend and i'm seriously considering attending for a second time. Not enough can be said, nor enough praise given for this intimate, thought provoking piece." - DK H.

We were also amazed by the many private messages/emails Velvet Chase Productions have received from people expressing how deeply this show affected them. 

#truelyhumbled

Risks & Challenges

With taking our show to France we face a few risks and challenges. However we also have solutions for your risks to minimise them and to fix the challenges.  

Language Barriers - No one in the cast speaks French and we need to promote the show.

Cutting a 90min show down to 50mins and adjusting it to suit the cast that are going.

Finding accommodation for 13 people and props (can't store props at the theatre) 

10min bump in and set up time (we are used to a generous 5 hour bump in)

 "Je M'appelle Dannielle "  This very day, Saturday the 26th of March, some of the cast and crew met up with one of the local French groups that meet every week for brunch. This will be our new family for the next few months, anyone who speaks French is welcome to join the group on Saturdays from 9.30am onwards @MyFriendLouis. #nofilter has no dialogue and is performed to a beautiful music score which in turn makes it universal and able to break through those language barriers. 

The beauty of #nofilter is that it contains all these beautiful little stories that can be told alone or together - the show has been designed to be able to perform it from a 15min show to a 90min full scale production. 

As there is such a large group of us we would be looking at sharing a villa about a 30min train ride out of Avignon But with Storage and no preparation room at the venue this was seeming to be a hurdle we couldn't jump until one of our amazing tec guys suggested we hire a small room in the hotel that is home to Garage International ( this will become our props and change room area )  

As for 10min bump in, we have cleverly come up with an idea of setting up the stage as part of our first routine allowing us more time for bump in. 

#wecanovercomeanything 

Other Ways You Can Help

We will also be running a variety of fundraisers which you can keep up to date on with our new facebook page. 

We understand that not everyone can afford to donate but you can still help. Please share this campaign with your friends and start a conversation about the impact of mental illness and how important acceptance and support is. 

#everylittlebithelps #pleaseshare 

 

All photographs by ModernFlesh Photography

story:
Making Oxford a Better Place for Theatre

Oxford has a lot of great theatre but, for the most part, it either comes from am-dram groups or touring companies. Here's :a few way in which we hope to help with this situation and how your pledges can make this possible:

  • We intend to ensure that our actors are fairly rewarded for the work they do for us. Whenever possible this is done through giving 60-70% of our profits from productions to the cast.
  • Making theatre more accessible to the public. This covers everything from taking our shows to people that don't normally have the chance to go to the theatre, to making difficult texts, like Shakespeare, easier for people to follow and understand.
  • We always promise to provide our audiences with the highest quality or production that our means will allow.
  • We cast our actors based on talent alone. We don't care about experience or degrees. If we feel that you're right for the part then it's yours.

What We Need & What You Get

  • We're asking for just £1000 to add to the money we've raised over the last 3 years so that we can put on this production of Romeo and Juliet without taking out a loan.
  • By pledging you will be helping the arts in Oxford. If companies like our can continue to opperate and pay our actors then the quality of theatre in the county will increase.
  • If we don't reach our goal we will take the funds that we do have and make them work as best as possible.
  • If we excede our goal then it means we can do even more with the production than we originally thought possible.

The Impact

  • We train our actors as we go. With this show we're offering free classes for our cast.
  • We've had actors move on to attend RADA, LAMDA, Bristol Old Vic and Central School of Speech and Drama.
  • This is a company run by actors. As such, we have more interest in producing quality theatre than in making loads of money.

Risks & Challenges

Every show comes with risks and challenges here are some that we face 

  • Putting on a show is not cheap. To do a show in Oxford it will cost at least £2000 in marketing alone.
  • It's difficult to get investors because there's no assurance of a return. If there's no audience then there's no money. It doesn't matter how good the production is.
  • Doing a show that everyone knows can be tough, as you'll need to bring something new to it, but keep it familiar.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Get the word out and make some noise about us and our campaign.
  • Our website is www.donthatetheplayers.co.uk and you can find all of our social media tabs there.
  • If you saw our last show then why not write a review. Or share the ones we already have http://www.dailyinfo.co.uk/event/168177/The_Tam...

Thanks for taking the time to read this.

story:
Hola,

soy Iván, tengo 18 años, y como ha de ser a esta edad, estoy lleno de ilusión por conseguir las tantas expectativas que uno se plantea alcanzar para cuando empieza a trazar lo que será su vida. Casi inesperadamente, me he encontrado con una gran oportunidad que permite que esta ilusión siga creciendo.  Se trata de la gran suerte que he tenido de ser seleccionado para estudiar en P.A.R.T.S, considerada internacionalmente una de las mejores escuelas de danza contemporánea.


Hello,

my name is Iván, I am eighteen years old, and, like it has to be at my age, I am excited to make true all the wishes I´ve had when I was wondering what would I do in my life. And now I have the great opportunity to study at P.A.R.T.S. to make them true.



Sobre mí / about me

Llevo varios años estudiando en el Conservatorio Profesional de Danza del Institut del Teatre, y aunque disfruto con muchas otras cosas, el baile es a lo que le he dedicado más tiempo estos últimos años. No diré que quería ser bailarín desde pequeño, pero siempre me gustó bailar, así como cantar y tocar cazuelas con un par de baquetas, hacer el payaso, dibujar, hacer películas... 

Las artes siempre me han gustado, pero también el deporte, cosa que puede haber condicionado que me haya decantado por la danza. Sin embargo no es todo lo que quiero hacer ni lo único que hago. De hecho llevo más tiempo estudiando la batería, y aunque sea por mi cuenta, no voy a dejar de hacerlo. Soy alguien con muchas pasiones y mi intención es vivir con todas ellas, hacer que se nutran entre sí, combinarlas, fusionarlas y hacerlas aparecer en escena; y por esta razón P.A.R.T.S. es uno de los mejores lugares a los que podría ir, no solo por el nivel técnico en cuanto a la danza, sino por la formación completa que ofrece, en la que se trabaja también el teatro y la música para formar a intérpretes que realmente dominen el arte de la escena.


I´ve been several years studying at the Conservatory of Dance of Institut del Teatre, and although I enjoy doing many other things, the last years I've spent most of the time dancing. I will not say I wanted to be a dancer since childhood, but I always liked to dance, sing and play pots with a pair of drumsticks, clowning, drawing, making movies...

The arts have always liked me, but also sport, which could had conditioned me to opt for dance. However, it is not all I want to do and the only thing I do. I am someone with many passions and I intend to live with them all, make nurture each other, combine them and fusion them on stage; and for this reason P.A.R.T.S. is one of the best places I could go, not only for the technical level in terms of dance, but for the complete training offered, in which theater and music take place to develop performers who really dominate art scene.



Sobre / about  P.A.R.T.S.

P.A.R.T.S. (Performing Arts Research and Training Studios) es una escuela de danza contemporánea fundada por Anna Teresa De Keersmaeker que proporciona una formación técnica y completa para que bailarines y coreógrafos puedan convertirse en artistas independientes y creativos.

Se trabaja con más de 50 profesionales de alrededor del mundo en intensivos técnicos o creativos que suelen durar un mes; se imparten clases de teatro, canto y teoría musical, así como de shiatsu, yoga, pilates, y danza clásica como entrenamiento físico; y hay clases teóricas de anatomía, historia de la danza, sociología y filosofía.

Para entrar tuve que pasar una preselección realizada en 21 países de todo el mundo que determinó quienes seríamos los 180 que iríamos a Bruselas a hacer la audición final durante una semana entera. Allí eligieron a los 44 alumnos que representaremos a la escuela durante los tres próximos cursos, pues trabajan con un único grupo durante el proceso de la formación; cosa que complica aún más formar parte de la escuela, por su única audición cada tres años, su larga duración y la abundante participación que esto conlleva.

Más información en http://www.parts.be/.


P.A.R.T.S. (Performing Arts Research and Training Studios) is a school of contemporary dance founded by Anna Teresa De Keersmaeker that provides a technical and complete training for dancers and choreographers to become independent and creative artists. 

It works with more than 50 professionals from around the world in technical or creative workshops usually lasting one month; there are theater, singing and music theory classes, as well as shiatsu, yoga, pilates, and classical dance as physical training; and there are theoretical classes including bodie´s anatomy, dance history, sociology and philosophy.

To enter I had to pass a pre-selection they did in 21 countries around the world. And then I went to Brussels with 180 more people to make the one week final audition, which decided the 44 students who will represent the school for the next three courses (they work with only one group during all the training cycle, which further complicates being part of the school, becouse their only audition every three years, its long duration and the abundant participation that this entails).

More information at http://www.parts.be/.



Presupuesto / budget

La escuela no es barata, los tres cursos cuestan unos 13.450€ en total (4.500€ de matrícula + 7.500€ por los tres cursos + 450€ para las actuaciones + 1.000€ para proyectos); y vivir allí tampoco (véase el presupuesto estimado del primer curso).


The school is not cheap, the three courses cost around 13.450€ (4.500€ registration fee + 7.500€ tuition fee + 450€ performances + 1.000€ external projects); and living there neither (look at the first year´s estimated buget). 



Colaboración / collaboration

Realmente con vuestra colaboración estaréis propiciando el éxito en la importante etapa de mi profesionalización. Así que por favor, os pido que me  ayudéis a que se haga realidad esta gran aventura. Ya sea por difundir esto o por colaborar con una donación (que por pequeña que pueda parecer valdrá oro para mí si todos aportáis un poquito) os estaré enormemente agradecido.

Gracias!


With your collaboration you will be contributing the success of the important stage of my professionalization. So please, I ask you to help me in this great adventure. Whether spreading this or making a donation (which althought may seem small it will be gold for me if everyone helps a little) I will be very grateful to you.

Thank you!



Un abrazo fuerte,


Iván

story:
Help Support a Live Radio Play!

Do you love live radio plays? Do you care about the economic and artistic future of the Dawson community? Do you want to support capacity building in the dramatic arts? Do you love the Palace Grand Theatre (PG)? Do you want to see a show about the contemporary Dawson experience?  

If you said 'Yes' to any of the above questions and have just $10 to spare - we'd love your support to run our live radio show, A Klondike Cabin Companion! 

The Play 

A Klondike Cabin Companion is a LIVE radio performance comedy that follows the story of one Cheechako's trials and tribulations during his first FULL year in Dawson. Canadian indie performers Carolyn Mark and Al Simmons headline the musical interludes between radio-play acts written and performed by Dawsonites.

What is a Cheechako, you may ask? It's someone who is new to the Klondike, and who'll likely make some hilarious mistakes as they learn how to laugh and live through the four extreme seasons up here.

Inspired by A Prairie Home Companion, Garrison Keillor's live radio variety show, our cabin-centric show will play to a live audience.

A Klondike Cabin Companion will run June 24 and 25 in the restored historical ballroom at the Klondike Institute for Art and Culture (KIAC). If this pilot performance goes well, we will expand it for summer 2017 and stage it in the historical Palace Grand Theatre.

The Immediate Need 

We need 1000 amazing people to give just $10 each to this cause! Maybe you've visited Dawson City, or you've heard about the amazing number of festivals and art events that happen in our tiny town of 1500. Maybe you live here and love all the events that pack the summer arts calendar. Or perhaps you just love radio plays and independent theatre productions. Whatever your interest, we hope you'll choose to be one of the 1000.

100% of your money will go to the production of The Klondike Cabin Companion - from making costumes to printing .

As one of the 'Grand for the Grand' your support will be recognized at both of our live performances this year - June 24th and 25th. 

And of course, if you want to give more, we'll love you forever.

The Creative Community Context 

Dawson City's community theatre scene is small but growing. The Friends of the Palace Grand is a volunteer, non-profit group that formed in 2014 to strategize ways of bringing sustainable programming to the Palace Grand, our town's gorgeous theatre originally built by Arizona Charlie in 1899.

After two successful runs of the Live at the Palace Grand music and theatre series, the group thought: why not try a production that's written, produced, and performed by Dawsonites? And thus,A Klondike Cabin Companionwas born.

Your support adds to this foundation, and will build our community's capacity to create and produce the dramatic arts.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you're unable to donate, here are some other ways that you can help:

  • Share our campaign on with your friends (Indiegogo has share tools for all your social media outlets)!
  • Buy  ticket for our show (available at Maximilian's and KIAC)!
  • Volunteer (we need some volunteers to help run our concession and front of house)

If you have any questions or would like more information, please contact me (Justine) at 867-993-3075 or at producer.kcc@gmail.com. 

THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT!

story:
Summary

Violence, passion, and faith catapult 12 uniquely spirited characters on a unifying journey through the chaos of life (and death) in the City That Care Forgot.  Pure, honest, and as heart-warming as it is heart-breaking, Interludes reminds us that what's worth dying for, is also worth living for. 
"A Touchingly Soulful Experience" - San Diego Story

Interludes is a one-woman-show written and performed by Claire Christine Sargenti, with music by Darrell Smith, performed by the 8 piece Interludes Jazz Orchestra.  Claire Christine Sargenti, a professional ballet dancer working in New York City (Joffrey Ballet School, New Bridges Ballet) suffered a serious and permanent hip injury, ending her ballet career.  In January 2013, she set out on a journey to New Orleans hoping to find a new dream.  Interludes was the result.   

Interludes has been selected to perform at the New York International Fringe Festival. This is a huge honor and we are very excited to be included with the other spectacular shows that FringeNYC will be featuring this year!  Producing independent theater is a community effort, and we need your help to make our performances at FringeNYC a success!

Here's Our Budget:

Fringe Participation Fee: $700

Body Microphone: $100

Required Insurance: $125

1/2 Page Ad in Fringe Program + Fringe Website Banner: $900 

Discounted PR through Fringe: $550

     -Press Release Mailing $125

     -Postcards to Press $100

     -Postcards to Producers and Agents $100

     -Postcards to Previous Fringe Ticket Buyers $225

Interludes Jazz Orchestra: $2000 

Space Rental: $1700 

5,000 Postcards: $286.80 + $32 shipping

250 Personalized envelopes: $100 + $17 Shipping

50 Posters: $100 + $12 Shipping

Transportation: $600

Box Office Fee: $100

Stamps: $100

Required Set Fireproofing: $100 

Lighting Design: $100 

Light Technician: $100

Sound Technician: $100

$177.20 In case of emergency

Total: $8,000

The Impact

We've been working hard on making Interludes a reality for over 3 years now, and performing at the New York International Fringe Festival is a dream come true! The story Interludes tells is near and dear to my heart, and a story that needs to be shared with the world.  FringeNYC is a great platform to build our audience, as well as to meet and collaborate with other theater artists!

We've worked long and hard to get to where we are now.  Here's some of the highlights of our Interludes journey that have brought us to FringeNYC!

January 2013 - Claire Christine Sargenti moved from NYC to New Orleans with little more than a dream 

July 15, 2013 - The first Piano Man monologue is performed at Animamus Art Salon at Saleya, NYC

October 2013 - Claire Christine Sargenti workshops some of the new characters at Animamus Art Salon, A Living Gallery at Apiary Studios, London 

Thanksgiving Day 2013 - The first draft of the Interludes script is finished!

December 3, 2013 - The first workshop performance of Interludes performed at The Barrow Group, NYC with space donated by Artistic Director Lee Brock 

May 13, 2014 - Performance at The Duplex Cabaret Theater, NYC, Directed by Zillah Glory, Lighting by Joe Williamson

June 2014 - Dominique Liboiron writes about the creation of Interludes in the Prairie Post

http://www.prairiepost.com/opinion/item/6258-new-york-ballerina-shares-the-ups-and-downs-of-a-new-start.html

September 6, 2014 - Performance at Zinc Bar Jazz Club, NYC, Directed by Zillah Glory, Introducing the Interludes Jazz Band with Music by Darrell Smith

October 12, 2014 - Staged Reading at The Barrow Group, NYC, Directed by Zillah Glory, Introducing the 12 person cast of Interludes

December 3, 2014 - Private Cast Staged Reading, New Jersey, Directed by Zillah Glory

April 10, 2015 - Artist and Activist Sera Smith Interviews Claire Christine Sargenti for her blog The Deliquescent Trail Of Gold

https://deliquescenttrailofgold.wordpress.com/interviews/

July-August 2015 - Interludes has 5 performances at the San Diego International Fringe Festival at the Tenth Avenue Arts Center, Main Stage, San Diego CA - Introducing the first ever Bi-Costal Interludes Jazz Band, receiving stellar reviews 

http://www.sandiegostory.com/new-orleans-and-middle-earth-come-to-san-diego-fringe/

http://vanguardculture.com/closing-the-fringe/

http://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/news/2015/jul/16/escondido-native-brings-show-to-fringe/

August 29, 2015 - Hurricane Katrina 10th Anniversary Benefit Performance - Zinc Bar, NYC -  10% of the ticket sales donated to Rebuilding Together New Orleans

September 30, 2015 - Interludes at The Shrine, Harlem NYC - Directed by Gregory Allan Bock, Introducing the 8 Piece Interludes Jazz Orchestra 

September 2015 - Canadian, and Interludes Character Inspiration Dominique Liboiron visits NYC and reviews Interludes 

http://www.prairiepost.com/component/k2/item/8613-interludes-and-the-decision-to-see-myself-for-myself.html

December 3, 2015 - Interludes 2nd Anniversary Performance, Zinc Bar NYC, Directed by Gregory Allan Bock

April 15, 2016 - New Orleans gets it's first taste of Interludes with the Piano Man monologue as part of the In/Fringe Festival at AllWays Lounge, sparking a collaboration with the fantastic actor and playwright, and our new director Diana E.H. Shortes

Other Ways You Can Help

Sometimes you cant spare any cash.  I get it.  Iv'e been there.  If you can't donate, that's OK.  You can still help out and join the Interludes family 
  • Spread the word!  Help us meet our goal by sharing our campaign!
  • Interact with us on Facebook (www.facebook.com/nolainterludes) and Twitter (@nola_interludes)
  • Come see us at FringeNYC and bring your friends!
Thank you for all your love and support! You rock!!! 
xo Claire
www.nolainterludes.com

http://vanguardculture.com/closing-the-fringe/
http://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/news/2015/jul/16/escondido-native-brings-show-to-fringe/
August 29, 2015 - Hurricane Katrina 10th Anniversary Benefit Performance - Zinc Bar, NYC -  10% of the ticket sales donated to Rebuilding Together New Orleans
September 30, 2015 - Interludes at The Shrine, Harlem NYC - Directed by Gregory Allan Bock, Introducing the 8 Piece Interludes Jazz Orchestra 
September 2015 - Canadian, and Interludes Character Inspiration Dominique Liboiron visits NYC and reviews Interludes 
http://www.prairiepost.com/component/k2/item/8613-interludes-and-the-decision-to-see-myself-for-myself.html
December 3, 2015 - Interludes 2nd Anniversary Performance, Zinc Bar NYC, Directed by Gregory Allan Bock
April 15, 2016 - New Orleans gets it's first taste of Interludes with the Piano Man monologue as part of the In/Fringe Festival at AllWays Lounge, sparking a collaboration with the fantastic actor and playwright, and our new director Diana E.H. Shortes

    Other Ways You Can Help
Sometimes you cant spare any cash.  I get it.  Iv'e been there.  If you can't donate, that's OK.  You can still help out and join the Interludes family   Spread the word!  Help us meet our goal by sharing our campaign! Interact with us on Facebook (www.facebook.com/nolainterludes) and Twitter (@nola_interludes)

Come see us at FringeNYC and bring your friends! 
Thank you for all your love and support! You rock!!! 
xo Claire
www.nolainterludes.com

story:
Finally something new for your dance classes  Enfin du nouveau pour vos classes de dance

I have been playing for dance classes for more then 25 years. Played for important companies and schools, both in Montreal and Toronto. But I can't be everywhere at the same time, and also, not every dance teacher can afford a pianist live for their classes. I will record material for 4 classes, music by Schubert, Granados, Balakirev, Nazareth, Verdi and many others. Some musics, for jumps e.g., will be recorded at 2 different tempi, some musics will have short and long versions, for diagonals e.g. 
J'accompagne les classes de danse depuis plus de 25 ans. J'ai joué pour les compagnies et les écoles les plus prestigieuses, tant à Montréal qu'à Toronto. Mais je n'ai malheureusement pas le don d'ubiquité. Sans compter que plusieurs professeurs de danse ne peuvent pas se payer de musicien. J'enregistrerai 4 classes complètes, sur des musique de Schubert, Granados, Balakirev, Nazareth et combien d'autres. Certaines pièces, pour les sauts par exemple, seront enregistrée sur 2 tempi différents, d'autres, pour les diagonales, auront des version courtes et des version longues. 

This is a pre-sale 

Ceci est une pré-vente

We both know you need new music! In order to make the recording, I need to pay for a technician and a studio. This will be a professional quality recording, on a grand piano. The type of recording you will enjoy listening for a long time! The first 2 CDs will be launched in October, online only, and the #3 and #4, in January 2017. Be the first to get these music. Get all of them right away on September 1st.

10$ : 1 class, 20$ : 2 classes, 30$ : 3 classes, 40$ : 4 classes, 

more$ : 4 classes plus my eternal gratitude.

Vous mourrez d'envie d'avoir du nouveau matériel pour vos classes de danse. Quant à moi, j'ai besoin de payer un technicien et un studio. Parce que l'enregistrement sera de qualité professionnelle, sur un piano de concert. Je veux que vous chérissiez ces musiques.  Les 2 premiers CD seront disponible en ligne en octobre, et les 3è et 4è CD en Janvier 2017. Soyez les premiers à avoir accès à toute cette musique dès le 1er septembre

10$ : 1 classe,, 20$ : 2 classes, 30$ : 3 classes, 40$ : 4 classes

pour tout montant additionnel : 4 classes et mon éternelle reconnaissance.


It is cheaper to buy 4 classes then to have me playing for your class.  

Pour un peu moins que mes honoraires d'une classes, vous aurez la musique de 4 classes différentes. Et ce pour toujours!


It's a small world 
En danse, tout le monde se connait
I know you want to be special and unique, but don't over play it and share this information to all of your colleagues. You know people all around the world, and both music and dance are an international language. Share the word, spread the news. Let's make of this a huge success!

Je comprendrais que vous voudriez garder cette nouvelle pour vous, mais ne soyez pas chiches, parlez-en à la planète danse. Vous connaissez des danseurs, des professeurs de danse de partout, partagez l'informations et la campagne de pré-vente. Faisons tous ensemble un immense succès de ces enregistrements.

story:
Watch the Full Indiegogo Video for even MORE info!

 

Dreams of Wrestling...

My name is Ashley Lauren Rogers and I'm a New York City-based playwright, stand-up comic, and trans rights advocate... But ever since I was 12 I wanted to be a professional wrestler.  I idolized the likes of The 1-2-3 Kid, Chris Jericho, Kane, and later Rob Van Dam... So why didn't I become a wrestler?  Back in the '90s it didn't feel like it was a viable option for work... And also I'm trans, so I didn't know whether I'd be welcomed.  So I focused elsewhere.  I focused on a career that was tangentially related to the "Sports Entertainment," I loved... I turned to theatre.   

I put my dreams of wrestling to the side.  Focused on dramatic storytelling, absurdist comedy, and using art as a form of both self reflection and of resistance.  I've performed and had my work produced in New York City, New Jersey, Wisconsin, Detroit, Cincinnati, Minneappolis and Miami to name a few.  I've been featured as an expert on Revry.TV as well as Fusion TV's Sex.Right.Now... But I've never forgotten that love of wrestling.

It is because of that that I want to create a hybrid of the medium I love and the medium I work with.  I want to create the atmosphere and story-telling of a professional wrestling Pay Per View event but utilizing fight choreography, acro-basing gymnastics, and technology to create a piece of action packed, highly theatrical performance art with a queer bent. 

With this I give you: SCOWL: Fight For Your Right! 

So is SCOWL Pro Wrestling?

NO...

But it is a choreographed piece of theatre which uses video packages, monologue and dialogue, and choreography to create a narrative much in the way that a wrestling Pay Per View is structured.  It's very similar to the Netflix series GLOW, or Pulitzer Prize Nominated play The Elaborate Entrance of Chad Deity.   

(Image by John N. Collins)

What We Need & What You Get

We are asking for $6,000.  We want to pay for:

  • Skilled Actors
  • Production Design
  • Stage Combat Coordinator Nathan Oesterle
  • Indie Wrestling Consultant Paola J Gonzalez
  • Rehearsal Spaces
  • Insurance
  • Marketing
  • GLOOOOOORIOUS Costumes!

If we don't make our goals don't fret, SCOWL: Fight For Your Rights will still be coming the The Brick in July however Rehearsal space will be limited and costumes will be whatever we have in our closets.

(Image by John N. Collins)
 

Cast 

Rachel Weekly is a street theater mime, with an affinity for fights and Shakespeare

Gabriel Spector is an interdisciplinary performer and performance maker who has been told by 5 people that they thought he was their imaginary friend

Jesse Rose Krebs Jesse Rose Krebs is a queer circus artist fighting for the right of every body's validity on stage.

Sylas Barrett is a sci fi writer, and NYC-based actor.

Gladys Hendricks is a Meisner-trained actor with a passion for Shakespeare and newfound love if pro wrestling.

Ashley Lauren Rogers is a trans rights advocate, a stand up comic, playwright, 

Risks & Challenges

Share what qualifies you to overcome these hurdles.  Describe your plan for solving these challenges.

Ashley is trained in stage combat, first being trained in college and sharpening her skills in New York City.  Most recently using such skills in Cage Theatre's Swordfight Christmas, Step 1 Theatre's production of The Vengeance Room, and when she and good friend Rachel performed a one off "Match," at Detroit's Motor City Steam Con one year ago.  

David Charles is an established new works director in New York City with a passion for subversive art, and is proud associate member of the Stage Directors and Choreographers Society.

Nathan Oesterle's experience as a fight choreographer speaks for itself on his website.

P.J "The Whip" Gonzalez has experience in both the Indy Wrestling world as well as Stage Combat and stage Choreography.

Production design is by Devon James; a New York native director, actor and designer currently with the Off Broadway hit Puffs. Previous credits include No Exit, Bare the Pop Opera (York theater), Urinetown (St. Bart’s).

(Image by John N. Collins)

Other Ways You Can Help

If you have a platform (Something as large as a podcast, youtube show, or blog or even something smaller like a facebook, twitter, or tumblr page) consider one of us to be a guest or simply share this with your network!  Just be sure to tag us!  @SCOWLFight on Twitter and Instagram!
