story:
The Basics

What: Waitlisted is an evening of concert dance produced by three artists at the beginning of their choreographic careers, and in the middle of navigating their identities in our current sociopolitical climate.

Who: Lydia Feuerhelm, Chloe Grace Michels, and Andy Slavin

When: November 16th + 17th, 2018

Where: Dovetail Studios, Francisco St and Montrose Ave, Chicago, IL

 

The Work

Made of Static

By Lydia Feuerhelm 

Made of Static is an extended examination of viewership, identity, and choice: how does our place in the world (or in the room) define what we believe about others, about ourselves? Part immersive performance, part collaboration with the audience, Made of Static situates viewers in the middle of inquiry by stationing them throughout the performance space in places both convenient and strange. Considering notions of “Placemaking,” this work sees the performance landscape as integral, a place for audience and performer to meet. By inhabiting this world, viewers are asked to negotiate personal choice and prescribed direction as they move throughout the work. In this way, place is used as mechanism to shape viewing lens, effect emotional state, and impact viewing response. On “stage,” dancers negotiate the vulnerability of being seen as individuals and as a unit, embodying states of togetherness and individuality, while navigating the physical landscape of the audience, asking, “where are the boundaries between individual personhood and associated identity?”

 

BIG GIRL PANTIES

By Chloe Grace Michels

BIG GIRL PANTIES is a solo performance that responds to the socially appointed notions of “proper” physique in western dance forms. Drawing on 20+ years of ballet and modern training, the performer, whose body lies outside of this spectrum, confronts our field’s confinements and overall size-ist attitudes in relation to physicality. In this piece, the depths of fatigue as it parallels the body’s threshold for both cardiovascular and muscular endurance is tested, challenging the stigmas associated with physical fitness and its socially constructed symbiotic relationship with the body’s physique. BIG GIRL PANTIES questions the validity of size determining  “fit”ness, ultimately asking the audience to decide who is worthy of taking the stage.

 

BreakingTime (excerpt)

By Andy Slavin

In BreakingTime, we do not lose. We do not tie. We do not crack or falter. If we fall, we fall harder than you, cracking our bones, and bruising big. We do not hurt. We get back up. We do it fast and hard. We make the shot. We stay 100.


BreakingTime is an evening length dance work performed by six women on a basketball court. It explores the attempt to beat exhaustion as an act of hyper masculinity, and the resulting fallout when exhaustion wins. Through the art of practice, scrimmage, and gameplay, its players are asked to not portray, but prove they are the best. The game is complicated by the challenge of handling their game pieces (sacks of flour) weighing them down, falling apart, and caking their bodies with the evidence of their losses. Testing both the brutality and camaraderie of sports culture, BreakingTime manipulates its players into a self dependent team unraveling upon itself.

 

Who We Are

Lydia Feuerhelm:

Lydia Feuerhelm is a Chicago-based movement artist interested in the intersection of viewership, physical expression, and experimental performance. Her interests lie in forwarding interdisciplinary art and performance and creating communities centered on artistic practices.

Since moving to Chicago in 2011, she has performed with a number of Chicago-based artists including Timothy Buckley, Margi Cole, Colleen Halloran, and Emily Stein. In 2014, Feuerhelm co-founded the performance collective The Coincidentals and has since produced a number of dance events and experimental performances ranging from traditional proscenium dance concerts to house parties with sporadic performances. Her work has been chosen for a number of performances including: American College Dance Association, Manifest Urban Arts Festival, Dance for $9.99, and Dance Shelter. She graduated with honors from Columbia College Chicago in 2014 with a Bachelor’s degree in Dance.

Chloe Grace Michels: 

Chloe Grace Michels graduated with a BFA in Dance from Columbia College Chicago in May 2015. Upon graduating she has worked with choreographers Timothy Buckley, Margi Cole (The Dance Colective), Paige Cunningham (Off Center Project), Fred Darsow, Emma Draves, Emily Stein and Karl Watson. In the fall of 2017, Michels restaged works by Fred Darsow and Timothy Buckley on students at the University of Texas Rio Grande Valley and Columbia College Chicago respectively. She has created work for The Coincidentals' Mess Hall installment #1 and #2 and LiRa Dance Theater. Michels is honored to premiere a new work alongside two of her nearest and dearest dancing buds. 

Andy Slavin: 

Andy Slavin received their BFA in Dance from Columbia College Chicago in 2016. They have presented choreographic work at Salonathon, Rebirth Gallery, Outerspace, The Fly Honey Show, The Grelley Duvall Show, The Den, Manifest Arts Festival, and Prp Thtr through an American Theater Company Core Residency. They have worked with choreographers Emma Draves, Kristina Isabelle, Atalee Judy, Erin Kilmurray, Darling Shear, and Karen Yatsko among others in addition to collaborating with theater collective Hot Kitchen and director Dani Wieder. Andy is currently preparing to present their evening length dance work, BreakingTime, in early 2019, as well as stilt walking with Kristina Isabelle Dance Company and teaching dance to toddlers in association with Chicago Moving Company.

With Your Help

Waitlisted is seeking $4000 to assist in funding production costs. As emerging artists we appreciate your support in getting our feet off the ground as we continue to establish ourselves as makers in the Chicago dance community. As we enter this collaborative process, we appreciate you in aiding our efforts in both producing this event and compensating our movers/designers.

With your help, we'll be able to accomplish the following:

  • Designing and Creating Costumes for 12 Dancers
  • Hiring Lighting Designer and Additional Technical Staff/Equipment Rental
  • Venue and Rehearsal Space Rental
  • Creating and Printing Marketing Materials/Programs
  • Compensating Dancers for their Work
  • Performance Documentation for Archival and Sharing Purposes (Videography/Photography)
  • Assistance in the Evening Length Production of BreakingTime in February 2019

Purpose

For most, we understand what we can see. By embedding our research in a physical exploration, we can engage our viewers' in conversations through imagery, effort, shape, and sound, inviting a multi-sensory experience. Each of these works serve a direct line of inquiry. Do our bodies have value? How does language limit others' perceptions of ourselves? How do the spaces we choose to occupy reflect our needs to identify? To prove our right to hold those spaces? To provide us comfort in our belonging? We invite you to join us as we enter these studies of self both in and out of the studio.

Putting A Bow On It

Thank you. Thank you in advance, and thank you for now. Thank you for your financial backing. Thank you to our community for its mentorship, propulsion, and support. 

We are so grateful.

Share. Engage. Attend.

We'll see you in November

story:
Dance Place is raising money for the 2018 Art on 8th community programming season and our 8th St Arts Park! Created after an 18-month community engaged design process in 2016, we’re proud that our park transformed asphalt into art!

 

What better way to underwrite the 100% free cultural programming on the park this spring and summer than by reaching out to our community for support. Please consider making a donation that supports performances, garden club, classes, games and arts workshops on the 8th St Arts Park and Monroe St Market Stage.

 

Check out this video showing the transformation of the 8th St Arts Park!

 

Thanks to our current Art on 8th sponsors Monroe St Market and Long & Foster!

story:
Short Summary

My name is Saya Baker, I am a 20 year old Pilates Instructor, Reiki Practitioner, and artist/dancer based in NYC. I have been dancing for 15  years, and I have recently begun choreographing to perform. 

I am building this campaign to grow funds for my new dance piece "If Her Eyes Could Talk". The piece is about my life, the trauma I have experienced up until this point, and the subconscious narrative and conversations created because of it. This work is extremely close to my heart, and I get to make my vision come to life. 

What We Need 

I need to raise at least  $2,000!

What this pays for:

  • Rehearsal Space ($200+)
  • Theater Rental ($1,000)
  • Musician stipend ($150+)
  • Dancers stipend ($100+)
  • Production Manager/Lighting Designer ($225+) 
  • Costumes ($250+)
  • Accessories ($75 - 100)

If the entire goal of $2,000 is not reached, the funds will immediately go to theater rental. 

The Impact

"If Her Eyes Could Talk" is a piece that speaks to hundreds of thousands of people all over the world. The trauma that we experience as children has a direct effect on the person we grow up to be. Every relationship that we build, the way we communicate, the way we see the world, and the way we see ourselves is shaped by our history. In my case - and I'm sure many others - I grew into only resentment, bitterness, and pain. I felt that the world was against me, and that every relationship I built - intimate or not - would result in the same pain I felt as a child.

And sure enough, it did.  

I manifested my past into my present and continued to experience traumatic event, after traumatic event. It became too much. All I wanted was to feel peace, and joy. It didn't feel possible up until this past August. 

I want to share my life, and my vision with people, to show them that they are not alone.  

Risks & Challenges

Creating a piece and performing it in 2 months is difficult process. For example, finding dancers that are available on all rehearsal dates, finding affordable rehearsal space, stage and lighting design could not happen if sufficient funds are not generated, etc. 

This piece gets to be shared with the world, and although it may be challenging, I am committed to having it happen no matter what. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to support financially, don't let that stop you from supporting another way!

Spread this campaign around, use the Indiegogo share tools, show up to the performance, MAKE SOME NOISE!  

 

Thank you for the love, 

 

Saya

story:
This January, we're throwing caution to the wind in an immersive, one-of-a-kind rendition of Shakespeare's Twelfth Night, where the play itself erupts out of a Twelfth Night Party inspired by Elizabethan tradition -- live music, refreshment, games, and other performances begin at 6:30pm for VIP ticket holders, culminating in the cutting of a Twelfth Night Cake just before the performance. In the cake are hidden a dried bean and a dried pea; one audience member will cut the cake into slices and give them to the actors. Whichever actor discovers the dried bean will play the Duke Orsino in that evening’s performance, and whichever actor discovers the dried pea will play the Countess Olivia.

Now, now the mirth comes,
With the cake full of plums,
Where Bean’s the king of the sport here;
Besides we must know,
The pea also
Must revel, as queen, in the court here.

Begin then to choose,
This night as ye use,
Who shall for the present delight here,
Be a king by the lot,
And who shall not
Be Twelfth-day queen for the night here.

– Robert Herrick, "Twelfe Night"

Twelfth Night is one of Shakespeare’s most beloved comedies, where a lovable cast of misfits are thrust into chaos through love, lust, and loss. In this play where “nothing that is so, is so,” assumptions and aspirations about identity are flipped on their heads as the “whirligig of time brings in his revenges.” Swapping through roles in the rehearsal process, we've already discovering so many new moments in this classic story and have been incredibly inspired by watching each actor bring their unique take to each character, and we can't wait to share it with residents and visitors to the vibrant Queens arts scene.

The production is led by actor-manager Montgomery Sutton (Twelfth Night at Shakespeare’s Globe; Much Ado About Nothing with Rude Grooms) is produced in partnership with Long Island City Artists at the Plaxall Gallery (5-25 46th Avenue, LIC)and sponsored by Mikkeller Brewing NYC. Performances begin at 7:30pm with a Twelfth Night Party beginning at 6:30pm each night for VIP ticket holders featuring a variety of musical guests to be announced.

Please Note:

Donations on IndieGoGo are not tax-deductible. You may make a tax-deductible donation on Fractured Atlas: Rude Grooms is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Rude Grooms must be made payable to Fractured Atlas only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.​

When making a donation, make sure to enter a whole number without a decimal point (i.e., 35 rather than 35.00) -- contributors have reported issues with decimal points when backing the project. If you have any questions or issues, please reach out to us directly and we'll figure it out.

 

What We Need & What You Get

As an experiment in translating the Elizabethan theatre troupe model intro 21st Century Startup vernacular, our Patrons are of especially significant importance to us. With as small a donation as $25, you'll get priority access to all of our events -- including events not available to the general public (like our Secret Shakespeare Hunt, which guests have called "by far THE COOLEST THING I'VE EVER DONE IN New York City").

Because this is an extremely limited-run and we are committed to keeping our "Groundling" admission accessible at $10, even sold out performances can't fully cover our costs -- by supporting us, you'll be a fundamental part of bringing these performances to Queens at prices residents can actually afford.

This production also celebrates 6 months of producing plays in non-traditional venues throughout Queens, Brooklyn, and Manhattan and our third production produced in partnership with the amazing Long Island City Artists at the Plaxall Gallery, and so we're going big with the crowdfunding campaign to celebrate: we need 12 supporters to give $12 each day for the 12 days leading up to Twelfth Night to help not only this production but to jump-start our programming for all of 2019.

Each day, we will give away a raffle prize as an additional perk to one of that day's donors drawn at random. We'll announce each day's special item item in the morning -- if you contribute on multiple days, you could win more than once!

DAILY SPECIAL PRIZES (announced each morning)
EXTENDED DAY 1 (12/25-26): 3-Month Stickwork Subscription (Jan-March, Feb-April, or March-May)
DAY 2 (12/27): $100 gift certificate for Astoria Video Auditions (www.astoriavideoauditions.com)
DAY 3 (12/28): Private Yoga Session with Deb Radloff
DAY 4 (12/29): It's #MerchDay! A package including the following: 1 Twelfth Night mug, 1 Rude Grooms water bottle, 1 Rude Grooms handkerchief (choose red or blue), 1 Rude Grooms sticker, 1 book from our stock (choose from "The Millionaire and the Bard," "How to Keep a Boy from Kissing You," "Much Ado About Nothing," "Worlds Elsewhere," "The Year of Lear," or "License to Quill"). Domestic shipping is included! (International shipping is also possible -- we'll split the cost with you)
DAY 5 (12/30): 2 tickets to New York Shakespeare Company's Macbeth + a signed poster

And if we meet our goal -- an average of 12 donations a day of at least $12 for the 12 days leading up to Twelfth Night -- then we will bring together members of our company and guest artists to record an audio play of Twelfth Night which we will send to all backers!

Here is exactly where the money will go:

$1,200 - Stipends for Artists and Staff
$1,200 - Rehearsal expenses (rehearsal room rental, printing, etc.)
$750 - Costumes & Props
$625 - Insurance & General Admin
$500 - Publicity & Marketing

In addition to joining our extended family, the following contributions will get you unique perks:

$12 - Upstart Crow - a personalized Twelfth Night Meme in thanks for your contribution and an entry in that day's raffle.

$25 - Patron - all of the above, plus Patron Benefits through the end of 2019, including exclusive access to Patron readings and events and 10% off Reserved/VIP seats to public performances.

$175 - Muse of Fire - all of the above plus a "Master of the Fest" ticket to the performance of your choice (only January 4 and January 5 are still available!), a VIP ticket for you companion, a commemorative mug for both of you -- (1 down, 2 to go!)

$500 (only available on IndieGoGo) - Make the Welkin Dance - all of the above plus our Master of the Revels (Montgomery Sutton) will cook a Twelfth Night cake and lead you and a select group of friends through your own Twelfth Night inspired party!

$3,000 ($4,000 value) - The Food of Love - a private performance of Twelfth Night at your home or the venue of your choice (transportation not included; the cast for your private performance is subject to change, pending actor availability) -- only 2 available at the reduced rate

Even if we don't meet our goal, this production is coming to Long Island City January 4th, 5th, and 6th. Groundling admission starts at just $10 at bit.ly/TwelfthNight2019.

 

More Ways to Help

We recognize not everyone can contribute financially, but your interest and support mean the world to us -- thank you! If you can't join the project as a backer, please consider helping us in the following ways:

  • Share this campaign all over your social networks. Connect us with people in your circle who are hungry to support arts organizations
  • Come and see us, and bring your friends! We are all about the audiences -- you are the most important member of our cast! Tickets for Twelfth Night may be purchased at bit.ly/TwelfthNight2019.
  • Lend us your talents! Rude Grooms is a truly collaborative experience, and we have multiple slots for volunteers at each performance. If you'd be interested in volunteering your time for free admission to the show, please email pr@rudegrooms.com

 

Stretch Goals

If we exceed our budget through a mix of crowdfunding and ticket sales, here's how that money will be utilized:

$0-$1,200 - Artist Stipends & production elements - the first $1,200 above our barebones budget will go to doubling all artist stipends evenly across the board.

$1,200-$2,000 - Additional PR and Marketing - more targeted online advertising, printing posters to put up near performance venues, etc.

$2,000+ - Hiring Additional Staff - bringing on additional front of house staff and assistants to support the production

story:
Hi! Here’s the story. 

BFF is a dark, comedic full-length play written by 17-year-old Zoe Nelms in the hopes of having it performed by her high school drama department. 

But, before that happened, BFF was accepted into the New York Theater Festival’s 2019 Winterfest! 

We found some amazing actors, rehearsed like crazy, and had a great run at Winterfest (yep, that was a standing ovation you heard on closing night).

Now, we're going to make it happen Off-Broadway. 

And that ain’t cheap.

Our goal is to launch a six-week run of BFF with the hopes of continuing on the heels of a successful debut.

This is a monster opportunity for an up-and-coming playwright (one of the youngest in Off-Broadway history!). We hope you’ll join our team and help us get BFF to Off-Broadway.

What We Need

We need to raise $20,000.

Where does the moolah go?

Straight to making BFF happen. This is a six-week production (at least) which means plenty of expenses:

Cast and Crew – We have some seriously talented people working with us. Brilliant actors, visionary designers, superhuman technicians, an incredible director, heck, even our PA’s are impressive.

Rehearsal Space – Excellent performances start with tons of rehearsal. So, there’s going to be plenty of it. And that means lots of rehearsal space.

Wardrobe – An integral part of the BFF experience, wardrobe can be its own critical storytelling element. Isn’t that right, Mrs. Maisel? 

Marketing and PR – We’re going to have a fantastic production but we’ve got to spread the word if we’re going to fill theater seats. That means getting reviews, making ads, creating buzz, and reaching as many theater lovers as possible. Luckily, we happen to have a few experienced marketing pros helping us out.

Theater Rental – This is where the magic happens, but we still have to pay the rent.

And we’ve got perks! Lots of them. Fun, unique, exclusive BFF-related tchatchkes and experiences. Every donation gets you some sweet swag and helps us reach our goal of getting BFF to Off-Broadway.

Join us!

story:
Yes, this is a campaign to fund a arts management position!  But it's sooooo important -

Sure, in a perfect would this would be a funded position... that was the original plan! But due to a combination of factors (including some unexpected budget and space issues) the planned hiring of Paula Marchiel had to be put on hold. 

Look, if it weren't for the fact that there's a baby on the way, this might just be a momentary blip on one company's journey. And truth be told, in spite of not being able to hire Paula, Ann and Manuel have committed themselves to following through on their beautiful and very ambitious plans for 2018. 

But why should it be like this?

For her part, Paula would do this work for free... if she could. But she can't. This is an enormous undertaking, and Paula has the skills, the temperament (which is amazing) and the desire. Her presence would be a tremendous support to the artists of the 2018 retreat, so for the sake of everyone involved...

Let's get her there!    

Those of us who work in the theater all know how unforgiving it can be when comes to family life. We all want it to change. We all want it to be kinder, to be more humane, to be more supportive of those of us who spend our lives in an art form that claims to be dedicated to making the world a kinder, more humane, more supportive place for us all. We have an opportunity here to make that happen. Nearly all the pieces are in place...

Let's make it happen. Now.

story:
The Performance

SILVA is a performance exhibition piece which combines projection mapping and contemporary dance. With original music composed by Candice Ng, three dancers explore the depths of desire, power, and betrayal. Silva emphasizes on the consequences that neglect and ignorance can cause in the pursuit of innovation. Staged within the boundaries of a 15ft x 15ft set, the dancers interact with visual effects, achieved through projection mapping, which surrounds them to help carry out the narrative.

Synopsis

Terra, a gentle being, lives an empty and unfulfilling life and yearns for companionship. In desperation she turns to mystic energies to divide her soul in sacrifice for a companion, Genus. However, while her desires are met, consequences quickly catch up with her as Genus begins to have her own motives when she starts playing with these mystical energies. Vanus is brought to world and inadvertently rips Terra out of it. Bringing to tears a hopeless and responsible Genus.

The Team

SILVA is being created by a team of passionate, young, and like-minded artists from Toronto, Ontario. This production is a final year thesis for Ryerson University’s New Media Fine Arts program.

Artistic Director & Creator: Jessie Lee

Head Choreographer: Zsakira Del Col

Composer: Candice Ng

Audio Production: Julia Wittmann, Lucas Bozzo

Musicians: Brendan Rogers (cello), David Debono (piano), Erick Oliver Wawrzkiewicz (violin)

Dancers: Jenna Stover, Jessica Simmons, Madeleine Hollingshead, Sophie Kudryk, Sydney Levitt, Zsakira Del Col

Set Construction: Gabrielle Pangan, Imran Dhanani, Jessie Lee

Projection Animation: Emily Green, Ginny Sivakumar, Jessie Lee

Marketing Team: Isabella Santiago, Natalie Chuck, Tristan Sauer

Costs

Ways to Help

BACK US! SILVA is a low budget, student-funded project with unavoidable costs. Please help us bring this piece to life by contributing whatever you can!

SHARE this page and help us promote! All contributions are greatly appreciated and the more people we can reach the better.

FOLLOW us on social media! Updates, photos, videos, and more content will be shared on our Twitter, Instagram, and Facebook.

CONTACT us for more information. Questions, comments, compliments? We’d to love hear back from you! Email us: silvaproduction2017@gmail.com
story_txt: The PerformanceSILVA is a performance exhibition piece which combines projection mapping and contemporary dance. With original music composed by Candice Ng, three dancers explore the depths of desire, power, and betrayal. Silva emphasizes on the consequences that neglect and ignorance can cause in the pursuit of innovation. Staged within the boundaries of a 15ft x 15ft set, the dancers interact with visual effects, achieved through projection mapping, which surrounds them to help carry out the narrative.SynopsisTerra, a gentle being, lives an empty and unfulfilling life and yearns for companionship. In desperation she turns to mystic energies to divide her soul in sacrifice for a companion, Genus. However, while her desires are met, consequences quickly catch up with her as Genus begins to have her own motives when she starts playing with these mystical energies. Vanus is brought to world and inadvertently rips Terra out of it. Bringing to tears a hopeless and responsible Genus.The TeamSILVA is being created by a team of passionate, young, and like-minded artists from Toronto, Ontario. This production is a final year thesis for Ryerson University’s New Media Fine Arts program.Artistic Director & Creator: Jessie LeeHead Choreographer: Zsakira Del ColComposer: Candice NgAudio Production: Julia Wittmann, Lucas BozzoMusicians: Brendan Rogers (cello), David Debono (piano), Erick Oliver Wawrzkiewicz (violin)Dancers: Jenna Stover, Jessica Simmons, Madeleine Hollingshead, Sophie Kudryk, Sydney Levitt, Zsakira Del ColSet Construction: Gabrielle Pangan, Imran Dhanani, Jessie LeeProjection Animation: Emily Green, Ginny Sivakumar, Jessie LeeMarketing Team: Isabella Santiago, Natalie Chuck, Tristan SauerCostsWays to HelpBACK US! SILVA is a low budget, student-funded project with unavoidable costs. Please help us bring this piece to life by contributing whatever you can!SHARE this page and help us promote! All contributions are greatly appreciated and the more people we can reach the better.FOLLOW us on social media! Updates, photos, videos, and more content will be shared on our Twitter, Instagram, and Facebook.CONTACT us for more information. Questions, comments, compliments? We’d to love hear back from you! Email us: silvaproduction2017@gmail.com

story:
So far, we’ve staged and performed six out of a cycle of seven rites.  The final play, Saturn, is the capstone to the project we started sixteen years ago.  

 

Some of you have seen many of our Rites, and some of you are approaching these plays for the first time. If you’re new, Welcome!- And you’re in luck: while we’ve been working our way through the series, Saturn represents the beginning of the cycle, where it all originates.

 

If you’re familiar with our work, and have been experiencing the series with us, then you understand what an achievement this is going to be! That’s why we’re inviting you to help make this finale great.

 

If you've seen our production of Jupiter, you are familiar with the custom carousel we built. It took about 180 hours to construct and cost roughly $4000.

 

 

We'd like to rework it to create Saturn’s feature structure, the Outpost on the Frontier of the Abyss .  

 

As you can see from this model, the plan is to turn it into a rotating cathedral that can be assembled on-stage.

The soundtrack is 80% complete, and will be available as a perk for donors this spring and for general release this summer.

 

These Rites are much bigger than just us and our adaptations.  It takes much more than DVDs; Worldwide Distribution; Soundtracks; IT TAKES YOU. YOU as Patrons, you as promoters, you as the type of people who support art, and who recognize the value of the creative process. What we're asking for is you to help us bring Saturn to life.  

What we need is money, and we are offering a number of swell and outlandish perks to our patrons!
 

The dates for the theater are set for September 2018, now we need to start creating. We appreciate your support.

story:
Short Summary

On Feb 2-4, 2018 I am producing a unique 1 hour acrobatic dance piece and interactive gallery installation revealing the complexity of international adoption titled Born, Never Asked.  This work is bringing awareness to an underrepresented element of adoption policy through an artistic medium that connects people through the heart, not just their minds.  With your support I can bring healing, empowerment and consciousness to adopted families.

 

What We Need & What You Get

We are needing funds to cover set design expansion, gallery installation and documentation of the performance.

$400 Added Set Design: A 40 foot self illuminating bloodline will be raised and come to life in the finale of the show.  Branches from my homeland will float from above. Rigging pulleys, carabiners and rope to support suspension of scenic elements.

$500 for Gallery Art Materials:  expand on a previously designed interactive gallery installation.  This expansion includes:

  • History of Adoption Timeline:  80 feet of continuous hand dyed, braided yarn and fabrics for audience to take in as they enter the theater stairwell.  Historical facts and policies related to adoption, immigration, and native people's rights will be curated by the Adoption Museum Project.

 

  • Projector Rental:  Project images of visiting my homeland and the orphanage I was adopted from.

 

  • Transportation: delivery of 10ft x 8ft Mural, self illuminating dresser with sand, dirt, grass, sea weed in drawers for audience to peak into and find questions about displacement, immigration, and home.

$900 to Video Document all 3 nights: This video would be used to present at adoption conferences, and entice touring opportunities. This work needs to be seen by adopted communities across the country!

The Impact

Adoption is both beautiful and complicated. 60% of people in the US have a connection to adoption, and yet many of the issues in adoption seam invisible.  Current immigration policies have a huge impact on International Adoptees for example.  35,000 are at risk for deportation due to some policy loopholes.  Born, Never Asked. gives voice and a platform for these issues through a new medium of dance, acrobatics, gallery installation, and post performance discussion.  In its first iteration, a shorter version of Born, Never Asked. received powerful response from audiences.  Adopted people said they felt validated, Birth/First Parents felt not written out of the conversation, Adoptive Parents felt they could understand deeper.  General public were stunned by the visuals and all were truly moved.


Awards & Recognition:  The first 30 mins of Born, Never Asked. was developed out of the CounterPulse Artist Residency Program in 2016.  Zoë Klein was awarded a Zellerbach Family Grant to support marketing for the full evening Feb 2018 production.  Born, Never Asked. was featured in SF Chronicle's Critique's Picks Week of Jan 28 as well as the February SF/Arts Monthly issue.

 

Risks & Challenges

Creating a full length show has been an enormous challenge. I created new costumes and doubled the length of the show.  I casted a new ensemble of incredible acrobats and dancers who are themselves immigrants born outside the U.S.

It wasn’t easy, but as team we did it, and we are so excited to share it with you Feb 2-4.  We just need your help to complete the project.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to contribute monetarily, I understand.  However there are many other ways you can contribute.  Please share this post on social media, let people know about this groundbreaking show, and most of all, please buy a ticket and join us.  It will be an extraordinary weekend that I am so excited to share with you.

story:
SOULSKIN Dance and Choreographer Adrianna Thompson  need your support to present their World Premiere...

HERO

HERO is a politically themed ballet that poses the question: What defines a hero?

Collaborators include: Guest Artist: Sebastien Thill, Visual Designer: Andy Mogg, Playwright: Lilly Bright, Lighting Designer: Harry Rubeck, Costume Designer: Jamielyn Duggan, Composer: Noah Salomon, Dancers: Devon Chen, Barbara Koch, Erika Hassan, Allie Papazian (ODC Dance & Company Nacional de Danza - Madrid), Margot Lena (Sarah Bush Dance Project), Arvejon Jones (Sean Dorsey Dance & PUSH Dance Company), Ryan Camou (Smuin Ballet, State Street Ballet), Adonis Damian, Delvis Savigne Frinon and Emanuel Colombo.

From HERO Playwright LILY BRIGHT:

"When a young woman unexpectedly receives a message from faraway, a doorway mysteriously reveals itself. An odyssey of the individual merging with the universal ( and vice versa) is the parallel realm that envelops her, testing her fortitude through longing and love, struggle and salvation, loss and remembrance. At once mystical and mundane, HERO explores the multitude of roles the hero plays in our everyday, extra-ordinary lives."

BE A HERO!

We need to raise an additional $5000 in order to REACH OUR BUDGET

  • All Funds Raised will go to producing HERO
  • CHECK OUT OUR HERO Support Packages!!
  • WE MUST REACH $5,000 in order to USE ALL THE FUNDS for HERO
  • CELEBRATE SOULSKIN DANCE'S 5TH ANNIVERSARY of bringing amazing collaborative dance events and artists to the bay area

Please help SOULSKIN Dance Get the Word out!

  • Share this Campaign on Facebook and use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • https://www.indiegogo.com/project/preview/27e5e3ee

story:
From the Choreographer

My mission as a freelance choreographer is to remain committed to sharing, bridging, and expanding modern dance language through depicting the external and internal landscapes of contemporary first-generation American identity. With a Master of Fine Arts in Dance degree from the University of California, Irvine, I research lineage, embodiment, and process to make original contemporary choreographies. With my work, I comment on world consciousness through physical, subtle, and often nuanced embodied patterns of thought. 

The Work 

This particular work, began as a personal choreographic journey that searched for a balance between western concert dance practices and my female Mexican-American culture and upbringing. 

Agave Americana -- A perceptional journey of ethnic identity taking shape in the American Southwest. Symbolic gestures, swaying hips, and harmonic progressions take audiences through a poetic movement experience that celebrates Mexican-American femininity.

The Restaging

Agave Americana at Bootleg Theater on October 25th & 26th, 2019

In this project, the team dives deeper into blending and layering stories. The dance first premiered in Orange County in April of 2019 with performances by UC Irvine undergraduate dance majors. It is currently being restaged and reimagined with professional artists to take on a fresh shape that deepens the context of ethnic narrative, perception, and form in a modern dance performance.

This dance was first created with intentions of having showings in Los Angeles. Transforming the work into a touring project to reach diverse audiences is the ultimate goal. The experience touches on familial aspects, that create a through line among different communities and cultures.

Musically, the choreography in Agave Americana has a fascinating relationship with sound, which features guitar, cajón, and wood flute sounds intermixed into a hauntingly sweet texturized world. The composition, performed live, is inspired by the themes found in Mexican folk music and is created conceptually and harmoniously between Ordaz and composer, Andrew J. Tarr. Together, this cast subtly reclaims the American Southwest by asking questions about a new sense of “place” that is affected by time.

The Process

All artists are generously committed to the meaning of this work and have agreed to be a part of this process for far less than their time, efforts, and artistry deserve. LA-based professional dancers have been rehearsing with Andrea Ordaz alongside long-time collaborator Andrew J. Tarr. 

All production fees and performer compensations are the sole responsibility of choreographer Andrea Ordaz in order to successfully present Agave Americana at the Bootleg Theater. Consider giving to this project to ensure that all artists and collaborators experience a creative environment that connects and enriches the arts with financial acknowledgment and support. As the project nears completion, we hope you join our campaign that raises funds to help pay all collaborators and/or the future possibilities for this dance!

The Team

Director/ Choreographer : Andrea Ordaz 

Composer/Sound Designer:  Andrew J. Tarr

Scenic Designer: Anna Ialeggio 

Lighting Designer: Wouter Feldbusch  

Stage Manager: Jose Garcia Davis

Performers: 

Catalina Jackson-Ureña 

Emeline Lotherington

MarieElena Martingano

Joan H. Padeo

Samantha Scheller  

Andrew J. Tarr (Live Musician)

The Impact 

Your support will cover costs for:

-Performer/Collaborator and Creative Team Compensation

-Renting Rehearsal Space

-Theater Rental Fees

-Strengthening Marketing Efforts

-Costuming and Scenic Needs

Risks and Challenges

Rehearsals have been underway and are scheduled up until our performances. The venue is set but we are counting on the support of this campaign to ensure that we produce Agave Americana to its highest potential with utmost integrity. Our lack of revenue for this production hinders our rehearsal commitments along with artist living necessities. We need your help and are grateful for any amount of support! xoxo   

* * * * * * * * * *

Learn more about the show, collaborators, and director here.

Follow on Facebook: @A.OrdazDance

Follow on Instagram: @dreaordaz

Follow on Twitter: @dreaordaz

story:
Seven Starving Artists is a collaborative company focused on social change and social issues. We are committed to creating poetic, thought-provoking work that gives voice to underrepresented people and topics. We hope to create experiences that resonate with modern audiences.

Seven Starving Artists was formed at the University of Lethbridge by a group of senior students looking to create a place for themselves in the ever-growing landscape of Canadian theatre.
The founding members of Seven Starving Artists chose to work together due to a shared desire to create and produce new and exciting work that challenges social norms and pushes the boundaries of the art form.

Donations to this project will help us put on the world premiere of a new Canadian work written by a fellow Albertan. The money raised will pay for the rental of rehearsal spaces, the production of a set, items needed for lighting and costume design, paying the artists involved and so much more! Any money raised above and beyond what is required for this project will go towards the companies insurance and future productions to keep us running in the future.

Funding Breakdown

Where will your money go?

Production: ~$250-$300

Scenic Design: $100 - We expect that this show will require a budget of approximately $100 for the Scenic Design elements of this production. For purchasing furniture and building materials to build an amazing set that will bring the audience into the world of the play. 

Costume Design: $50 - This will cover any items needed to costume the actor's that we cannot borrow from actors and crew.

Lighting Design: $50 - Our production will take place in a garage and the lighting budget will cover the practical lights needed to properly light the space.

Prop Design: $50 - This show requires many props and the $50 budget will cover any props that cannot be borrowed from the cast and crew.

*These numbers are all approximated and we may end up needing to expand budgets.*

Production Team and Actors: ~$1000 (Seven Starving Artists Founders will not be paid)

We estimate that paying the production team and the actors (approximately 15 artists) for their work will require around $1000 to pay everyone. Any money raised above and beyond will allow us to pay the team more than a minimum honorarium.

*If we do not make enough money to cover our costs we will have to dive into personal pockets and hope that we will make it back from ticket sales, so we very much appreciate any and all donations made.*

Feel free to email us at 7starvingartists@gmail.com if you have any questions about donations.

The Impact

Your donation makes it possible for Seven Starving Artists and companies like us to continue making art in the Calgary Area. New and upcoming artists are coming to Calgary to start their careers and knowing that we have the support of the citizens of Calgary will encourage students and young artists to continue migrating to Calgary and creating new and important art for the community. 

Thanks to Calgarians and their donations to our company, this will be our fourth show produced in Calgary. Seven Starving Artists has even managed to participate in festivals and win awards thanks to donations from people like you.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone is financially able to donate to causes and projects even though they may want to. If you are unable to donate and would like to help bring this project to fruition you can share this page with friend and family. Even just spreading the show around by word of mouth is a great way to help out. Ticket sales are our largest source of revenue and if you share this show with your friends we will be able to pay our actors.

story:
Production Summary

Drama of Works marks their 20th anniversary with this world premiere puppet play for all ages by Amina Henry. The piece has been awarded the Henson Foundation family grant and will premiere at the TANK in July 2019. ​

** ** ** ** ** ** ** ** ** ** ** ** ** ** ** ** ** ** ** ** ** 

In the early 1900s African-Americans began to migrate north in large numbers. Harlem was where their community was, so many moved there, despite the high rents. Rent parties became a popular way for families to raise the rent money they needed. They would hire a musician or band, get cheap refreshments and charge a small entry fee. 

An innovative toy theater fills the stage, a replica of a Harlem block from the 1920s. Lights flicker on as people awake. We see toy theater puppets, shadows come to life in windows, and at a certain point the whole set transforms. All the while actors frolic in 20s costumes, original saxophone music plays through the speakers and a cat does back alley beat poetry. We’re transported in time to an era poignant and pivotal to the African-American experience in this country and people of all ages should know these stories, hear these words and listen to this music. Come follow Rose, Jenny and Ricky as they help their mammas throw a RENT PARTY to save their house. All they need to do is get the ice, hand out some cards, oh - and get a real live musician to play. Shouldn't be too hard...​

Together, with Amina, we have the power to take on issues like water shortage, poverty and racism, in a way that is palatable for all ages. We achieve this through drama, fantasy and humor. 

 

WE NEED YOU!

Your donation will go toward the following initiatives:

  • A compact laptop that will run all the sound in the show. (And sound is very important to this piece...)
  • Guaranteeing that we can pay all of our designers and actors a nice fee without relying on box office sales. This helps us pay them on time and with more security.
  • While our toy theater set is simple, we have upped the professionalism with lighting and accessories. Who knew that dollhouse lights were so expensive? Help us make the set as beautiful as it can be!

 

Can't give now? Come see the show!!!

We understand if you can't donate to this campaign. You can still help us out, though. Please come see the show, bring friends and kids. Tell others about it!

TICKETS: https://www.thetanknyc.org/calendar/2019/6/12/r...
story_txt:
Production Summary
Drama of Works marks their 20th anniversary with this world premiere puppet play for all ages by Amina Henry. The piece has been awarded the Henson Foundation family grant and will premiere at the TANK in July 2019. ​
** ** ** ** ** ** ** ** ** ** ** ** ** ** ** ** ** ** ** ** ** 
In the early 1900s African-Americans began to migrate north in large numbers. Harlem was where their community was, so many moved there, despite the high rents. Rent parties became a popular way for families to raise the rent money they needed. They would hire a musician or band, get cheap refreshments and charge a small entry fee. 
An innovative toy theater fills the stage, a replica of a Harlem block from the 1920s. Lights flicker on as people awake. We see toy theater puppets, shadows come to life in windows, and at a certain point the whole set transforms. All the while actors frolic in 20s costumes, original saxophone music plays through the speakers and a cat does back alley beat poetry. We’re transported in time to an era poignant and pivotal to the African-American experience in this country and people of all ages should know these stories, hear these words and listen to this music. Come follow Rose, Jenny and Ricky as they help their mammas throw a RENT PARTY to save their house. All they need to do is get the ice, hand out some cards, oh - and get a real live musician to play. Shouldn't be too hard...​
Together, with Amina, we have the power to take on issues like water shortage, poverty and racism, in a way that is palatable for all ages. We achieve this through drama, fantasy and humor. 
 

WE NEED YOU!
Your donation will go toward the following initiatives:

A compact laptop that will run all the sound in the show. (And sound is very important to this piece...)
Guaranteeing that we can pay all of our designers and actors a nice fee without relying on box office sales. This helps us pay them on time and with more security.
While our toy theater set is simple, we have upped the professionalism with lighting and accessories. Who knew that dollhouse lights were so expensive? Help us make the set as beautiful as it can be!

 
Can't give now? Come see the show!!!
We understand if you can't donate to this campaign. You can still help us out, though. Please come see the show, bring friends and kids. Tell others about it!
TICKETS: https://www.thetanknyc.org/calendar/2019/6/12/r...

story:
WE’RE PUTTING ON A SHOW (…actually a whole lot of them)

TLDR; here's what you need to know:

  • We have put together an intersectional Bay Area-wide Women’s Theatre Festival with 3 months of theater written & directed by women+/non-binary artists with at least 50% women+/non-binary folx on- and off-stage
  • This is the first festival of its kind in the Bay Area
  • We are committed to paying EVERY SINGLE PERSON working on this festival
  • 70% of our $100,000 festival budget pays PEOPLE (the rest of the budget: 10% is fiscal sponsor fees, 12% is space rental & 8% is all the printed programs & posters, binders, music stands, glow tape, etc. we can afford)


We're extremely grateful for any support you can lend us to pay our artists, production team, organizers, venues, and other festival costs. (More info at baWTF.com)

Your contribution to the Bay Area Women’s Theatre Festival will support all of the following programming:

  • Amplify! a 24-Hour marathon of women+ taking the stage including solo works, stand up, short plays, staged readings, devised works, improv, clowning, workshops and more (April 18-19, 2020 on all 3 stages and every available space at Brava in SF’s Mission District)
  • The Women of Color Reading Series (primarily contemporary plays)
  • The Classical Reading Series (plays written from the Elizabethan era to the 1930s)
  • Spreading the word about full productions and staged readings produced by participating theater companies in all 9 Bay Area counties
  • Workshops & Forums & Parties
  • An opportunity to advocate for the work of and hiring of women+ and non-binary artists in every aspect of theatrical production

 

We are showcasing women+ creating an array of performances – a variety and range of work that challenges presumptions of what a “women’s show” might be – in a place where we see, hear and are inspired by each other’s work. We are creating community for new collaborators to meet, planting the seeds for further work. We are providing a place for work that matters to us, and where we matter. And it is going to be FUN!

 

TELL ME MORE ABOUT baWTF (aka, is “WTF” intentional)

A few weeks ago, one of our participating theaters asked us about our nickname – baWTF. YES, the “WTF” is intentional. Sometimes when you see the lack of women+ voices, artists, designers, the first thing that comes to mind is “WTF?!?!” And we are here to make that change…

WHAT'S THIS INDIEGOGO MONEY FOR

$15,000 for artist stipends
AMPLIFY! alone will have over 150 artists - performers, directors, stage managers, deck crew, technicians - working over the course of 24 hours.

Our 2 readings series will have between 60-120 actors, 12 directors and 12 stage managers.

Every one of these artists deserves compensation.

This campaign doesn’t even cover space rental, stipends for our 20+ organizers, print materials, marketing and publicity. We are raising over $50,000 through traditional fundraising channels in advance of the festival to help cover our costs before tickets go on sale – we believe in paying vendors ON TIME and giving artists their fair share!

 

HOW ELSE CAN I HELP?

Not everyone can support our show with a donation and we understand that! You can help us out in other ways like coming to see us in MARCH, APRIL and MAY of 2020, sending our information on to a friend, or sharing this campaign on social media! Check us out on Twitter and Facebook (we may become Insta folx, but baby steps…) to see where our next event, fundraiser or party is happening!

 

A Note on Inclusion: We recognize the limiting nature of the binary use of woman. baWTF welcomes anyone on the gender spectrum who identifies either always or some of the time as a woman. We also welcome those who identify as non-binary. In our narrative above, we use the term “women+” to represent the expansive definition of women to include women+, womyn, womxn, wimmin, womin, woomin and trans persons.

 

We are fiscally sponsored by Intersection for the Arts, a 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization, which allows us to offer you tax deductions for your contributions. The portion of your contribution to baWTF that is above the market value of the "perk" you have chosen may be tax-deductible. Please consult your financial advisor for further information.

story:
Through the Looking Glass and into the Heart of the Community.

What is Storm Fever Theatre and what are its aims? 

We are Storm Fever, a theatre company that is for everyday people who haven't acted before or haven't had their voices heard. We specialise in helping people with underlying mental health issues and/or people who have never had the opportunity to perform. This project has been set up to help people express themselves and get out of their heads and everyday lives. They use art as a safe place to explore characters and scenarios they never would have done before and learn from it. We also feel in our cast that age is but a number and doesn't define you as a person. We have cast members ranging from 22-85 which means that as a theatre community we can conquer any age barriers that have been set in modern day society.

So what is the play and what's the main aims of this production?  

Play is on he 22nd of February at 6pm. Doors open 5.45pm. East Oxford Community Centre.

Wonderland is a place where anything is possible and we have decided to call our project after Alice and this well known children's fairy tale.  However, this production will have a environmental twist and therefore will simply be called 'Alice with a Twist.' In this tale, it starts at Alice's birthday party and then goes into a whirlwind adventure after being swept up by the rubbish tip outside her house. She is sad, confused and looking for her cat, but will she find a way out of this trash wonderland she finds herself in? 

Aimed at both adults and children, this play presents this classic fairy tale from a different perspective, and highlights the ongoing environmental crisis that we are finding ourselves in everyday. From the forest fires in Australia to our fish eating plastic, Storm Fever wanted to write a play that talks about these issues but in a way that is also child friendly. This is so that the younger generation can understand the importance of these issues too. 

Why Help Us? 

By helping fund this project you will be helping a brand new theatre company root itself into the arts and spread its wings into highlighting issues and events that need to be spoken about. As well as this, you will be helping a community of people gain confidence and improve their mental health by exploring the arts. This particular project is getting people to discover their inner child and helping them relive and express themselves in a very human way. The actors have worked very hard to get this far and by giving us this extra support, we can put on the best show we can for local communities and support groups . This show is all about freedom of expression, identity and the environment  and so by contributing you are letting everyday people have their opinions heard. 

What will you receive by donating to this company? 

  • Any money raised will go straight back into covering costs for the rehearsal space, performance venue, making and buying costumes, props and set design. It will also give us the opportunity to keep our ticket prices low and to have concessions on the door.  
  • If we cover our initial costs, any profit will go straight back into the theatre company for our next show and future projects. It will also fund for any community workshops we want to do in the future. 
  • By supporting this company you will be giving back to your local community and will receive an email of thanks and appreciation from the Artistic Director. As well as this you will receive the perks which are listed on this campaign. 

The storms that lay ahead...

There has been various risks and challenges with this project. From the fact that most of the people in it have had no previous performance experience, to the idea that this whole project is community lead which has its own series of risks and hurdles. We have no money up front, which means we are relying on this page and a series of clothes sales and busking performances. The more we can raise, the better the quality of the performance.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can spread the word about our show, to liking our Facebook page or Instagram Storm Fever Theatre to sharing this Indiegogo page, it would make the world of difference to us! Performance Dates will be confirmed but we are scheduling the show for the mid/end of February, which doesn't give us too long! However, we are determined to do everything we can! What we can promise is a colorful, avant-garde, political and fantastical experience.  We are also planning to book acting workshops after the show and try to get to the heart of Oxford in everything we do. Any wonderland props or costumes you have hiding in your attic  we could use as well would be great, we want to recycle as much as possible! Or just wear silly hats and come and see us perform! We can't wait to do a storm of a show!

We can't wait to do a storm of a show!

story:
Fall of the House: A Synopsis

A bitter author, a jealous friend, and a HOUSE that foretells death. Welcome to New York, 1839.

Part thriller, part detective story, part surrealist drama, Fall of the House is a play that uses movement, music and text to explore the extraordinary circumstances behind the writing of Edgar Allan Poe’s famous short story “The Fall of the House of Usher”: a tale which eerily mirrored Poe’s own life. 

Set in three overlapping timelines, Fall of the House is the story of a man on the edge of sanity, a real-life murder plot, and a HOUSE that manipulates the nature of reality.

 

Prepare yourself . The HOUSE is waiting.

 

Who Are You Guys Anyway?

Hello! We are the team behind "Fall of the House": a brand new hybrid theatrical work being created in New York City. We're a majority-female creative team that is criss-crossing genres to make a wholly new take on Edgar Allan Poe's 'The Fall of the House of Usher', which links fiction, documentary, mystery and fantasy into one truly unique and unforgettable play.

Our team consists of a bunch of awesome collaborators, who are all stars in their respective fields. They include, but aren't limited to:

 

​Ashley Marinelli - Writer/Choreographer

Greer Gisy - Creative Producer

Jessica Wu - Producing Consultant

Lily Desmond - Composer

Chris Grant and Lauren Yalango-Grant - Choreographic Consultants

Jeanette Abell - Assistant Choreographer

Roni Pillischer - Sound Designer

Mary Jessica Colvin - Showcase Director

 

 

So, Why Should We Care About This Project?

If you've watched our pitch video, you may already have some idea (and if you haven't, why don't you go watch it? It's right up there ⬆️). But if you still don't know, let us break it down for you:

1) This isn't your mother's Edgar Allan Poe show. Take it from our Assistant Choreographer, Jeanette Abell:

"Seeing through the layers of what was socially acceptable in the historical context of Poe’s lifetime, and being able to peel those away and modernize him in a theatrical work invites us to discover what lies at the root of our allure to Poe. In our own work, we often tell our own stories, share our vast secrets, our glowing victories, and despicable truths and fears. Unafraid to implore Poe’s emotional vulnerabilities for all to see, we plan to deliver the chance we all deserve to know and relate to Poe as a human, rather than a legend.

Also, we have The HOUSE,  intersecting timelines and Joseph Snodgrass. You don't even understand yet, but you will."

 

2) We're a team of mostly-female artists interested in taking a fresh look at a character (and a story) that many people assume they know a lot about. Once again, Assistant Choreographer, Jeanette Abell:

"We must revisit renowned figures and their stories that we thought we knew with crisp and modern inquiries, as we have lenses at our disposal now that were not socially acceptable during the periods in which these figures lived. These lenses sometimes tell a more honest story.

Though  female figures had such a huge affect on Poe's life  (and indeed, are the reason we have a lot of his work in the first place - but more on that later), we don't hear from them in  our current history books. Therefore, a female perspective is an ideal framework to revisit Poe, especially given his biography."

 

3) We are collaborators who believe that artists with good ideas should be given opportunities to create and be compensated for their work:

Jeanette Abell, ladies and gentlemen (she really is so articulate):

"When Ashley [Writer/Choreographer] and I initially met up to discuss her idea for a new show she felt compelled to create, our conversation began naturally around the current climate of opportunities available and sought after by performing artists, and how this prompts aspirations to make the work that you want to see and do. As performing artists, we all know this conversation, and how it can lead you into a depressing realization that there is:  

  • A deficiency in fresh and original stories and character explorations 
  • A lack of diversity in conversations explored and voices heard ​
  • Casting opportunities on a slimming trend, and as always,​
  • Difficulty with network willingness and resource acquisition 

What I've come to understand is that the creation of new work is important, and that if you want to change the trends, then you have to make work, and new work. Therefore, we must support artists who create with conviction from the ground up, and we must support them even before an esteemed reputation for high caliber work precedes them. Recognizing the gravity of the particular window of time and opportunity at the beginning of an artistic process, I am one of a group that has aligned behind an artist’s vision for a production that will undoubtedly be a tremendous piece of theater. "

 

That All Sounds Great, But What Are You Raising Money For?

We've been working on the show for a little over a year, and we've got several readings, three choreographic labs and one workshop, to show for it! But now it's time to take the next steps towards finding the show a permanent home. 

In service of that goal, we will be producing a Showcase in May 2020 in NYC, in the hopes of attracting producers and investors that will help us with these next steps. 

However, producing a Showcase isn't cheap, and so we need help covering the costs of venue rental, rehearsal space, performer salaries, creative team salaries, printing costs, marketing costs, equipment rental, etc. We estimate that this will cost a total of $10,000.

We've gone as far as we can on our own, and now we need your help.

So, please consider...

The Breakdown (and some perks):

 

What If I Can't Donate Right Now?

Any amount of money, even $1, really helps us at this point. However, we all know what's it's like to be strapped for cash.

If you can't donate right now, you can help us by sharing this campaign on social media, or telling your cool and art-loving friends about this show!  Like Malcolm Gladwell says, be a 'Connector'! If you don't get that reference, go check out "The Tipping Point" and thank us later.

And of course, be sure to check out www.fallofthehouseplay.com and follow us on Instagram at @fallofthehouseplay.

Thanks for considering us, and we hope you have a bright and fulfilling 2020!

In love and creativity,

 The "Fall of the House" Team

"

What If I Can't Donate Right Now?
Any amount of money, even $1, really helps us at this point. However, we all know what's it's like to be strapped for cash.
If you can't donate right now, you can help us by sharing this campaign on social media, or telling your cool and art-loving friends about this show!  Like Malcolm Gladwell says, be a 'Connector'! If you don't get that reference, go check out "The Tipping Point" and thank us later.
And of course, be sure to check out www.fallofthehouseplay.com and follow us on Instagram at @fallofthehouseplay.
Thanks for considering us, and we hope you have a bright and fulfilling 2020!
In love and creativity,
 The "Fall of the House" Team

story:
Hello! My name is Vladimir Kremenović and I am a Seattle-based artist premiering work at Velocity Dance Center’s upcoming Bridge Project 2019. The Bridge Project is a yearly performance showcasing Seattle’s most promising new talents in dance choreography. For this year’s Bridge, I am developing an original piece entitled Shear Stress, inspired by the mechanics of landslides – both geological and emotional. Working in collaboration with nine other dancers, my piece seeks to find resonances and intersections between the Pacific Northwest landscape and our personal experiences of drastic – and sometimes destructive – change.

 

For the last month, my nine fellow dancers and I have spent over 48 hours developing, evolving, and practicing this complex piece in an accelerated preparation for its upcoming premiere. I aim to raise enough money from the local community to fairly compensate each of my performers for their dedication to this intensive process. The dancers are: Kara Beadle, Elise Beers, Gabby Bilka, Anna Joswiak, Sage King, Amy Nielsen, Leah Russell, Rachel Wu and Andy Zacek.

Whether you can attend our performance on January 31st – February 3rd or not, I hope you can show support for local artists by donating to this campaign or sharing the link. Working artists like myself depend on generous donations from the community to keep creating. Thank you for your support!

 

More About Me:

Immigrant performer and filmmaker Vladimir Kremenović originally hails from Banja Luka, Bosnia & Herzegovina. He graduated from Middlebury College in 2017 with a joint degree in dance and film. He has studied under Christal Brown, Trebien Pollard, Tzveta Kassabova, Gabriel Forestieri, Katie Martin, and Andrea Olson. Based out of Seattle since 2017, he has most recently performed with Heather Kravas, Mellissa Riker, Petra Zanki, Jordan Macintosh-Hougham, and Noelle Price. The Bridge Project marks his first original work to premiere in Seattle. His choreography draws inspiration from dance theater, as well as postmodern elements such as repetition, variation, and improvisation.

 

More About Shear Stress:

            “Landslides occur when gravitational and other types of shear stresses within a slope exceed the strength of the materials that form the slope.” In exploring this piece, I focused not so much on the landslide itself as an event, but rather the unseen processes foreshadowing this destruction. I seek to draw correlations between landslides in geology, in society, and in our personal lives. When does stress reach a breaking point where collapse becomes inevitable? How does this destruction manifest itself in the environment, our political systems, our emotions? Is there catharsis in catastrophe?

story:
Who the heck is Tara?

Hey there! My name's Tara. I'm an actor, comic, wife and mum. I've been up to a few things over the last few years, including performing at some great comedy venues, directing the five star sell out show 'NewsRevue', working with amazing writers like Fay Weldon, and actors like Nicole Kidman, and most recently/importantly, being a full time mum to two beautiful boys. Something I've always dreamt of doing was taking my own show to the Edinburgh Fringe Festival, and now we are making that dream a reality. I've been testing out material on my children, as well as audiences made up of adult humans.. and they've been laughing, which is a great sign. I have confirmed Just The Tonic as the venue, which is one of the best comedy venues at the Edinburgh Fringe, and I also have previews booked in for Brighton Festival, the Oxford Comedy Festival, Hungerford Summer Arts Festival as well as venues in London and Guilford. 

What this show means to me

This show means a lot to me because it's not just about making people laugh, it's also about bringing people together and breaking down stigma. Yes there are jokes about group pelvic floor exercises and googling how to change a nappy, but I also touch on some heavier topics. I had three miscarriages before our first son was conceived, and during that time my husband and I felt completely heartbroken and very alone. I had no idea how common miscarriages are, because no one talks about them. I also didn't realise that it was possible to be lonely as a new parent, or how isolated women with post natal depression could feel. So as a way of getting people to open up more, I decided to write some jokes about it! Oh great, miscarriage and loneliness jokes.. Sounds like a really fun show.. Honestly though, in this social media driven, genuine-connection-starved world, now more than ever we need a supportive and understanding community - for parents, people who want to be parents, and even people who never want to be parents because they really can't stand kids. 

What your support can do

Regardless of whether we get extra funding, this show is going to Edinburgh Fringe Festival (I've signed contracts, and if I don't go through with it, I believe I go to contract jail?). But with your support, it can not only 'happen' - it can actually be successful! A huge part of getting people through the door, getting articles written, and getting that book tour is marketing! And marketing is expensive.. That's on top of accommodation (couch surfing is not an option with two babies.. they're super demanding), the venue guarantee, poster design, travel costs.. it's a long list. So any donation or help is very much appreciated! 

What sponsorship will go towards:

  • Technical overheads for the month 
  •  Ed Fringe venue hire for the month 
  •  Marketing & PR 
  •  Poster/Flyer design & printing
  •  Accommodation & travel

Other ways you can help

I realise not everyone has cash to spare so it's no worries at all if you can't donate - but if instead you could help support the show by spreading the word, sharing this with someone who might be interested, posting about the show on social media, telling your grandma etc. then I would be so so grateful. Regardless of what you do, THANK YOU THANK YOU THANK YOU! I really appreciate it.

For more information about me or the show please go to: www.taranewtonwordsworth.com

Or you can check out my social pages: 

  • https://www.facebook.com/taranewtonwordsworth
  • https://www.instagram.com/taranw/
  • https://twitter.com/tara_nw
