story:
Who are we and why are we making this appeal?

We are passionate about bringing incredible theatre to as many audience members as we can. We are helping to change the cultural landscape in Long Island City and we're hoping you are passionate about these aims too. 

  • The Secret Theatre has been the home to an incredible amount of contemporary and classical theatre, dance, music, children's theatre and more. More than one person has said that the facility is like a mini-arts center because we either promote or host a broad spectrum of performance arts beyond theatre.  Everyone, clients and audiences alike, has raved about the quality of the space in terms of look, accommodation, and atmosphere.
  • Our campaign needs to raise $15,000 to ensure that we can not only put on an incredible 2016 calendar of events but more importantly we need this money to ensure our survival. We have a funding gap. If we cannot fill it there is a real and present danger that we will not be able to continue.
  • There are amazing things on our immediate horizon even in the midst of this financial vortex: In January we are producing:

  • City Girls and Desperadoes - Directed by Artistic Director, Richard Mazda and starring renowned actor/director Austin Pendleton, Annette Benda Fox, burlesque royalty, Julie Atlas Muz, Orange is The New Black's Karina Ortiz, Peter Collier and Connie Castanzo. 

    • In February, we have:

  • A Chorus Line in a 40th anniversary special directed by author and director Tom Rowan.
  • These great shows will be complimented by a New Voices Project premiere of Opaline by Fengar Gael, Children's drama classes, Pirate Pete, The Queens World Film Festival, LIC Arts Open events and an incredible lineup. 

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

What We Need & What You Get

Lets break it down to specifics:

  • We need to raise $15,000.  This money will be used in the following ways:
  1. To help us pay our bills. [We receive no major grants and rely on donations, fundraising and ticket money]
  2. To help us pay for great sets, costumes, and props.
  3. To help us pay increased stipends to our actors, directors and creatives. [Most off off theatre is performed by unpaid actors hoping for credits and reviews - this is because the typically low off off Broadway ticket price of $18 vs NYC rents and other expenses make wages for performers a remote and distant hope]


    You give to us and we give to you!


  • If you are able to donate we have some incredible rewards including a limited run T shirt speically designed by one of LIC's most celebrated artists, Luba Lukova, tickets to shows, subscriptions and other gift ideas.
  • Want to get professional acting or coaching for your budding young actor? Our rewards include a limited amount of places in the Academy at reduced rates and you will be helping us at the same time!
  • If we don't reach our entire goal we are most likely going to use what we raise for items 1 and 2 in the above list.  We will also run a separate sponsorship campaign to the many local businesses that support us even as we help to bring customers to the area.

What is special about this Secret?

  • Can we toot our own  horn?

  • Here is a short list of some of our achievements:
  • Time Out said that The Secret is among the top 50 theatres in NYC. Twice.
  • In our 10 year history we calculate that we have served over 100,000 customers many of these also become customers of other local businesses like LIC Market, Court Square Diner, Tost, The Shannon Pot, Gaw Gai and many, many others.
  • Over 3000 artists have performed at The Secret - many of these artists have been able to get their agents, mangers and to find other projects with a respected Secret Theatre credit on their resume.
  • All of the realtors and property developers have used the existence of The Secret and other cultural organizations to promote the diversity and ambience of what is now one of the hottest places in NYC to move to. We want to continue to contribute to that LIC 'feeling'.
  • Playbill in July named The Secret Theatre alongside BAM in Brooklyn, St George in Staten Island, The Lehman in Bronx as the theatre in Queens. To be compared to giant organizations like BAM or the Lehman Performing Arts center is a huge honor. Playbill Article or on the picture for the full article.

  • We created the first real theatre in LIC in 2005 before the area became incredibly hip.  However, its well known that after an area is colonized by artists that they are the first casualties once the area takes off.     Recently it was announced that another local theatre, The Chain would be closing in early 2016. [The Chain was created by ex-Secret Theatre staff].   The rising rents and pressure from an overheated Long Island City property market are making life challenging for arts related businesses like ours. The irony is that we are among several cultural projects that help to gentrify and make the area attractive but now we are in danger of becoming a victim to this success.
  • We need you and we certainly hope you would agree that you need us. The area where we are located is in the middle of an exciting expansion but the residents both new and old need the area to be more than just a series of glass towers without amenities.  Besides all of the in house and rental projects we are also partners with great local organizations like The Queens World Film Festival, The LIC School of Ballet, LIC Academy of Music, Queens New Music Festival, Queensboro Dance Festival. We provide classes to local children and offer the only professional theatre environment for children to



We recognize that there are many campaigns to contribute to and its easy to feel you already did your part but we sincerely ask you to consider donating at any level you feel comfortable with - every single dollar will help us.


  • We have made it this far and we think its actually a long, long way. 
  • We also promise to always strive to achieve nothing more than perfection. Even when we fail to reach this divine level we help to contribute to the rich traditions and help to enrich a very special place, Long Island City.

Other Ways You Can Help Keep The Secret

If you can't or even if you can donate you can help us in other ways, which, are FREE!

  • YOU could post our indiegogo link on your Facebook, Instagram or Twitter page. Just copy the url!
  • Perhaps you might consider sending to your mailing list
  • YOU can use the Indiegogo share tools!

Whatever way you help us, we are very grateful for and we sincerely hope to continue to provide great theatre and other arts for many years.
story_txt:
Who are we and why are we making this appeal?
 We are passionate about bringing incredible theatre to as many audience members as we can. We are helping to change the cultural landscape in Long Island City and we're hoping you are passionate about these aims too.    
The Secret Theatre has been the home to an incredible amount of contemporary and classical theatre, dance, music, children's theatre and more. More than one person has said that the facility is like a mini-arts center because we either promote or host a broad spectrum of performance arts beyond theatre.  Everyone, clients and audiences alike, has raved about the quality of the space in terms of look, accommodation, and atmosphere.
 Our campaign needs to raise $15,000 to ensure that we can not only put on
 an incredible 2016 calendar of events but more importantly we need this money to ensure our survival. We have a funding gap. If we cannot fill it there is a real and present danger that we will not be able to continue. There are amazing things on our immediate horizon even in the midst of this financial vortex: In January we are producing:


City Girls and Desperadoes - Directed by Artistic Director, Richard Mazda and starring renowned actor/director Austin Pendleton, Annette Benda Fox, burlesque royalty, Julie Atlas Muz, Orange is The New Black's Karina Ortiz, Peter Collier and Connie Castanzo. 

In February, we have: 

A Chorus Line in a 40th anniversary special directed by author and director Tom Rowan. 

These great shows will be complimented by a New Voices Project premiere of Opaline by Fengar Gael, Children's drama classes, Pirate Pete, The Queens World Film Festival, LIC Arts Open events and an incredible lineup.  
  Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?   What We Need & What You Get Lets break it down to specifics:  We need to raise $15,000.  This money will be used in the following ways:


To help us pay our bills. [We receive no major grants and rely on donations, fundraising and ticket money]
To help us pay for great sets, costumes, and props.
To help us pay increased stipends to our actors, directors and creatives. [Most off off theatre is performed by unpaid actors hoping for credits and reviews - this is because the typically low off off Broadway ticket price of $18 vs NYC rents and other expenses make wages for performers a remote and distant hope]




You give to us and we give to you!
If you are able to donate we have some incredible rewards including a limited run T shirt speically designed by one of LIC's most celebrated artists, Luba Lukova, tickets to shows, subscriptions and other gift ideas.
Want to get professional acting or coaching for your budding young actor? Our rewards include a limited amount of places in the Academy at reduced rates and you will be helping us at the same time!

If we don't reach our entire goal we are most likely going to use what we raise for items 1 and 2 in the above list.  We will also run a separate sponsorship campaign to the many local businesses that support us even as we help to bring customers to the area.
    What is special about this Secret?
  
Can we toot our own  horn? 


Here is a short list of some of our achievements:

Time Out said that The Secret is among the top 50 theatres in NYC. Twice.
In our 10 year history we calculate that we have served over 100,000 customers many of these also become customers of other local businesses like LIC Market, Court Square Diner, Tost, The Shannon Pot, Gaw Gai and many, many others.
Over 3000 artists have performed at The Secret - many of these artists have been able to get their agents, mangers and to find other projects with a respected Secret Theatre credit on their resume.

All of the realtors and property developers have used the existence of The Secret and other cultural organizations to promote the diversity and ambience of what is now one of the hottest places in NYC to move to. We want to continue to contribute to that LIC 'feeling'.

Playbill in July named The Secret Theatre alongside BAM in Brooklyn, St George in Staten Island, The Lehman in Bronx as the theatre in Queens. To be compared to giant organizations like BAM or the Lehman Performing Arts center is a huge honor. Playbill Article or on the picture for the full article. 


We created the first real theatre in LIC in 2005 before the area became incredibly hip.  However, its well known that after an area is colonized by artists that they are the first casualties once the area takes off.     Recently it was announced that another local theatre, The Chain would be closing in early 2016. [The Chain was created by ex-Secret Theatre staff].   The rising rents and pressure from an overheated Long Island City property market are making life challenging for arts related businesses like ours. The irony is that we are among several cultural projects that help to gentrify and make the area attractive but now we are in danger of becoming a victim to this success.
 We need you and we certainly hope you would agree that you need us. The area where we are located is in the middle of an exciting expansion but the residents both new and old need the area to be more than just a series of glass towers without amenities.  Besides all of the in house and rental projects we are also partners with great local organizations like The Queens World Film Festival, The LIC School of Ballet, LIC Academy of Music, Queens New Music Festival, Queensboro Dance Festival. We provide classes to local children and offer the only professional theatre environment for children to 
 



We recognize that there are many campaigns to contribute to and its easy to feel you already did your part but we sincerely ask you to consider donating at any level you feel comfortable with - every single dollar will help us. 
We have made it this far and we think its actually a long, long way.  

We also promise to always strive to achieve nothing more than perfection. Even when we fail to reach this divine level we help to contribute to the rich traditions and help to enrich a very special place, Long Island City.
    Other Ways You Can Help Keep The Secret
 If you can't or even if you can donate you can help us in other ways, which, are FREE!  YOU could post our indiegogo link on your Facebook, Instagram or Twitter page. Just copy the url!
Perhaps you might consider sending to your mailing list
 YOU can use the Indiegogo share tools!   Whatever way you help us, we are very grateful for and we sincerely hope to continue to provide great theatre and other arts for many years.

story:
Hello! 

Welcome to our crowd funding page for Correspondence, a new play by Lucinda Burnett, premièring at the Old Red Lion Theatre, London from 8 March to 2 April 2016.

Blythe Stewart will directs Lucinda Burnett’s powerful new witty drama Correspondence, a bittersweet story of fledgling friendships and mental health set between Stockport and Syria on the brink of the Arab Spring. 

This production will coincide with the 5th anniversary of the Syrian Revolution.

We have developed this play with actors, mental health charity SANE, Doctors and experts in mental health and psychosis, the British Red Cross, and some lovely Syrians...and now WE NEED YOU!


Why We Need You

We have been given a four week run of Correspondence at the Old Red Lion Theatre in Islington, London and have raised a significant amount of funding needed through trusts, funds, investment and generous donations.

However, we still have a little more to raise, to ensure this production is of the highest quality and reaches our identified audiences; to raise the profile of our talented artists and also raise awareness of the two core themes in Correspondence – mental health and the Syrian crisis.

The £1,000 we are asking you for will pay our brilliant Press Representative Chris Hislop - www.chrishislop.com to get press coverage for Correspondence and ensure reviewers attend the show, achieving our artistic goals in supporting Lucinda Burnett’s first full length, professional run.  

Your support will also go towards our marketing materials and campaign ensuring that we reach our target audiences and raise awareness.


The Impact

This play has been developed over a long period of time with a wealth of wonderful people and organisations, and it would mean the world to have your support in helping us finally present this play in the professional, full-length run it deserves.

The run of Correspondence coincides with the 5th anniversary of the start of the Syrian outbreak (13th March, 2011 was when it all sadly began) and we want to talk about this as well as mental health, which affects 1 in 4 of us but is still a taboo subject.  

Correspondence specifically looks at the early signs of psychosis in young people.


ABOUT THE PLAY

“If you’re in, you’re in, no messing. This isn’t bunking off to Stockport, to play Laser Quest at Grand Central. This is the kind of activity that sets us apart from the dross.”

Spring 2011.  Kate and Wills tie the knot whilst Syrian teenagers are tortured for anti-government graffiti.

Ben is 16, and his friend Jibreel has disappeared from Xbox Live.  He thinks he’s mixed up in the protests in Syria – and he’ll risk everything on a journey to find out the truth.

What happens when a teenager from Stockport tries to stop the world exploding?


OUR FABULOUS TEAM!

Writer - Lucinda Burnett                                                                                                         Director - Blythe Stewart                                                                                                   Designer - Bethany Wells                                                                                                     Lighting Designer - Christopher Nairne                                                                     Composer and Sound Designer - Giles Thomas                                                           Casting Director - Stephanie Hume                                                                           Production Manager - Pip Robinson                                                                            Producers - Emma O'Mara and Robyn Keynes for Glint of Light Productions            PR - Chris Hislop                                                                                                             Photography and image by Richard Lakos


Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t give financially but still want to support us, or if you would like to do both, please spread the word of our #CorrespondenceCampaign on social media, email, or good old fashioned word of mouth!


For more information please go to: www.oldredliontheatre.co.uk/correspondence

Twitter: www.twitter.com/_Correspondence

 @_Correspondence #CorrespondencePlay

Facebook: www.facebook.com/CorrespondencePlay 

 

Much love and thanks for reading,

Lucinda, Blythe, Emma, Robyn and the entire Correspondence team x

story:
Lady Garden

Our Indiegogo Campaign was launched to raise the necessary funds for its research and development theatre workshop (stage 1). In my mind, Lady Garden, after it's research and development workshop and script writing phases, I see it opening on a West End stage. It's a dream and a vivid vision and it takes discipline (and a dash of obsession) to make it happen. 

Lady Garden is real actors, a real director, challenging the world, making us think and feel. It's a story about us. Lady Garden intends to be a story, told by us for our generation, to share with the future, intending to create a better world; such is the power of story telling. 

The Lady Garden project is designed to build and create a new piece of womens' theatre based on a framework of creative ideas outlining a story about women, for women and told by women, working on a Garden Allotment in London. 

The basis of the script will be created around a rainbow of women (and a transgender woman and a male actor), from a myriad of cultures and backgrounds, from diverse socio demographics, discussing universal women's concerns, and of many ages from the young to the young at heart. Ldy Garden won't be a caricature play.  

The main themes will include:

  • Humanity
  • Comedy
  • Cultural and Diversity
  • Inclusion and Class
  • Challenge the perception of gender
  • Havens
  • Contrasts


Background

In London, the idea of creating this project has drawn great interest from a female director, four female actors, one transgender actor and one male actor. It's time to write a theatre script, for women in theatre, about women to allow real women to perform where their voices will be heard.

Lady Garden takes place in a garden allotment in the London area for the local community, focusing on the local community requirements, whether the main purpose of their visit is hibernation, a re-focus of mind and body, establishing a gardening routine, making new friends or to celebrate a special occasion, each woman has her patch of garden to either become a recluse or to reach out and communicate.


Defined Method of Approach

The Lady Garden project will be a collaborative process in which the playwright / creative producer will provide a framework upon which the Lady Garden script will be created, defined by the female director, four female actors, one transgender actor and one male actor.

The director and actors will work in collaboration to workshop the framework into a production ready, full length stage script. 

The director and actors will work with the playwright to determine the path of the story, plot and character outcomes.

The playwright will form part of the decision making process in line with the director to decide upon story relevance, strength of plot and character driven ideas, making final decisions on the story’s path, framework and dialogue. All this, culminated from the collaborative work completed with the actors.


Research and Development

Using the framework of creative ideas, the director and actors will decide what story to tell and how they tell it. Through a collaborative process, they will generate an organic storyline by researching their characters, the world in which those characters live and how they cohabitate. 

The final outcome from the research and development workshop will deliver a final draft, production ready, full length stage script. 

The full length stage script will formulate a ‘stage 2 project’ plan with an outlook of mounting a fully staged professional production, engaging the original team.


The Impact

A common problem in theatre is a lack of available good quality scripts for women, real women (not a caricature), for older woman and for women from diverse backgrounds. The Lady Garden project will provide:

  • a strong, diverse, powerful and compassionate story for women about women.
  • providing opportunity to work, to perform and speak with a strong voice.
  • a script told by women, constructed by women, for women.


Risks & Challenges

Our transparency is clear. Our obstacles at delivering such a powerful script include lack of funding and lack of ongoing financial support. The artists need to eat, support families and be part of an equal equation. The artist's talents and passionate commitment to their art requires remuneration .

  • Your generous and appreciated financial support through donations will assist us to overcome our financial challenges.
  • Strong social media profiles, ongoing marketing and constant communication will assist our project immensely to avoid the risk of failing this project.


The Playwright

Darren Brealey has written over 30 plays and has had many of them produced around the globe; although he is not a global name. He is well known for his self confession about his writing, "I don't write about Fairytale sunsets and I'm not about to start now." He is a perceptive playwright with the ability to expose the flaws in the human condition, to hit home.
Brealey wrote and produced his first full length play before the age of 25 years and it won an Award for Best New Production in the 1996 Melbourne Fringe Festival Awards. With many awards, recognition and much work to show, Brealey tirelessly works on new theatre projects, assists others with their work and lives for the theatre. "Theatre is what gets me out of bed in the morning". 
Lady Garden is a new piece of writing for Brealey, yet more importantly, a new way of working for him. Collaborating with a female Director, four female actors, one transgender actor and (for balance of scale) one male actor, this writing process will allow Brealey to work directly with creative input and work in a cohesive and collaborative process to create a new piece of amazing theatre. 
His heritage is full of strong women. 

Project Deliverables and Desired Outcomes

The desired deliverable of the Lady Garden project will be to deliver a production ready, full length stage script.

The desired outcomes include:

  • the creation of new work in the theatre for women with powerful, embracing and inclusive dialogue with a positive message to women, about women
  • the creation of a new project plan to be called a ‘stage 2 project’ where funding is sought with a vision for a fully professionally produced production; once the current project life cycle has been delivered and considered a success
  • holding an award winning script for future productions of equity paid work, school productions and community theatre productions for women with an outcome to spread the positive messages in the Lady Garden script


Scope

Lady Garden is an artistic project with the intent to deliver the following inclusions:

  • humanity
  • comedy
  • challenging perceptions of gender
  • describe a haven
  • international characters and their cultures, views and experiences
  • contrasting stories about women
  • community spirit
  • a transgender character
  • sexual preference
  • financial standing
  • class / social standing
  • personality
  • religious beliefs
  • marital status
  • family, children and siblings
  • employment status 


What We Need & What You Get

The Lady Garden project is quite simple for Stage 1:

  • Our budget for Stage 1 is simple, we want to (and need to) pay wages, venue hire, food, administration and insurance. This 15 day project will provide fully paid work for these artisans.
  • With different levels of support for you to choose from, we'll pack a punch to match your generosity when you pick a perk. Should you wish to remain anonymous, we will respect your privacy. 


Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word. It would be amazing if you could share to the world on social media our desire to create our world class theatre by independent artists. We would love to be able to write the Lady Garden.

LET'S MAKE SOME NOISE

We are grateful and appreciate your donation and support. Should you be unable to provide financial assistance, you can still help. Please spread to the world on social media.

Remember to use the Indiegogo share tools.


* Flowers painted by Darren Brealey

story:
Our book festival is backed by award-winning writers and leading figures in Welsh public life.

We hope to get your support to create awareness of it and get people talking about it.

This year we'll host a three-day festival aimed at promoting reading, writing and debate to the Welsh capital for the first time this autumn (28-30th October 2016).

It comes in the year the city celebrates the centenary of its most famous literary son, Roald Dahl.

Our ambition is to continue to grow every year adding more events and putting the Cardiff Book Festival on the literary map.

To give you a flavour of what you can see at the festival, we'll have events with Ifor ap Glyn, the national poet of Wales, award-winning writers including Rachel Trezise and Jonathan Edwards and the investigative journalist, Martin Williams.

We are aiming to raise £5,000 via Indiegogo but the more we're able to raise, the more events we can organise at the festival.

As well as helping the festival get off the ground, we're offering supporters a range of experiences including signed books, Roald Dahl walking tours, masterclasses with award-winning authors including Rachel Trezise and workshops with publishers and agents on how budding writers can get into print.

We have the support of Cardiff University, Literature Wales, the City of Cardiff Council and leading figures from a range of areas of Welsh life.

Our aim is to have a diverse and inclusive programme featuring talks and debates from high profile figures on topics ranging from poetry to politics, crime writing to children’s events, fiction to feminism and the Welsh language to walking tours.

We hope you'd like to be a part of it. 

Here's some media coverage of our launch:

http://www.walesonline.co.uk/whats-on/arts-cult...
story_txt: Our book festival is backed by award-winning writers and leading figures in Welsh public life.We hope to get your support to create awareness of it and get people talking about it.This year we'll host a three-day festival aimed at promoting reading, writing and debate to the Welsh capital for the first time this autumn (28-30th October 2016).It comes in the year the city celebrates the centenary of its most famous literary son, Roald Dahl.Our ambition is to continue to grow every year adding more events and putting the Cardiff Book Festival on the literary map.To give you a flavour of what you can see at the festival, we'll have events with Ifor ap Glyn, the national poet of Wales, award-winning writers including Rachel Trezise and Jonathan Edwards and the investigative journalist, Martin Williams.We are aiming to raise £5,000 via Indiegogo but the more we're able to raise, the more events we can organise at the festival.As well as helping the festival get off the ground, we're offering supporters a range of experiences including signed books, Roald Dahl walking tours, masterclasses with award-winning authors including Rachel Trezise and workshops with publishers and agents on how budding writers can get into print.We have the support of Cardiff University, Literature Wales, the City of Cardiff Council and leading figures from a range of areas of Welsh life.Our aim is to have a diverse and inclusive programme featuring talks and debates from high profile figures on topics ranging from poetry to politics, crime writing to children’s events, fiction to feminism and the Welsh language to walking tours.We hope you'd like to be a part of it. Here's some media coverage of our launch:http://www.walesonline.co.uk/whats-on/arts-cult...

story:
#WhoIsBrian?

Brian is the central character of our play, one of the many people killed by prejudicial police brutality whilst in custody. 

Like Brian, every victim has a bereaved family with a story to tell. 'Custody' represents one of those many stories.

----------------------------
 

'Custody', created by Urbain Hayo (The Art Machine) and written by Tom Wainwright (BBC 1 and Radio 4), will be a full-length play directed by Gbemi Ikumelo, of the award-winning theatre company Faith Drama Productions.

Once Custody is successful in raising its required budget, the play will go on tour, premiering at the legendary Theatre Royal Stratford East, in November this year.

'Custody' will be filmed and documented by award winning director Shabazz L. Graham of the story collaboration group, Emotive Narrative. 
 

----------------------------
 

WHY ARE WE CROWDFUNDING?

We need your support to help us stage a full-length play throughout the UK and beyond.

Backing this project will enable us to stage the play in November and record it for the purpose of attracting more needed attention to this emotive story.
 


CUSTODY: RESEARCH & DEVELOPMENT

In early 2015 'Custody' went through the first phase of research and development (R & D), culminating in an extract sharing to a small audience who provided feedback which helped the writer's development of the story for the full-length version of the play. The team is now more excited than ever to get this powerful show on the road.
 


FDP

Faith Drama Productions is an established arts organisation that celebrates its 10th anniversary this year. Under the visionary guidance of FDP's Artistic Director, Gbemisola Ikumelo, the organisation supports emerging artists, like our lead creative Urbain, helping them realise their potential. FDP are experienced in staging mid- to large-scale new productions and have performed works both in established theatres and site-specific unconventional spaces, in London and throughout the UK.
 

 

STAGING CUSTODY

Once successful with our Indiegogo campaign, we will be able to stage Custody in the 'Gerry' studio at The Theatre Royal Stratford East which is a long-established theatre in the London Borough of Newham. Since 1953 it has produced Olivier award-winning shows and plays that have also transferred to the West End. They recently launched the 'Gerry' studio, a 60-seater space that runs opposite the main house, in which they have already successfully presented several well-received new shows similar to 'Custody'. 

We are looking for to raise £20,000 to kick start our play and get it on the road.


We have managed to raise a small amount of seed money, which helped with our R & D phase and have strong interest from Arts Council England, who expect us to raise at least 40% percentage of our overall budget ourselves before they will consider offering us a grant.

Whilst artists and creative people are often extremely generous with their time, many practical production costs are unavoidable, such as rehearsal and equipment hire, front-of-house and technical staff, touring accommodation and transportation costs to name a few.

 

DONATION PERKS

Please check out our donation perks, and feel free to suggest new ones if you don't see what you would like from us.

Please support by sharing this campaign on social media using #whoisbrian? 
 

Twitter: @CustodyPlay    |     Facebook: @Custodyplay

 

---------------------------------------

 

THE CUSTODY TEAM

 



Urbain Hayo - Lead Creative, Actor (Brian's Brother)


Urbain is the Artistic director of The Art Machine. He has primarily worked as an actor in the theatre but has now ventured into writing, producing and fine art. His work focuses on telling stories that challenge and change society. Custody is Urbain's first play that has been produced.

 

Tom Wainwright - Co-Writer


Tom was selected for the Royal Court theatre’s exclusive Young Writers Programme in 2010 and was invited back the same year for their autumn studio group. Tom is a writer and performer based in Bristol. Writing credits include Emo (ATC/Bristol Old Vic Young Company), Hansel and Gretel and 10W2 (Theatre Royal Bath), The Egg – Urban Arts and Shakespeare Unplugged respectively), Run and Fallen (Bristol Old Vic Young Company) and Come to Where I’m From (Paines Plough).

 

Gbemisola Ikumelo - Director


Gbemisola is an award-winning actress and director and is the founder of FAITH Drama Productions. In 2011 Gbemisola won the John Fernald award for emerging directors and has since written and directed a number of projects for stage and film. Theatre credits include: ‘Life on the Stairs’ which toured nationally over 3 years; ‘The Fiddler’, which ran successfully at the Unicorn Theatre; and 'Next Door', which premiered at The Cockpit Theatre. She also directed a short adaptation of 'The Rise and Shine of Comrade Fiasco', which was performed at the Royal National Theatre.

 

Cindy Claes - Movement Director


Born and raised in Belgium, Cindy moved to London in 2005.  Her artistic journey kept expanding during her numerous adventures as a dance backpacker.  She has researched her artistry and craft extensively over the years and has travelled to Africa, the U.S.A., the Caribbean and all over Europe, collecting invaluable experiences along the way.

 

John Russell Gordon - Dramaturge


John R Gordon is a multi-award-winning novelist, graphic artist, playwright and screenwriter of gay black lives, and has been nominated for a NAACP Image Award. He is a founder-member of Rikki Beadle-Blair's Team Angelica and runs their book imprint. With Rikki, for the past seven years, he has mentored diverse LGBT and BAME playwrights through their Angelic Tales new writers' scheme at Theatre Royal Stratford East and seen some of those writers go on to real success. He regularly mentors and dramaturgs up-and-coming playwrights, screenwriters and novelists. His most recent novel - his sixth - is 'Souljah'.

 

Thomas Kell - Producer


Thomas Kell is a theatre producer and consultant. He began his career with Theatre Centre and served as the administrative director of Tiata Fahodzi for seven years. He is currently supporting a range of companies and projects including Pursued by Bear, the Elufowoju Jr Ensemble, Tangle and Faith Drama. Thomas is delighted to be helping to produce 'Custody'. This is a play of urgency and importance, and deeply worthy of support from every sector of society.

 

Shabazz Graham - Filmmaker


Shabazz L. Graham is a visionary director and skilled editor with over 20 years experiences in the UK creative industry. He is the Head of Post Production at Salt TV, a leading advertising film production company, based in London's creative centre Soho. Shabazz works to evoke emotion in every production he is a part of. In 2016 he launched Emotive Narrative, a collaboration and consultation group which helps storytellers communicate their ideas better through understanding the power of human emotions.

 

Faith Omole - Actor (Brian's Sister)


Faith trained at the Royal Central School of Speech and Drama. Her credits whilst training include Cabaret, Spring Awakening, Richard II, The Rover and Twelfth Night.

 

Chereen Buckley - Actor (Brian's Fiancé)


Chereen graduated from the 3-year acting course at RADA in 2011. Previous to this she was working with BAFTA award-winning director Ben Kellet, playing Belinda in THIEVES LIKE US for the BBC.

 

Jacqueline Acheampong - Actor (Brian's Mother)
 

Jacqueline was awarded a full scholarship to study at City Lit three year drama training.

 

 

-------------------------------
 

We remember:

Christopher Alder,   Sean Rigg,   David Oluwale,   Brian Douglas,   Alton Sterling,   Sandra Bland,   Eric Garner,   Sheku Bayoh,   Habib Ullah,   Ralkina Jones,   Daniel Rodrigo Saenz,   Adama Traore,   Freddie Gray,   Natasha McKenna,   Mzee Mohammed,   Mark Duggan,   Dalian Atkinson

story:
Our Story

In March, several students from exalt (a development program for court-involved youth) and a New School student joined a bus of young people to meet with senators to advocate for the issue of Raise the Age. After talking with many senators and listening to the stories of graduates of exalt, as a team we recognized that these stories should be heard on a larger level and are fundamentally important to the passing of this law. This past summer, Eugene Lang  partnered with exalt to develop a performance, 16 Bars-Youth (Off)Ending Justice. The style of this piece is documentary theater, so the content is based off of interviews performed by the students with each other as well as facilitated by the teachers. The culminating performance will take place at a conference hosted by Eugene Lang professors, Arts Advocacy: Youth in the System also on the topic of Raise the Age. During the three day event, students will have the opportunity to meet CBOs working on this issue and plan and propose a related event. Friday, September 9th there will be a 'Thinking Out Loud' event featuring successful artists who work with youth of color in New York City, including Liza Jessie Peterson, creator of Peculiar Patriot, and Jamal Joseph, a teacher at Columbia University, former Black Panther and creator of Chapter and Verse.

Raise the Age

New York and North Carolina are the only states that automatically try 16-17 year olds as adults. Latest scientific research shows that the frontal cortex (decision making part) of the brain is not fully developed until age 25. Violent offenders aged 13-15 are sometimes also prosecuted in adult court and receive adult level sentences. Youth housed in adult facilities are 36 times more likely to commit suicide than in youth facilities. 80% of young people released from adult facilities end up back in the prison system. Over 70% of the children and youth arrested are Black or Latino.  Of those sentenced to incarceration, 80% are Black and Latino. For more information visit http://raisetheageny.com.

Our Team

Brian Lewis--Co-Facilitator/Director

Cecilia Rubino--Co-Facilitator/Director

Louisa Strothman--Project Manager/Assistant Director

Naomi Khanukayev--Media Designer/Assistant Director

Aasim Rasheed--Assistant Media Designer

Morgan Stevenson--Assistant Director

Josefina Perez--Assistant Director/Stage Manager

What We Need

This money will go to making sure this project makes the impact it needs to to get this law changed. And with your donation, you have the satisfaction of helping out a worthy cause, and if you so choose one of our lovely perks. 

Specifically this money will go to:

  • payment for editor so a film of the process of the piece can be shown and official trailer

  • funds to document and evaluate the performance so that it can be recreated with other groups of young people facing the same or similar issues. 

  • Honorariums for guest speakers at the Arts Advocacy conference who are all artists and scholars who speak about the issues that the young people in the performance face. 

  • Cameras to record performance

The Impact

The past two years Governor Cuomo has proposed a bill to raise the age of criminal responsibility which has been overturned both times. The house is very divided on this issue and the issue has not gotten the attention it deserves. This means there is still work to put pressure on our representatives for the next legislative session. When talking with legislators we learned that many of them are not only unaware of the facts of brain development in young people, but also that they had never heard stories of the kids who are directly impacted by these laws. 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Spread the word about Raise the Age, and this campaign! Register for and attend the symposium: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/arts-advocacy-youth-in-the-system-tickets-27007869264 as well as assist with outreach by posting to social media
  • Get educated on the laws of your state and elected officials, including prosecutors, judges, legislators and many other people who have a hand in making and carrying out laws and petition them to get Raise the Age and other worthy causes passed
  •  Spread the word about Raise the Age, and this campaign!
  • Get educated on the laws of your state and elected officials, including prosecutors, judges, legislators and many other people who have a hand in making and carrying out laws and petition them to get Raise the Age and other worthy causes passed

story:
Haygen & Elaina: a brief his/herstory

Oh wow, where to begin... It all started in the year of 2009 as two young, naive, presumably innocent freshman at The University of the Arts in Philadelphia. We met... didn't like each other... a semester passed... and then we fell in love. 

 

FAST FORWARD!

  • Oh hey! I'm Elaina Di Monaco (and I'm Haygen Brice Walker!) and together we have formed ON THE ROCKS, a producing umbrella for our collaborative works. This is our #adulting theatre baby full of queer-wild-junkfood-popculture-millennial-magic. Haygen is the playwright. Elaina is the director. And we co-produce!
  • Birdie's Pit Stop is our first full-length production as an official collective and we couldn't be more excited to share it with you. Both of us identify as queer millennials and are active theatre-makers. The more we advance, the more of a void we feel in the work we're seeing on stage. The voice of the queer millennial is not fully present on Philadelphia stages and we, as artists, consider it our mission to fix that. This piece is a love letter to our people!

OUR NEEDS & DONOR-KARMA!

In order to make this production happen, we need money. We both have made personal contributions to the project (Fringe fees, insurance, so many props, etc) and have also made every effort to eliminate unnecessary purchases (living room rehearsals, borrowing, crafting). From this point forward, we're counting on you! 

  • We need to raise $1500! 
  • That money will go directly to the following: Venue fees, scenery, props, costumes, marketing, fake blood and wigs! 

THE WHY

As emerging theatre artists, we work around the clock to make our work, build our careers and pay our bills. We do this because we can't imagine doing anything else. We do it because we have stories to share. We do it because we have something to say.

  • This play is special. We are taking risks in the way we engage with audiences through this piece. We're challenging the status-quo of what makes good theatre. We're bringing new genres to the stage. Most importantly, we're putting queer millennials on the stage in a way that you probably haven't seen them before.  Yay queers! Yay millennials! Yay theatre!
  • We plan on blowing your minds with our queer-theatre-magic.  We want to blow your brains the way Beyonce blew the brains off the VMAS.  The way Ryan Lochte's abs blew the brains off of millions (why are they so hard?).  The way Rooney Mara blew the dragon tattoo off of the girl.

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't contribute? That's okay!

  • Share this campaign on your Facebook/Insta/Twitter! 
  • TELL YOUR FRIENDS!
  • Come see the show! TICKETS HERE!

Other Ways You Can Help
Can't contribute? That's okay!

Share this campaign on your Facebook/Insta/Twitter! 
TELL YOUR FRIENDS!
Come see the show! TICKETS HERE!

story:
Our Mission

To create thoughtful  theater, with an emphasis in visual and verbal story telling. We focus on found-space theater, and cultivating an appreciation for thoughtful design, and direction, with family friendly, classic, and current theater.

Our Vision

To become a leader in Local theater, become a staple of regional theater, to become a nationally recognized theater, and to build local culture, as a destination for professional artists.

Why We need You!

Community support is always a key ingredient to any new arts organization. Funding to support this Unique company, would mean bringing a new perspective to local performing arts.

story:
Short Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • I am an award-winning playwright and stage director.
  • I aim to present a polished production in a major New York theatre festival in hopes of generating interest from producers for a commercial production or screen adaptation.
  • Contributors will help me achieve my dream of getting my play the exposure that is necessary for it to lead to opportunities for further production and development.

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • I need $1500 to mount a polished production of my one-act, three character play.
  • Perks include playbill credits for major theater festival production, tickets to a performance and producer credits for a future production!
  • If we do not reach the funding goal, the funds will go to creating the best possible production for the festival.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know the difference their contribution will make:

  • The themes of the play, including family, acceptance, marriage and LGBT issues, are universal and issues that touch us all at some point in our lives. This story should be seen and shared.
  • Previous crowdfunding campaigns I've created were very successful and helped make 2 NY stage productions possible, including an award-nominated play.
  • I have a record of staging award-winning plays in NY with talented actors and designers, creating major roles for women and people over 40.

Risks & Challenges

People value your transparency. Be open and stand out by providing insight into the risks and obstacles you may face on the way to achieving your goal.

  • Given my success at raising funds via crowdfunding in the past, I am confident I will achieve the goal stated in this campaign, through diligence and persistence.
  • I plan to source social media for updated information on this production and encourage participation and dialogue from participants.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Even if you are unable to contribute to this campaign, please help us get the word out about this exciting new production!
  • Please be sure to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.

story:
Our Story

(By Odessa)

We’re working on a piece that's highly personal, but we think you’ll find it resonates with you too. Why? Because we all have bodies, we all have homes, and we’ve all had really trying experiences that we’ve had to come back from, heal, and return to some semblance of self.

After three years in California, countless dwellings I’ve called home, and one, singularly traumatic event that scared me out of my body, I’m reflecting on the following:

  • What does it mean to recover somatically from a life-threatening experience?
  • How does the contrast of city and nature serve as a outer metaphorical context of our inner realities?

Your support will make this project a reality, and enable us to travel back to my first home to perform this. We’ll be returning to my homeland of Jersey City, NJ to perform in Your Move Modern Dance Festival, a festival I envisioned and founded back in 2010.

Coming Home is a healing in and of itself, as well as a retrospective on what I have discovered in my search for home. I hope that anyone who has withstood trauma, or who has come up against similar questions will find a morsel of their own story in this piece.

 

What We Need & What You Get

Dance is expensive to produce. 

Your Move Dance Festival is not able to pay artists performance fees, but they do take care of all printing, advertising, theater rental and technical staffing costs - so it's actually way cheaper for us to perform with them then to strike out on our own.

Your contribution pays for the bare-bones necessities: studio space, costumes, equipment, and our travel to the east coast from California.

If we make our goal, we'll be able to fly Anthony out to perform, in his own way, with Odessa.

Rather than just send Odessa along with a video that is played alongside the dance, our vision is to include improvisational interactive video alongside the dance, to create for an awe-inspiring, vivid and immediate experience. For this to happen, Anthony, our video artist, needs to be there in person.

We’ll also be able to pay our artists for their time - we love doing our art, and we also believe that artists need to be compensated for their time because this is worthwhile and necessary work in the world!!

If we make above and beyond our goal, we’ll be able to perform this in Nevada City and up and down the west coast.

Your perks include awesome art prints from Anthony, gifted healing sessions from Odessa, essential oil samples, and even a fitness package. Be an angel donor and receive allllll the perks. :)

 

Who we are, and why we do what we do...

Odessa

As always, I’m getting really personal with my work! I do this because I believe vulnerability is the most powerful tool for change we have. I invite you all in to my process, and hope you find some of your story in relation to mine. 

Jersey City residents will remember the successful Art in Motion series I co-directed and produced with Justin Woo and Grassroots Community Space. I see this project as an expansion of that, and hope to spark a dialogue between Jersey City and Nevada City arts communities.

From 2008-2013, I directed my own interdisciplinary dance company, Insurgo Stage Project. Upon moving to the Bay Area in 2013, I have performed with Bianca Cabrera/Blind Tiger Society, Rosemary Hannon, and vîv, and collaborated with dancer/filmmaker Daniel Mollner.

Anthony

Anthony “sirios” West is an artist whose works mirror the journey of self. From his studio in the foothills of Northern California, he creates art that represents the natural ebb and flow of our Collective Experience.  A creator since his youth, he was introduced to meditation at a young age and quickly became aware of the power of thought. Anthony’s work is a journey through the inner workings of the mind and its undeniable powers of manifestation. Anthony ’sirios” Wests work is not a creation of the mind but a manifestation of spirit into the visual realm. He seeks to inspire spiritual awareness within the viewer allowing them to access their own ability as co creators and beings of unlimited potential.

As a video artist, Anthony’s video projections and installations have been featured at conscious dance and music festivals Lucidity, Lightening in a Bottle, Burning Man (Sacred Spaces) and Enchanted Forest, as well as supporting producers and musicians such as Random Rab, Desert Dwellers and Deya Dova.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Although financial contribution is what will fuel this project into reality, if that’s not realistic for you, please spread the word!

  • Please share this campaign to your social media following, email lists, or whatever other tools you have.
  • We’ll also be posting updates as we build the project, and invite you to engage in these by commenting and also sharing with your network.

Thank you for reading, for caring, and for sharing!!

story:
The company

Door Ajar Theatre formed in 2015 to bring Thisbe, a sequel to A Midsummer Night's Dream, to the Vault Festival. The play, a unique vision of the infamous lovers and their calamitous daughter tussling with their past and futures, was a huge success, winning a 'Spirit of the Festival' award.

Door Ajar utilises clever stagecraft, humour and music to convey tales of the heart, families, friendships and the twists and turns of human nature, presenting exciting stories with live music. The company is committed to championing the work of actor-musicians.

But what are we up to this Christmas?

The shows

It's time for those burning festive questions to finally be answered.

  • Who or what is the Christmas Goat?
  • How can you get your hands on a coveted Norwegian marzipan pig?
  • How long should you be keeping your yuletide carp in the bath before eating?
  • Is Krampus really husband material?

Around the World on Christmas Day is a celebration of traditions & tales from all over the globe, with a talented cast of four actor-musicians.

And in the daytime, a pair of Hans Christian Andersen's best-loved tales for ages 3+ - The Little Match Girl, and The Fir Tree.

These classic stories for young children will be told through puppetry, and we'll also be offering workshops for children to meet the puppets and have a play themselves.

The Little Match Girl was a hit at the 2015 Latitude Festival and we're thrilled to be extending the show and bringing it to London.

Around the World on Christmas Day is being directed by Tim Bell. The Hans Christian Andersen double bill is being directed by Roberta Zuric.

Sounds great, right? However...

We need your help

We'd love to make these shows for free, but that Christmas goat has expensive tastes.

We'll be making some money back from selling tickets, but we need funds upfront to do things like - 

  • Paying our amazing cast and creative team.
  • Buying costumes and building sets.
  • Hiring rehearsal spaces (and buying teabags to keep rehearsals moving).

This is where you come in. Anything you can give will go a long way.

But why should I?

Partly to stop Krampus taking you away. But also:

  • You'll be supporting a brand new performance space in Walthamstow.
  • You'll be helping to bring theatre to children and families at Christmas.
  • Your money will be paying professional artists a proper wage so they can do what they do best.

We need to raise £1,000 to get things going. Even a single pound helps us get there.

And even if you don't have the money...

...you can still help by getting the word out!

  • Share this page far and wide.
  • Like us on Facebook, follow us on Twitter.
  • Tell everyone you meet in the street about the Christmas Goat and point them towards Walthamstow.

Thank you - without your support we couldn't do this.

story:
Peering Through the Window

This season Next Reflex Dance Collective brings their newest work "The INtimate Window" to the stage in several different performances.  This choreography is inspired by Michele Iverson's photographic series "Night Surveillance" and peers inside our intimate spaces and exposes our voyeuristic nature.  This project is a collaborative one between choreographer Roxann Morgan Rowley ,the dancers of NRDC and musician Mark Snyder.  The dancers will move in and out of a  10'X10' performance space where a projection from the ceiling will cast an environment on the floor for each intimate section. The choreography explores more closely the intimate settings from Iverson's photos entangling the audience in a web of relationships , solo gluttony and erotic fascination. 

 

Next Reflex Dance Collective

Next Reflex Dance Collective was founded by Roxann Morgan Rowley and Erika Surma in 2007.  An award winning modern dance company based in Northern Virginia, NRDC has been presented throughout the region by multiple venues and festivals including The DC Dance Festival, The Charlotte Dance Festival, The DUMBO Dance Festival, The Cool NY Dance Festival, The Goose Route Dance Festival, The Howard Community Festival, Mason/Rhynes Productions “Late Night Series”, The Carter Barron Amphitheater, The Workhouse Arts Center, The American Dance Institute, Dance Place, The Harman Center for the Arts, The 2010 Metro DC Dance Awards, The National Theater, The John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, among others. NRDC has received support from the Puffin Foundation, the Arts Council of the Valley, the DC Commission for the Arts and Humanities, the Virginia Commission for the Arts, and the Arts Council of Fairfax County.

It is NRDC’s mission to create art collaboratively with artists of all disciplines and to support the creation of experimental dance work. As a unit, we are committed to creating new work which challenges ideas and broadens perceptions, while also encouraging experimentation at the highest level. We are devoted to being a part of our dance community’s growth through the inclusion of various artists in specific performance and outreach programs. Each NRDC collaborator brings a new community of not only audience but also outreach to our collective.

 

It's All About the Performance

The "INtimate Window" will be performed in several festivals and venues this performance season.  Specifically the company will be presented at the University of Mary Washington in October, Third Practice Music Festival in November, Barn Dance Music Festival in November, Small Plates Dance Festival in November and NRDC in Concert in the Spring of 2017. 

 

 

 

Fund the Artist

NRDC needs help supporting the artists involved with this project.  Funds raised during our campaign will go to pay musicians and dancers that are involved with "The INtimate Window." 

 

Breaking it Down

"The INtimate Window" will be performed in 4 performances throughout NRDC's performance season, employing 8 dancers and 4 musicians with each performance.  To help pay the artists involved we are trying to raise $2500.  Other expenses that are attached to these performances are; $400 venue rental , $200 for projection equipment, $400 for hotel and travel expenses, $200 for costumes and $100 for printing costs associated with advertising and production.  These expenses total over $3800.  NRDC is receiving generous support from grants and individual donations to go towards our production expenses.  This campaign will ensure funds for the artists involved . 

 

What If?

What if we aren't able to make our goal?  We hope to make our goal and then some but if we don't we will still divide all funds among the artists involved. 

 

Support NRDC at a Performance

If you are unable to contribute to our campaign attend one of our performances.  Or NRDC is always looking for volunteers.  Whether its, handing out programs, taking tickets or helping us find new ways of engaging with our community NRDC is always looking for individuals to help us move forward.  For more information please go to www.nextreflex.org.
